PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent a minister making one declaration of urgency and moving one motion for the allotment of time in respect of the Aged Care Bill 1997, the Aged Care (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997 and the Aged Care (Compensation Amendments) Bill 1997.

I move this motion to suspend standing orders so as to facilitate the House's consideration of this important package of bills which is currently before the House. By moving this suspension and the guillotine motion, we will set up a situation so that we can finish the House's consideration of this legislation today.

The reason there is some urgency about this matter is that this is important legislation and the government is keen to see the passage of the legislation through the House and into the Senate by the conclusion of today's business. I can only conclude that the Labor Party has little desire to see the passage of this legislation in a timely manner. I think all honourable members would be disappointed that, in particular, the shadow minister for social security, the aged and family services, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), sees this as an opportunity to run a scare campaign rather than to contribute in a constructive way to reforming the aged care system for the benefit of senior citizens.

The government cannot afford to accommodate a tactic of delay. The Senate's timetable is tight and it is important that this legislation be presented to the Senate without further delay. For any possible outcome that would see this legislation come back to the House to consider amendments following debate in the Senate, the legislation has to go to the Senate this week.

BREAK.PARA: One of the reasons for urgency is that this legislation needs to be passed through both houses before 1 July to enable a full implementation of the total reform package by 1 October. I do not need to remind members that we are in the first week of June, the scheme, in part, is to commence on 1 July and, naturally, with the long delays in the Senate, we cannot afford to dillydally any further. The legislation will enable the income testing component of the legislation to begin on 1 July.

TALK.START.PARA: —Be nice to be told about this.
—You were told about it. Not only was the Manager of Opposition Business told about it, but he was told about it on Monday morning.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. That is a lie.
—The honourable member for Hotham has means at his disposal to pursue the argument further later, otherwise you must withdraw.
—I didn't say the minister was a liar; I said that that assertion was a lie. But in deference to the chair—
—Order! We are not going to debate the technicalities.
—In deference to the chair—
—I want an unreserved withdrawal.
—I make an unreserved withdrawal. Can I just make the point—
—Sit down.
—Order! Resume your seat.
—There was no indication—
—Resume your seat now.
—There was no indication that you were moving this today—none at all.
—I warn the member for Hotham.

—It has been the end of a long fortnight for the Labor Party. The Manager of Opposition Business has just come in from a crisis meeting with the leader about divisions in the Labor Party. He is worried about the credibility of the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner). He is worried about the credibility of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). He does not like being accused of walking down memory lane with Pauline Hanson. No wonder he is a bit edgy as he walks in late this morning, knowing full well that this motion was being moved this morning. In fact, I rang his office 15 minutes ago as a final and last‐ditch attempt to see if we could talk some sense into them, but of course he was not available.

BREAK.PARA: We have always indicated that this particular component of the legislation—namely, the income testing component—would have to commence three months prior to the start‐up date of the complete reform package, which is 1 October. The bottom line is that the government has to do all it can to guarantee the legislation's passage through both houses in the month of June.

Allowing the legislation to stay in the House beyond this week would have placed in jeopardy the start‐up date of the income testing as well as the general start‐up date of 1 October. The aged care reform package needs to be implemented by 1 October so that we can start delivering better care to elderly Australians, something that this opposition never did when they were in government and something which they now want to stop when they are in opposition—even though in terms of the general thrusts, directions and principles of this legislation, it mirrors legislation and they general direction of reforms that they themselves introduced when they were in government.

The last guillotine we had in this place, on my quick assessment of the records, was back in 1996. We do not lightly move a guillotine motion. But in circumstances where there is real urgency and where we have been unable to obtain any cooperation from the opposition, we have but no choice in the interests of older Australians to proceed and ensure that this package is dealt with in a timely way by the parliament.

More generally, I think it is fair to say that both the government and the opposition have benefited from the cooperation which from time to time we have been able to achieve in the management of the business of the House. Whilst today I think does reflect a return to more base elements within the opposition, I would hope that once this issue is out of the way and properly dealt with we can resume a cooperative and sensible approach to the debating and management of bills before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this the new warm and fuzzy leadership?

—This is not new, warm or fuzzy. For example, we were prepared to support a member of the opposition frontbench raising a matter of privilege before the House. Where it is fair and reasonable that the opposition have matters that they want to bring before the House, we are happy to facilitate them.

BREAK.PARA: For example, on Monday we raised the issue of the handling of this Aged Care Bill and the need to have it through by the end of this week. We did say on Monday that we wanted to avoid the guillotine. The opposition's main concern was to ensure that there was adequate time for consideration in detail of this bill, and our response to that concern was to say that we would allow as much time as the opposition basically wanted for consideration in detail. It is fair enough that they should have the opportunity to raise issues in that way.

We have, quite frankly, done all that we reasonably can to facilitate the debate. We have had 19 speakers so far. We would have at least seven today but for the fact that we are now going to spend an hour on a guillotine motion, which is only depriving people of the opportunity to speak. I think that is unfortunate, but for some sort of tactical reason on the opposition side they have decided that, instead of facilitating the sensible management of this bill through the House, they would prefer to spend an hour on a debate over a guillotine, which I think is a complete nonsense—but that is the choice that they make.

As recently as Tuesday night we have facilitated the reasonable management of the House, for example, on the appropriations bill, where we facilitated 26 opposition speakers in the chamber against 25 government speakers, with nine of those restricting themselves to approximately 10 minutes as against the norm of 20 minutes enjoyed by opposition speakers. I think we were fair in our dealing with that. We have basically twice as many as you people and yet you are getting twice as much time to speak as some of our people. We are prepared to do that in consideration of the cooperative attitude that we take to these issues.

Under all of these circumstances, we obviously have absolutely no choice. I dare say that the Manager of Opposition Business will tell us that it is jackboots democracy and all the like, and we will be entertained by his fulminations about management of the House. But, in all reality, this bill needs to go through today. It needs to get up to the Senate so that the component parts which start on 1 July can do so. It is a very important part of the reform approach being adopted by the excellent minister that we have in charge of this legislation, the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan). I compliment her on the work that she is doing.

It is unfortunate that, both on the substance of this issue and in the management of the consideration of this bill, the opposition only want to score a few political points. But I think most Australians will appreciate that we have bent over backwards. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —What bill? I thought you were moving a motion, Minister. Given that you do not know what else is going on in this place, it is little wonder that you get flummoxed. Let me say this: we are opposing this proposal before the House at the moment because of the lack of process by this oil slick over here, the Leader of the House (Mr Reith). He has had the gall to come into this chamber and say we were told about this.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I just say what happened to put this process into perspective: we got a call at 20 past nine or thereabouts to say a guillotine would be moved but it would be moved at 12 o'clock. And here he is, sliding his way into this place at 9.30—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—
—Sit down unless you have a point of order!
—Mr Speaker, I have a point of order in exactly the same terms as the Manager of Opposition Business had, but mine is a more polite one: that is not true.

—Well, then let us get the records out, Minister. Here is the guy, baton in the knapsack, now with the jackboots on. Here is the guy who saw the Treasurer (Mr Costello) last night upstage his Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and feels he has to be in here today being tougher. Here is the man trying to get a few more little magazine clips for his Sunday program cameos. This is the man who takes no time managing the House but all the time working the backbench and the numbers for the future leadership.

BREAK.PARA: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There they are, cheering him on. How many can you count on today? Can I say this to the backbench: I hope he treats you more honestly than he treats us. This is a person whom we have cooperated with in the management of this House. In terms of the appropriation bills, we agreed to the 26 speakers coming into the main chamber on the basis that there would be unlimited time in the Main Committee. There was never any talk there of the guillotine.

BREAK.PARA: What we have here is a bill that ought to be delayed because the community affected by it is calling for its delay. There is so much uncertainty associated with the proposition. The churches and the private providers are saying that the prudential requirements are not known. How are they expected to function in the context of this thing that you are steamrolling through the parliament without allowing due process? The fact of the matter is we always know when you are in strife with your bills: because you come in with the guillotine.

It is not the only issue before the House in relation to which they have been in trouble. They want to steamroll this through the House because they know they need legislation. Let me just say this: another piece of legislation which they will not bring into this House quickly is the one that deals with their decision to cut car industry tariffs. The reported story today is the wisdom of Solomon approach—halfway between—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Manager of Opposition Business well knows that this is irrelevant to the motion to suspend standing orders. He ought to stick to the subject.
—There is no point of order; resume your seat.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. It is not irrelevant because this is a process demonstrating the contempt they are showing for the parliament. They want to steamroll through legislation that they have to bring in, they want to hide other pieces of legislation which they know eventually they will have to bring in and they have to try to placate the backbench.

BREAK.PARA: In relation to the car industry, the decision today, if it is adopted, will result in not all of the workers of the car industry being sacked but only half of them. That is the wisdom of Solomon. In reality, it is the stupidity of Howard—the belief that you can have a compromise proposal and the belief that you can ignore what the industry is saying to you and ignore what the rest of the world is doing in terms of their levels of support for the industry. If this decision has been taken by the cabinet, announce it and bring the legislation into this parliament forthwith. Make our day, because this legislation will not pass the Senate. Mark my words: you introduce the legislation to reduce the car tariffs and we will block it in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. So bereft is the Manager of Opposition Business in outlining any objections to what we are doing on the guillotine that he is now talking about something totally and completely unrelated. Its only relationship, even of passing interest, is his leadership ambitions within the Labor Party. It is a bit of a song and dance for the backbench on the Labor side, but it certainly has nothing to do with the matter before the House.
—I thank the minister. I think honours on both sides are about even. I call the honourable member for Hotham.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I am talking about the way the Leader of the House cannot manage this House and the way he is treating this place with contempt by not bringing important decisions before it. That is what I am talking about. This guillotine is but one example of it.

BREAK.PARA: I have mentioned this matter in terms of the car industry. The reason you will not bring the car legislation into the parliament is that your backbench is divided on it, and so is your frontbench. The other day the preferred option of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) on car tariff reform was reported. Do you know what it was? It was to actually increase car tariffs. This is the first minister to have proposed an increase in tariffs since Black Jack McEwen. No wonder the minister is called `Black Jack'. Members should understand that John Moore is the first industry minister to have proposed an increase in tariffs since Black Jack McEwen.

But he has been done by the Treasurer, as has been the Prime Minister. The Treasurer was dudding him last night on the importance of tax reform to employment, after the Prime Minister was holding up three fingers. I really reckon that yesterday the Prime Minister had two fingers up in terms of the electorate. This is the person that will not go to Newcastle. This is the person that told the people of Newcastle that he would be there soon. Five weeks have passed and he is still not there.

Where can he go before going to Newcastle? He is going via Lord's. He is going to see the cricket match. He is going to see the Australian cricket team play. But he cannot go to Newcastle. Prime Minister, I just remind you that Newcastle is that place with the smokestacks and is on the way to Hawks Nest. Why don't you go there? Why don't you go and talk to the constituents in the Hunter and in Newcastle about their future? Why wouldn't you meet the delegation from Geelong until you were forced to yesterday, when my colleague the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) has been supporting their call to keep the car industry intact?

We have got the decision today. What did he tell them yesterday? Did he look that delegation in the eye and say, `Have I got a plan for you on cars'? He said, `I'm going to sack only half of the workers in the car industry. Our approach to restructuring the car industry is to sack half of them, not all of them.' This is the Prime Minister in action, the Prime Minister who will not go to address these issues first hand, and the Leader of the House is incapable of managing the affairs of the place so that we can have decent, open debate.

I simply say to you: we will oppose this guillotine motion because this particular bill ought to be delayed. There is so much uncertainty and confusion about it that the whole of the industry is calling for delay and for further consideration. We sought to move a motion in the parliament yesterday to get that delay. We were denied it because the government used its numbers again.

This is a government without vision and without compassion. This is a government that has an inability to manage its own affairs. This is a government that is divided in its position on car tariffs. This is a government that has no idea as to how to get industry going and this is a government that has presided over a recession in the manufacturing sector. This was the government that was going to get the economy going. This was the government that was going to create jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —You stopped it.
—You stopped it.
—You stopped it.

—You are copying my words now, are you? You stopped it because you have induced the recession. You are the ones that have presided over the recession. Yesterday's national accounts say that the manufacturing sector is in recession. You have caused it. (Time expired)
—Mr Speaker—
—Is the honourable member raising a point of order?
—No, I am standing to make a contribution to this debate.
—I will call you if time permits after the minister has completed her contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a real and absolute urgent need to get this important legislation into the Senate as soon as possible. At the end of the day, the real and urgent need is for the thousands of elderly Australians who have been cared for in substandard buildings for far too long to be accommodated in appropriate buildings. We know that 40 per cent live in accommodation with four or more beds to a room. We know that 11 per cent of the buildings do not meet fire standards and safety standards. We know that 15 per cent do not meet the basic health standards.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor may have been prepared to allow this parlous state of affairs to continue indefinitely and to bury its head in the sand but this government is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of these groups have been in this parliament in the last couple of weeks and you will not meet with them.
—Order! The member for Prospect!
—Labor's real agenda on this bill today—
—Why don't you meet with the churches?
—The member for Prospect!

—Its agenda is not to see it go through the Senate but to delay and delay and delay. Mr Speaker, it is very evident that none of the speakers on that side of this debate have even bothered to read the bill. You have not even bothered to read that bill.
—Why don't you meet with the people who run these homes?
—You don't know what is contained in the bill. All they want to do is scaremonger. This is the shadow minister for scare. It is not the shadow minister for care.
—You don't care.
—You have haven't read the points in the bill.
—Order! There is too much noise in the chamber.
—The shadow minister will have her turn and maybe if she remains silent for two minutes she will listen.
—What? From the minister who won't even talk to the churches?
—Order! The member for Prospect!
—She might learn something. Mr Speaker, she keeps holding up a letter from Aged Care Australia.
—This is from the minister who won't even talk to the churches. It is an absolute disgrace.
—I warn the member for prospect.
—The fact is that on 16 May I met with the national board of Aged Care Australia. I am going to quote a summary of that meeting.
—That is wrong.
—That meeting was held on 16 May. Here is the quote.
—Minister, resume your seat. I invoke standing order 304A in respect of the member for Prospect.
—You are a dishonest minister. You won't even talk to the churches. You are a disgrace.
—Do you want to make it 24 hours?

PARA.EMPHASIS: The honourable member for Prospect thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I met with the national board—
—The minister will resume her seat.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Adams

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: there was a considerable amount of noise in this chamber when the honourable member was making her point.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Tuckey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a moment. I am on my feet. I will speak and I will make my point of order. You just sit there and be quiet—right?
—Order! Address your point. You will join your companion in a moment.

—Mr Speaker, in deference to you, there are a considerable number of members from that side of the House interjecting. They are not in their right seats, but they have been interjecting. You have just removed one of our side of the House. I would ask you to point out to that side of the House the forums and the workings of the House.
—I thank the member for his contribution. I am very much aware of the growing disorder in the House and I will act accordingly to maintain order.
—I met with the whole of the national board of Aged Care Australia on 16 May. This their summary, their own notes, of that meeting:

SPEECH.PARA: The restructure of residential aged care was discussed in detail. While maintaining the momentum of change is important, John Ireland advised the minister that ACA called for a delay of implementation until 1 October.
And we have signalled that. So Labor's real agenda is to delay and to delay and to go on with this absolute humbug. This government has consulted. It is urgent that we get this bill through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Reith's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —I declare that the following bills are urgent bills:

SPEECH.PARA: Aged Care Bill 1997
Aged Care (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997
Aged Care (Compensation Amendments) Bill 1997

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the bills be considered urgent bills.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the time allotted in connection with the bills be as follows:
Aged Care Bill 1997:
(a) For the second reading, until 12.00 noon this day.
(b) For the committee stage, until 4.30 p.m. this day.
(c) For the remaining stages, until 4.40 p.m. this day.
Aged Care (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997:
For the remaining stages, until 5.00 p.m. this day.
Aged Care (Compensation Amendments) Bill 1997:
For the remaining stages, until 5.20 p.m. this day.

This is the Labor Party at its very worst, full of rhetoric and no substance: rhetoric about their commitment to aged care, a commitment that they did not demonstrate in real terms over 13 years of government. They allowed the nursing home sector to fall into a parlous state and failed to address the urgent needs of the most frail aged people in our community. They have no commitment and they have demonstrated that lack of commitment. Many of their speakers have come in here to debate this bill without any commitment to the real substance of the bill and it has been evident in some of the speeches that they have not even bothered to read the bill itself. Clearly they have it wrong.

It is very important that we do examine the issues and have a wide‐ranging debate on this issue of importance and substance. What we need is genuine debate on the substance of the bill. We do not need the shadow minister for scare constantly scaremongering and misrepresenting the content of the bill and the substance of the reforms that we are to put into place. Their commitment to genuine debate is appallingly not there. It is just not there.

This government cannot afford to accommodate such delaying and disruptive tactics. The Senate's timetable, we know, is tight and it is important to the most frail citizens in our community that we get on and actually address the failings of 13 years of Labor's mismanagement and neglect in the aged care system. They are living in the past, they talk about all the things they did do—and they did do some things—but they started their reform process 10 years ago and then it totally stalled. This is while the shadow minister was in fact advising the then government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The minister knows that is incorrect and she should correct the record.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—It was a do‐nothing government and they are now a do‐nothing opposition. They are a do‐nothing opposition and this is a do‐nothing‐but‐scare shadow minister. She did nothing to help their party when they were in government and she is doing nothing to assist them now that they are on the opposition benches. We have not heard one solitary constructive comment. This is about the worst aspects of Labor and about playing politics. It is not about fixing up the problems confronting the most frail and vulnerable citizens in our community. They deserve better than they have been given in the last decade or so under Labor.

BREAK.PARA: This government wants to be allowed to get on with that job and to ensure the urgent passage of this bill in the interests of those in our community who are frail and who are vulnerable so that they have comfortable, decent accommodation where they can live with dignity, where they can have the care that they deserve, where they are not living in wards where there are four or more people in them, where the buildings are not a fire hazard and where the buildings do meet basic safety policy.

This is not about debating the substance of the bill. The Labor Party are about scare tactics and delay. As I said, this is an opposition who did nothing when they were in government and they are doing absolutely nothing to add to the substance of debate now that they are in opposition. They will stand condemned by the Australian public for the scare tactics that they have mounted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Every single aged care organisation in this country wants the Aged Care Bill delayed and the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) knows it. Every single body faxed the minister yesterday. What does Aged Care Australia, which represents all the non‐profit nursing homes in this country, say? They say:

SPEECH.PARA: Aged Care Australia cannot support the passage of the Aged Care Bill today. We urge you to require full disclosure of critical information and additional funding.

What does the Alzheimers Association want? They are urging you to delay the bill. The Australian Catholic Health Care Association calls the bill `discriminatory and ill prepared'. As it stands, it cannot be supported by the Australian Catholic Health Care Association or by the federal parliament. That is the view of an organisation that represents so many nursing homes around this country. They want this bill delayed; they do not want this bill debated in this parliament.

The Uniting Church, represented by Community Services Australia, says that the government's offer of $5 a day is an insult to the elderly and a slap in the face for charitable service providers. That is what this minister is doing. She is slapping the faces of charitable service providers. This minister treats this nursing home industry with abso lute contempt. All of these organisations are calling for this minister to delay this debate. All of them know they have not sufficient information to have any idea what is going to happen in nursing homes in Australia.

What Community Services Australia, what the Uniting Church homes, are saying is that you have slapped them in the face. Over Fifties Focus are saying that this bill must be delayed. They state in their press release, `The Aged Care Bill to be debated in parliament tomorrow should be immediately withdrawn.' They go even further and say that it should be immediately withdrawn. What should happen, of course, is that it should be withdrawn and we should not be debating it in this place.

What do the private nursing homes say? The minister does not have the support of the private nursing homes either. What they are saying is that two‐tiered aged care seems inevitable. Even the private sector, Minister, is saying two‐tiered aged care is inevitable. Because of your miserly $5 a day they know that they are going to be providing second‐rate care for those who cannot afford to pay your disgusting accommodation bonds. That is what they say.

What do the Anglicans say? Anglican agencies say that the standard of care for the aged is at risk—because of this minister's disgusting policies, because all of these agencies know that they will not have the money to care for people who are poor. They will not have the money to look after people.

Let us look at another press release, Minister. I am sure you have seen all of them and you have ignored every single one of them. You have ignored the call from every agency in this country. `Aged care subsidy a poisoned chalice'. You can insult me as much as you like. It does not matter because you are the minister and you are the one who is giving this aged care industry the poisoned chalice—not me. You are not giving them anything like Labor gave them. You are not putting a billion dollars into capital; you are putting in absolutely nothing and giving them a poisoned chalice.

Finally, today we have a press release from the nurses who care for the elderly people in this country. What do they say? They say that this Aged Care Bill takes nurses out of nursing homes. That is what is going to happen as a result of this nursing home bill. It is going to mean that agencies working for the poor are going to be discriminating against the poor. This bill must be delayed and taken out of the parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 June, on motion by Mrs Moylan:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am deeply concerned by the disastrous consequences of the Aged Care Bill, which is before the House. I am deeply concerned for the people I represent, particularly the elderly people who face great uncertainty as a result of this legislation. I am deeply concerned for elderly people with special needs. I am deeply concerned for elderly people who have no savings. This bill provides a clear example of the vast difference in ideology which underpins the Liberal and Labor parties. The Liberal Party believes that the individual should be allowed to look after themselves and that market forces will sort it out. We believe the government has a responsibility to look after people.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately for the people of Australia, the Aged Care Bill was drafted on these laissez faire principles. Up to now, the aged care industry has not been a big money‐spinner, and in the main nursing homes have been run on a modest profit margin or not for profit. But all this is about to change.

BREAK.PARA: When people require nursing care, they and their families are often in a state of great emotional upheaval. Time is usually something they do not have. They are in a weak bargaining position. But this bill would have them in a situation reminiscent of the government's individual workplace contracts. The elderly people will have to negotiate with nursing home owners. Mr Howard's advice to younger and more vulnerable employees was that they could always take their mums along with them to negotiate an individual work contract. Elderly Australians wanting to go into nursing homes cannot use this advice.

People who up to this point have been independent must adjust to their loss of independence and privacy when they enter nursing homes. The reality for most people is that, once they enter a nursing home, they are unlikely to return to their own home. However, for many people the fact that their home is still there to return to gives them some hope. If they have to sell their home, as they will under this bill, I really fear for their longevity. Selling the family's home is a final act. The government may as well be putting the nails in the coffins of elderly Australians because that is exactly what this bill will do.

The Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) again has been quite enthusiastic today to talk about the shadow minister and her past career and activities. Perhaps we need to take a look at the minister's past. As I recall, in her life before she entered parliament the minister was a real estate agent. I stress that what I am about to say is in no way intended to reflect upon the minister's propriety or the standard of her behaviour on the bill. I merely point out to the minister that, if she lives in a house of glass, she should not throw rocks at the shadow minister.

I am sure that, as a former real estate agent, the minister has lots of mates who are still real estate agents. They are the big winners from this bill as elderly Australians are forced to sell their homes, a situation over which they have no power and are not in a position to act in a manner which is appropriate. As people are forced to sell their homes to get nursing home care, there will be more house sales and more commission for the minister's mates.

I know that it was not the minister's intention to enrich real estate agents with this legislation, but she should be fully aware of what more scurrilous types will be up to in exploiting elderly Australians. The minister should also avoid trying to pretend that people will not have to sell their houses to get into a nursing home as a result of this bill.

There is an old saying—and I might distort Shakespeare a little bit by saying it—`Methinks that the minister protesteth too much.' If the representatives of older Australians, pensioners, providers of aged care, the churches and even private nursing homes are against this legislation, you might ask, `Who is in favour of it, and why is the government crunching it through this morning and restricting debate?'

It seems quite reasonable to have a system of aged care where every older Australian was guaranteed a nursing home bed if they became too frail to care for themselves and their families could no longer cope. Now if you are in this situation, all you have to do is sell your home, pay the bulk of the proceeds over to a nursing home and pay an extra daily fee of $63.30 a day for the first two months, and maybe indefinitely, and then and only then can you have a bed. This is the sort of reform which makes a farce of the government's position.

Seriously, is there anyone in favour? As it turns out, I found one group that is in favour of this proposal: Doug Moran, owner of the Moran Health Care Group, which is Australia's biggest operator of nursing homes. Dougie also happens to be listed in the BRW top 200 wealthy Australians. In fact, Dougie has risen to No. 40 on the list and is worth $250 million—a quarter of a billion dollars. How did Doug make this quarter of a billion dollars? He made it by charging people for health care.

I have nothing against people making a quid. But, when you are talking about someone with this level of money and when you are talking about someone who has already exerted substantial influence on this government's policy being able to charge people the value of their homes less $22,500 to get into homes, I think there is a prospect that Doug Moran will be rising up that list with a bullet in future years.

Doug's main operations are in Sydney, and we all know the value of Sydney properties, even pensioners' cottages, but Doug has now moved into Melbourne. According to BRW, his `public advocacy of the positives of private health has not harmed his cause with the Kennett government in Victoria'. And we all know how Jeffrey likes to help a mate.

It is rumoured that Doug was none too impressed by this government's sensible decision to delay implementation of the bill. In fact, the same rumour has it that he was on the phone to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) letting him know just how much that delay would affect his cashflow. Do not get me wrong, I am not saying that Doug has exercised overly undue influence. He said it himself. The disturbing thing is that Doug Moran claims to be the architect of the bill and the adviser to the government on aged care policy. Talk about the letting the fox guard the chickens!

Evidence was given to the Senate Community Affairs References Committee's inquiry into aged care by Reverend Harry Herbert, who is the Chair of Community Services Australia, the national Uniting Church community service organisation. Reverend Herbert said:

In a recent 7.30 Report interview in which I participated, a private operator, Mr Doug Moran, after having boasted that he was the government's main adviser in this area, was then asked what he thought about the creation of a two‐tier system. He stated, `Indeed, this will be the case; it will be a two‐tier system.' He stated further, `This is normal because people in the eastern suburbs drive cars worth three times as much as the cars of people in western Sydney.'
This is all rather blatant and shocking. I am a bit amazed that Doug Moran can be so brazen, but when you are No. 40 in the top 200 I guess you can put your position quite forcefully.

Doug certainly has taken his bits of the Liberal Party. We would all remember that he warehoused Bob Woods in between being the member for Lowe and being a senator. Appar ently, now he also has former leader Dr John Hewson on the payroll, working as a consultant, particularly in relation to the Victorian government.
Yesterday, the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) made a very positive reference in parliament to Doug Moran and the Moran Group. The member for Lindsay said:

Groups like the Moran Group are gearing up to take advantage of what can be done in the industry and to start providing some competition, some choice, some diversity and some varied standards of accommodation to meet the increasingly particular needs of the generation of the baby boomers, who tend to be more demanding in terms of services offered and accommodation type.

The member for Lindsay has clearly hitched her wagon to the Moran Group, as have Dr Woods and Dr Hewson. The Moran Group, it can be seen, do not just run private nursing homes; they also run a retirement home for failed Liberal politicians. Perhaps the member for Lindsay is taking out a bit of insurance in case she loses her seat, as I am sure will occur after the next election. Then we can have a troika: Woods, Hewson and Kelly all on the payroll.

I would like to refer to what the future brings. This bill really is back to the future in its setting back of aged care. In 1984, the then government brought down a report on private nursing homes in Australia, the Giles report. That report outlined a series of horrific activities run by private health care, activities such as patients being showered at 4 a.m. to 6 a.m. to reduce the strain on daytime staff, patients left shivering naked outside showers waiting for nursing staff to return with towels and patients left for long periods of time in wet or soiled linen. There was a terminally ill patient who suffered a broken humerus when untrained nurse assistants threw him onto a bed. A patient had been tied in a chair and not showered as punishment after she had defecated on the floor.

This is the reality of the system this government would introduce. The sorts of photos produced in the Giles report really go to the sort of future we would see if this legislation is allowed to pass. I urge all members to reject this bill. I condemn the government for pushing it through without proper debate and without the proper processes being in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent, Russell, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the saddest days that I have experienced in the time that I have been in this House, and the reason is that the words that have gone across the table between the government and the opposition today do not edify parliamentarians. The smiles for the aggressive performance of the shadow minister, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), that I have seen on those on the other side of the House have been saddening to say the least. We have just seen the disgraceful performance of the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) as he held up a report into the system of the former Labor government with his exhortation about the problems that elderly people had under the scheme of the government that he was formerly working for.
—On a point of order: the report was into your government, the mess that you left our government when it came into parliament. It is your mess which we had to fix up.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—It shows that the member for Grayndler is concerned about his performance in this, the politicisation of the care for our aged community. I come into this House on behalf of people such as the aged community in the electorate of McMillan. I am seriously concerned that because of this debate many people not only in McMillan but across Australia will be unduly concerned. It is not fair and it is not right at any time to take those least able to protect themselves and use them as political footballs, as has happened in this House today. It has been happening throughout this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It saddens me to see the shadow minister, Ms Macklin, using this as a stepping stone for her own political career. It saddens me because I know that she has a history of service in not only the care of the aged but community services as a whole. She knows of the parts that she did not read out that were in the aged care proposals that were faxed to her yester day from Aged Care Australia, particularly from the executive officer who, as we know, is one of the failed health ministers of the Cain‐Kirner years.

Maureen Lister is somebody I know well. I have known Maureen for a long time and I know in this particular instance she is justifying herself, like many lobbyists do on behalf of their organisations. This is her chance and her only chance to put herself on the map, when she could not put herself on the map as a health minister.

Why am I saddened? I am particularly grieved and angry at Aged Care Australia, for instance, which does represent most organisations. Today I have actually heard my own church—the Anglican Church—bandied around this place as one of those in opposition to this health care reform bill. I wonder whether the leaders of the Anglican Church know they are being used in such a way in this debate today.

What did Aged Care Australia actually say? They said, `Aged Care Australia have supported the general direction of changes.' That is what they said: `We have supported the general direction of these changes.' In fact, the whole industry, all of those people, support the general direction the government is taking. All they are dilly‐dallying about is some of the finer details.

All the speakers in this debate have gone through those finer details, and they have been answered by the Minister for Family Services, Mrs Moylan. I have to say that Minister Moylan has given information on a grand scale to everybody who has asked for it. We have Aged Care Australia saying, `We actually support these changes,' yet they have come along and they sent faxes out yesterday saying, `But there are parts of it we don't support.'

Why is this one of the worst days I have had? Back in the late 1960s, I was coopted on to a committee to raise funds for a local nursing home. In around 1969 I was first confronted with those people in our community—outside my own family—who were particularly aged and in need of care, those people who did not actually have the money to look after themselves when they were aged. Communities right across Australia recognised that. We need to come into this parliament and think about who we are here for—the very young, the very old, the vulnerable. We have put this aged care package together on behalf of those people.

I have been saddened by the front pages I have seen in my own local newspapers where decent people have been rolled out in wheelchairs and photographed for the front pages. Aged Care Australia have put out a general kit for communities to use with their local newspapers. They have taken a photograph of some vulnerable, elderly person, whacked it on the front page of a newspaper and said, `Here we are. We're opposed to what you're doing on aged care because it may upset our pyramid of what we are doing locally.'

This package of bills is about looking after older Australians. This is about addressing the issues of concern to all people, to every family. If you are like me and you have been through it with your own father, you know that we have to put extra effort and extra care into an ageing population.

We cannot as a government walk away from these reforms. These are the things the former Keating and Hawke governments wanted to do but never implemented. These are the changes that need to be made on behalf of the frail, aged Australians so everybody gets a fair go, so there is some equity in the system and so everybody gets fair access.

I know that in my electorate these changes will benefit all in the long term. Yes, there are some areas that need to be monitored, and the minister has said, `The areas you're concerned about we are prepared to monitor. We're prepared to relook at them. We're prepared to see how the accommodation bond progresses.'

The other day I was with a group of ethnic elderly in my community, and it was really worth meeting with them. Do you know what they were mainly concerned about? They were mainly concerned about this issue, because they had just been told a whole string of mistruths about what the government was doing in aged care.

BREAK.PARA: What we have said is, `We're trying to introduce here the same system—a similar system—that has been in place for hostels into nursing homes.' To do that and to match them, there are some difficulties because we have a system currently that needs to be changed. Any time you introduce reform and there is a political process to be carried out in this country—which, I remind you again, is what I am seriously disappointed about today on this issue, and I do not think I will forget it for a long, long time—there is always people who are concerned about the process. I think I understand that better than most. But we have to work on behalf of the people whom we serve, on behalf of the clients in the nursing homes and on behalf of all of those people who work within them.

I congratulate all those workers within my electorate. I have the best people working at an administrative level and at a committee level and the best people doing the direct caring for those people who are older and frail and for those who have dementia. We have more people with dementia in our system now than we have previously had. The ageing population is causing the need to address that issue. These bills do that.

We have worked gradually through this. We have given extra time. We have grandfathered those areas that need to be grandfathered and we have explained that. Where there needs to be slow adjustment and slow change, we are quite prepared to do that on variable fees. Where did that come from? That came from Aged Care Australia. They said, `We're happy with most of the changes, but we would like you to grandfather variable fees.' So we did that. Throughout the whole of Australia, people have been given time to change. There are issues to work through, but I know that the community as a whole will back the changes that we are making.

The speakers in this debate have been right. When it comes to your family and you are looking for care for your elderly parents, you do not want to be travelling. It is difficult in the region where we are, especially in Gippsland—and a number of speakers who come from regions have mentioned this—to have your elderly parents split up or to be 100 miles away from care and attention.

In closing, when I hear words like `nails in coffins' on an issue like aged care, I say that we are not actually looking at and caring for those people who we are directly responsible for. This government and the opposition have a responsibility not to frighten elderly people but to send a message out into the Australian community that we are concerned and that these changes will be beneficial to them.

I am sending a message now to Maureen Lister. If she continues with this program—I will send this message to you, Maureen, because you know that I have worked with you for a long time on issues such as this—it will be a great sadness that elderly people are threatened for party political purposes. This is unfair. It is not right. It does not edify this parliament.

It is wrong for a failed health minister to be running the program and for the shadow minister to be the parrot for Maureen Lister on this issue. Aged care is very important to all Australians. With this bill we will make sure that older Australians are cared for, that they get equity, that they get opportunity and that they get the sort of care we would want our own parents to have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent weeks it has been interesting to note the rhetoric of those on the other side of the chamber. For example, they are concerned that Labor is repudiating its past by reconsideration of tariff policy in this country. Throughout this debate, there has been constant whingeing, complaining and allegations of scare campaigns.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite ironic when you look at the political history of this country—reds under the bed; hide your money under the bed; subliminal messages that the country is being overrun by people who do not speak English; and concerns put to the elderly that the country is changing too fast, that we are becoming too globalised, that our migration program is wrong and that appointing an Australian head of state is a frightening prospect—to hear allegations of scare campaigns in relation to this debate.

BREAK.PARA: In my own electorate it is fair to say that I very rarely receive correspondence about matters of national importance. There have been major debates in the New South Wales and federal parliaments on moral issues about which very few of my constituents corresponded with me. I cannot think of many issues which have caused a thousand voters to sign a petition, as in this case, against these changes.

The government is so constant in their criticism of the shadow minister because they know the arguments advanced are having an effect out there in middle Australia. When the shadow minister visited my electorate, we had probably the largest public meeting on any issue since the Vietnam War and conscription. The people who attended that meeting came away not scared or overwhelmed by terror but facing realities about where this government is going with regard to home care. As a result of that, a significant number of people signed this petition of their own initiative—not on street corners by the Labor Party or the unions or some pensioner group, but off their own bat from that meeting and from ringing up our office. That is why we have this constant bemoaning of the need for groups like the Anglican Church to take up this issue.

Typical of the way this issue is penetrating middle Australia is the Ukrainian community in my electorate. That is interesting because we all know that, until the last three or four years and the collapse of the Cold War, that community have been archetypal supporters of the current government. I had approaches from the Ukrainian Welfare Association and from individual Ukrainians in my electorate, a very significant electoral force. They want to be organised. They want to be involved. They are requesting it. They want to fight this campaign very strongly. That is the reality out there.

It is the reality of John Howard, as the Australian of 5 December 1996 said with a bold headline `Howard endorses plan for elderly to go into debt'. It was all right to hear the member for Lilley (Mrs Elizabeth Grace) talking a few nights ago about how the government's paltry savings proposal is something at last for those people who have saved and those people who have purchased a home. Well, she should use the same rhetoric with regard to this bill because, quite frankly, those people are under a major assault as a result of the changes the government is suggesting.

I will refer to two pieces of correspondence I received on this matter. Once again, I absolutely repudiate and reject the notion that everyone who opposes this government's policy—whether it be particular nursing homes, individuals, elderly people, veterans groups or, as in this case, the Bankstown Frail Aged Persons Home Trust—is a moron, does not understand what is going on, is manipulated or is stupid.

Quite frankly, this Bankstown Frail Aged Persons Home Trust, predominantly in the electorates of the member for Banks (Mr Melham) and the member for Blaxland (Mr Hatton), which I had dealings with as a former state member, are not stupid. They were one of the first councils in this country to establish their own network of elderly people's homes. They have been in the marketplace. They know the industry. They have been active for decades. These people, at the conclusion of a long letter which very strongly criticised the costing process and the assistance for those people that are basically concessionals, said:

. . . for any residents in excess of 20%, regardless of what socio‐economic area they came from the Government should pay the same rate per day the organisation would get if the person was a full accommodation bond paying resident. That is $19.18 per day. This would be equitable, it would not be discriminatory and would be uniform across all socio‐economic areas. An organisation would not be penalised because it is trying to provide care in a poorer area compared to another charity trying to provide the same accommodation to the same standard in a more wealthy area.

They are making a very fundamental point that in the area they represent they will be forced to basically go into bankruptcy, to go into a period of not being able to maintain their premises, because of the high number of concessional people they will take. I will read into the record what I regard as a fairly articulate explanation from one of my constituents about this matter. She states:
The government did not inform the public during their election campaign of their intention to foist this iniquitous impost on the people, and therefore they have no mandate to do so!

Any vague references they may have made to means tests were inadequately explained and lacking in detail. Indeed they actively sought to avoid giving the voters any specific details on most issues . . .
She goes on:

Much of the support that the coalition gained at the expense of the A.L.P. would certainly have come from elderly people who would become potential nursing home entrants in the relatively near future. Now the coalition is betraying those people in the most callous, cowardly and cynical manner possible.
Furthermore:

On behalf of all of Australia's frail and elderly battlers, I ask you Mr. Ferguson, to please spare no effort in having this iniquitous, cowardly and completely un-Australian attack on those least able to defend themselves overturned.

This letter was from Ruby Gibbons of Berala. I do not think, from the three‐page letter this woman has written me, which covers the issues very broadly and which asks me to fight the legislation very strongly, that she is under any misapprehension about the kinds of serious changes this is going to cause in our country.

There was a complaint from the previous speaker, the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Broadbent), about the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) quoting a survey of the inhumane treatment people receive in nursing homes in this country. As the member for Grayndler pointed out, it was clearly under the previous government. I want to refer to that. In one of the more impressive and more aggressive contributions from those opposite, the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus)—who should be in the place of the current minister but who unfortunately had the unpalatable task of trying to defend this government's previous Aboriginal policies in opposition—bemoaned the question of bureaucrats running around the place requiring standards. In a fairly longbow approach, she complained about people supposedly having to write down every five minutes how much they were scrubbing.

That is the thin edge of the wedge of the government's complaint essentially about the previous government. We have seen exposes in the Sydney Morning Herald of the kinds of conditions people live in and the chains that operate in this field which are basically out there for the big dollar. The previous government, quite clearly, quite strongly, intervened to make sure there were standards in this industry.

When those opposite complain about bureaucrats interfering too much in nursing homes, what they are essentially saying is that they do not want standards. They want them undermined. They do not want people like me, as a federal member, to be able to say to the local papers in my area that this nursing home met this standard and that one met that standard. They do not want that kind of thing. Despite all the rhetoric about how the nursing homes are a shambles and how maintenance has fallen, this policy is essentially driven by the private operators.

The three main issues to be covered are the introduction of entry charges to nursing homes, arrangements for concessional residents who cannot pay entry fees and the move to a uniform system of income related fees for both nursing homes and hostels. Until now, access to nursing homes has been based on assessed medical need, not on capacity to pay or entry contribution.

Under the bill, the government will force people who enter nursing homes after October to pay what they euphemistically call an accommodation bond. There is no upper limit proposed for the entry charge, provided that the resident is left with assets of at least $22,500. The industry claims the average entry fee could be $40,000 and over $100,000 in some cases. The value of the intending resident's home is taken into account in calculating this asset level, except where a partner or dependent child still lives there or a close relative or carer who has lived there for at least five years and is eligible for a social security pension or benefit still lives there.

Clearly, under these arrangements many senior citizens whose health is deteriorating, particularly those who are single or widowed and who own their home, will be required to sell their home or take out a loan to raise the coalition's nursing home entry fee. Their assets, chiefly their home, will be considered too high for them to get an exemption from the entry fee. This category would doubtless include a considerable number of war widows because DVA data shows that, out of the 97,000 war widow pensioners, some 78,000 or over 85 per cent are aged 70 years of age or older and are thus in the group most at risk of needing residential care.

More than 60 per cent of those entering nursing homes come straight from hospital after serious illness, such as a stroke, or suffering from dementia. It would be hard to imagine a more vulnerable starting point for bargaining about entry fees. In contrast, most people entering hostels have time to look for the hostel of their choice, taking into account the quality of facilities, entry charges, et cetera. The minister says that the so‐called accommodation bond:

. . . will operate as a capital deposit which the provider holds while the resident is in the facility. When they leave it is refunded, less a modest contribution of up to $2,600 indexed per year for up to five years.
This means that the nursing home owner will pocket $13,000 over five years plus any interest that accrues out of the entry fee.

Clearly, the intention of the entry fee is to shift the capital cost of upgrading aged care facilities from the government and operators to the frail aged and their families. Under the bill, the government will all but cease providing capital funding for residential care, saving for themselves $244 million for further headlines over four years. The government retains capital funding for a mere $10 million for special purposes mainly in rural and remote areas.

The bill's provisions are consistent with the ideological agenda of Treasurer Costello's National Commission of Audit, which is the coalition's social policy road map for the future. Based on DSS and Taxation Office data which suggests that just over 30 per cent of Australians over 60 have assets worth $50,000 or more, excluding the home equity, the commission—as I say, the guiding force, the ideological bent of the government—said:

. . . a high proportion of our retired population are in a position to meet at least a significant share of the costs of their own health and care needs. The Commission is not questioning the policy objective of providing nursing home assistance to those in need but is questioning whether the preservation of clients' wealth—
as we know in this case, not too much wealth—
at the expense of the rest of the community, should be part of that policy objective . . .

Whilst the government did not directly accept the commission's specific recommendation that it recover from estates the full cost of nursing home benefits provided to asset‐rich senior citizens, this bill seeks to achieve much the same outcome via a different method.
As confirmation of this, I quote from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who said last December that it was:
. . . fair and reasonable to say to that person you should borrow some money against that [home] and, if it is not paid before you die, it will be paid out of your estate.

He said that on 5 December in the Australian . As shadow minister for veterans' affairs, I am particularly concerned at the likely impact of these measures on the ex‐service community. It should be remembered that some 85 per cent of those who are under the protection of the veterans' affairs portfolio fall into this age category. As the ageing process and the strains of their war service take their toll, a growing number face the need for residential care in the very near future and will be slugged by the coalition's nursing home entry charges.

In lieu of the entry fee, nursing home operators receive a mere $5 a day of extra government subsidy for concessional residents whom the government assesses as being unable to pay an entry fee. This means that the annual subsidy for concessional residents is $1,725 a year. By contrast, a nursing home can draw down $2,600 a year plus interest from a better off resident's entry fee. This will create an obvious incentive for operators to minimise the number of concessional residents in their facility and favour the wealthy.

The minister says that every nursing home will have to set aside 27 per cent of its places for concessional residents, who will not have to pay an entry fee. She claims that this will ensure that access is based on needs, not means. This claim is clearly untenable if, as predicted, concessional people represent more than 27 per cent of applicants for care. The nursing home industry has predicted that up to 55 per cent of applicants will be in the concessional category, more than twice the number of the reserved places they are proposing.

There must also be doubt about the minister's ability to guarantee observance of the 27 per cent quota, quite frankly. The outcome is likely to be a two-tier system where concessional nursing home places, on the one hand, will be in extremely short supply, but where the better off, on the other hand, can afford to be choosy. This offends against the basic principle that nursing homes should be part of society's health safety net, with admission rationed according to assessed medical need.

There is also the likelihood that older people with assets just above the cut-off point for the concessional resident definition will face particular dilemmas. They will have neither the guarantee of the reserved concessional places, no matter how inadequate these will be in number or quality, nor sufficient savings to pay the going rate in their area for the entry fee that the better off can afford.

This matter is of particular concern to the veteran community. Quite frankly, the minister concerned should be in there batting for the 85 per cent of affected veterans in this country. To my mind this portfolio is far more crucial than his new occupation as a film critic. It is far more crucial than press releases about everything under the sun, except the crucial social security problems that this community faces.

In conclusion, the member for Lilley said—admittedly in a different context, in defence of their savings policy—that many of these people have struggled and worked hard. Quite frankly, as this government well knows, if there is one issue that has them on the back foot, it is this. There is anger out in the Australian community. There is anger from middle Australia about the way in which they have been misled over these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marek, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to talk on an issue that is most important to my electorate and one which I feel very passionate about. The debate on the Aged Care Bill 1997 and two cognate bills provides me with an opportunity to make people aware of the burning need not only to address the administrative and operational structure within aged care but also discuss the present lack of government funded beds and pass on to everyone what I am doing to address this very problem in Capricornia.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, let us look into the operational side of the debate which this legislation effectively works to put right. This legislation will bring about significant structural reform to the way aged care works and make it more viable and sustainable. It will ensure fairer access to higher quality standards of care and accommodation. I also strives to address the problem of trauma which is caused by relocation to alternative facilities to get appropriate care.

This legislation introduces strong protections for consumers and creates incentives for providers to invest in maintenance and improvements to buildings. It means that people who can afford to pay more towards the cost of their care and accommodation will do so, at the same time securing equal rights of entry to residential aged care for those who cannot afford to pay.

When you look at that previous statement and compare it with what the opposition is rumbling on about, it makes you ask a question about commonsense. Sometimes you must wonder whether commonsense is really common. I say this with regard to the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), the shadow minister for social security, the aged and family services, whose argument is that she wants to put all the money into the pockets of future beneficiaries and to place all the burden of aged care on to the taxpayers of Australia.

I do not have a problem with people handing on family wealth, but let us be frank: the people in my electorate tell me that they do not begrudge anyone a fair go; in fact, many people say that we should put more money aside to help the elderly, like increasing the Medicare levy, and that money be focused directly to aged care. The reason for this is that the elderly have worked hard in the past for the betterment of this country and they should be able to spend the latter years of their lives without stress and in a serene environment. But someone requiring nursing home care or the like who has sufficient wealth should pay and contribute to their care. It is as simple as that.

The Labor Party argues, with the socialist welfare mentality, that the government pays for everything, thus driving the country into severe debt, like we were in after 13 years of the past Labor government. Do not forget the Australian Labor Party government's welfare mentality of spending the government's funds. But I say that it is not the government's money; it belongs to the taxpayers of Australia and this spendthrift mentality of the ALP is what lost them government in March 1996.

Moving on, I now have the pleasure of putting a Labor Party lie to bed. It is in relation to the grubby picture that the Labor Party is painting in Rockhampton about the number of beds being funded at the Eventide Nursing Home facility. It was of interest to see that Gareth Evans, the member for Holt, took time in the past week to visit Rockhampton in my electorate of Capricornia—nice of you to look me up. While in Rockhampton, Mr Evans visited Eventide Nursing Home. How appropriate that he should see first‐hand the problems that are being experienced at Eventide with reduced bed numbers. This is a sad case of affairs.

Some might ask why we have reduced bed numbers at Eventide Nursing Home in Rockhampton. Mr Robert Swarten, the Labor Party state member for Rockhampton, the then state Minister for Health, Mr Beattie, and Carmen Lawrence, the member for Fremantle and the then minister for health, know why. In fact, Mr Swarten and Mr Evans appear to have been telling a few pork pies here.

Now back to Gareth Evans, the federal member for Holt. I hate to be the giver of bad news, my friend, but it would appear that your state colleague has dropped you right in it, old chap. We do not have to wait for the answers with regard to the reduced bed numbers at Eventide; I have the answer right here. The previous Labor government signed off to reduce bed numbers. Yes, that is right—cuts. The Australian Labor Party cut the funding to the Queensland public nursing home beds, in particular, Eventide Nursing Home at Rockhampton, while they were in government in October 1995.

The Queensland state Goss government notified the member for Fremantle, Carmen Lawrence, in November 1995 that they would accept the federal plan. In January 1996 the program started. What is more, under the plan the numbers would be cut to 60 rather than 80 at Eventide. It was interesting that Mr Robert Swarten dropped this in the media the other day. You can see why he knew all about it—because he was involved in it. Thankfully for a coalition state government in Queensland, they have funded the additional 20 beds to ensure that the facility will have 80 beds at Eventide in Rockhampton.

Mr Gareth Evans has had the audacity to say in Capricornia media that the reduction in beds from 129 to 80 is a matter which should be taken up with Mr Paul Marek, the federal member for Capricornia. Mr Evans, you are a hypocrite. How does it feel to be a member of a party that sets you up and is responsible for putting so many elderly electors in the community out of nursing home beds? So much for Labor government nursing home reforms! It makes you wonder where they are going to stop. It was the Labor government's so-called nursing home reform funding cuts which caused the lack of nursing home bed numbers in my electorate.

In closing on this grubby affair and putting to bed once and for all the issue of bed numbers at Eventide and who cut them, I say to the people of Rockhampton and Capricornia: I condemn the Labor Party for their gross continuation of innuendo and lies. The Labor Party should remember this issue at the next election. I know the people who need beds in Capricornia will.

The Labor Party has no clothes and cannot be trusted. It is funny that the Australian Labor Party here are trying to cast off the perception of old Labor and they want to be known as new Labor. The problem here is that you cannot change your name and expect the public to change their perception of you, because you are all just a bunch of hangers‐on from a failed, distrusted, conceited Keating Labor government. The future of Labor members will be judged at the next election, and their actions and statements should be treated with the contempt they deserve.

On a more positive note, I am happy to be part of a government which has devised reforms which will do what Mr Gareth Evans, Dr Lawrence and their Labor colleagues have failed to do: increase bed numbers and provide quality facilities to our aged. Nursing homes, hostels, carers et cetera are sick and tired of being pushed from pillar to post in trying to get government assistance to meet the demand being placed upon them for additional bed places, care packages et cetera.

From day one as the federal member for Capricornia, I have received submission after submission from nursing homes and hostels seeking funding for more bed places. Bureaucrats say we are over the benchmark. If that is the case, why do nursing homes and hostels continually ask to have the problem with placement fixed and why are waiting lists so long?

It was time to find out for myself, so I commissioned a study within the electorate of Capricornia in response to aged care related concerns expressed by constituents. The survey is being undertaken at this very moment by Mrs Ashley Reid. She comes very highly recommended from all sectors of nursing and aged care, and brings with her a wealth of knowledge and expertise in the field.

The study will be conducted without prejudice and in a competent and professional manner, ensuring fairness and equity for all. Even though the study is in its infancy, it has identified many things so far, including the concerns of non-government nursing home/hostel administrators with regard to the speed of the introduction—on 1 July—of the Aged Care Bill 1997. Once again, this government has listened to the people of Australia, and the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) has announced that the implementation of the entire aged care reform package will commence on 1 October 1997. What more can people ask for than a government that is listening to the people of Australia?

I believe this government has—unlike the previous government, which sat on their hands and watched the standard of nursing homes decline—introduced reforms which will provide certainty and flexibility for our aged. I welcome these changes, and I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Marek), referred to the Aged Care Bill as the aged care reform package. SPEECH.PARA: This bill unfortunately shows that the government does not understand what is happening in this area of aged care. The government is mixing apples with oranges. The only way people can get into a nursing home now is if they are put there by a doctor or an assessment team. A lot of people make lifestyle changes during their life. People might sell their family home when they are in their 50s or early 60s, when their children have grown up, to go into a townhouse. Some time later on, perhaps in their late 60s or early 70s, they might sell their townhouse to go into a retirement village or a hostel. These are lifestyle changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Minister, please do not leave the chamber.

This bill is not an attack on the rich. If it were an attack on only the rich, the opposition would be supporting it. But this bill is an attack on the poor.

The government will not admit that this bill imposes an effective 91 per cent tax rate on part pensioners. If you impose a 91 per cent effective tax rate on part pensioners, how can that be an attack on the rich? There are not too many part pensioners that I know who are rich. Certainly in my electorate of Watson, which has a lot of nursing homes in it, the people who are in those nursing homes are invariably poor.

This bill, in relation to the people of my electorate who unfortunately have reached a stage in their life and health that they have to go into a nursing home, will result in such people having to sell their house to gain entry.
