Where does a pensioner who lives in a small semi-detached house in my electorate, after working most of their life on the council or in a shop, get $88,000 from, apart from selling their house, to go into a nursing home if they have got sick?

The government is trying to attack these people during probably the most traumatic time in their lives. As I said, 60 per cent of people who go into nursing homes go there straight from hospital. Under the regime that we ran, if a person went from hospital into a nursing home or they were admitted into a nursing home by their doctor and the assessment team, for the purpose of the assets test, the house that they owned was not considered as an asset for a couple of years. So people could go into a nursing home and still have the hope that ultimately they would get better and be able to return to their home. At that very traumatic time in their life when either they are going from hospital into a nursing home or their doctor has told them they cannot cope anymore at home with their family or relations, the government is now saying to them, `And, at the same time, you've got to sell your house to get the $88,000 to get in.'

We hear a lot of trite discussion by the government about the people of Australia and how much they mean to it. But let us look at who these people are that the government is attacking in this bill. This is a generation of Australians who have made this country what it is. This generation of Australians, who are in their 70s and 80s and are now going into nursing homes, went through the Depression, went through the Second World War, went through the hard times after the war and made this country what it is today.

What does this government say to them? It says, `When you get old, and when you get sick when you get old and you are so sick that you need to go into a nursing home, we're going to make your life even more difficult. We're going to make you decide whether you're going to sell your house.' Imagine the situation where some poor old lady or poor old man in their 80s has just come out of the hospital after having had a heart attack or something and is put into a nursing home, and then the real estate agent comes around—the profession that the current minister worked for before she got into this parliament. All the real estate agents will be very happy about this new policy; they will love this. When these old people are ill and have just been put into a nursing home, the real estate agent will come around and say, `Have I got a deal for you to sell your house.'

How can people at that time in their lives make a decision about selling the asset they have spent their lives accumulating? If this bill attacked only the rich, it would not be a problem. The rich old person does not worry about this; they just gasp out, `See the accountant, see the lawyer,' because they have a phalanx of them there. But the fanciful idea of the poor people in my electorate who have to go into a nursing home having to deal with this sort of thing at that age and stage of their lives is appalling.

I cannot understand how a government that says that it has any thought for these people wants to do this. Kind and decent people, like the Benevolent Society and a very large charity in my electorate called Saint Basil's Homes, which is a very large group charity, write to me and tell me that this bill is terrible. Saint Basil's Homes wrote to me and said, `We consider the following issues about this bill to be of the greatest concern.' They say there is an unrealistic time line to implement reforms effectively by 1 July, given the lack of current detail in the bill. They say there is incompatibility between the Commonwealth legislation and state and territory legislation and that there are risks of further inefficiencies and duplication of monitoring.

They say that the prudential arrangements worry them, that it is vital for the credibility of the new system, and they have not yet been finalised. They say there is a lack of detail about funding levels and that this poses the dilemma for adequate financial planning in preparation for the new financial year together with the uncertainty over whether the new levels will be adequate to meet the care needs of residents. Saint Basil's Homes are also concerned about the inadequate indexation and growth of funding levels. They are also concerned about the lack of clarity and unnecessary complexity in the Aged Care Bill. They are also concerned about the lack of provisions for any external complaints handling process. So you will put these people in there now and they will not have any chance to complain. They are also most concerned about the confusion and rhetoric applying to the policy objective of `ageing in place', which is the government's sham proposal in this.

The minister has been talking about this bill for a long time. The minister has hidden this bill from the parliament for a long time. When we finally got the chance to debate this bill today and yesterday, what did the government do this morning? It came in and reduced the amount of time we can have to discuss it. When my colleague the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) was outraged by this, the Speaker threw her out. That is the government's answer to this terrible problem for older people in our community and in my electorate.

If I had 20 minutes, rather than the 10 minutes I have got to discuss this bill, I would bring before the House a number of other things which people in and who run nursing homes in my electorate, like Saint Basil's Homes, are terribly concerned about. If the government really thought anything of the generation of Australians who dragged this country through the Depression, who went to war and lost many of their loved ones and who are now in their 70s and 80s, it would never bring in disgraceful legislation such as this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The major fault of this legislation is the manner in which it fails to protect elderly Australians from having to sell their homes should they require nursing home care. The longer the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) has refused to admit what is plainly obvious to everyone else, the longer she has remained silent on the ramifications of nursing home entry fees, the more the clamour of concern has grown within our communities.

SPEECH.PARA: It is really quite simple, and I understand the reticence of the minister and of the members opposite to face up to these facts because we all know they are really quite shameful. It all comes down to one question: where does it say in the Aged Care Bill 1997 that all people will be exempt from having to sell their home to gain a bed in a nursing home? The answer is quite simply, `Nowhere,' and I have read the bill cover to cover. The only exemption offered is for persons entering a nursing home when that person shares their house with a spouse or a family member who is on a carer's pension—that's it, close the book. That is the limit of this government's generosity.

What the legislation does say—and it is there in black and white for the members opposite to read—is that a person with assets of over $22,500 will have to pay to get a nursing home bed. For those people not covered by the exemption, their home is included in that assets test. Forget the fact that you may be a Second World War veteran who shares his home with his son, and I know such a gentleman in my electorate—he contacted my electoral office last week. They are not exempt. Forget the fact that you may share your family home with your elderly sibling, and I have several people in my electorate, who have been to my electoral office, who do. They are not exempt.

For the majority of these people, the only reason they enjoy assets of over $22,500 is because they own a home. It does not take Einstein to realise that, in order to pay the fees demanded of them, many old people will now have to sell their house in order to get their nursing home bed.

The minister and members on the opposite side continue to play with semantics. They keep saying, `Show us in the bill where it says people will have to sell their homes,' and yet all the time they know that this bill cynically manoeuvres many people into doing nothing less if they want to get a nursing home bed. A document from the minister's department states:

The capacity of long‐stay residents to pay an entry contribution will depend upon the size of their asset holdings. In particular, the people who are most likely to be capable of paying an entry contribution are those who either own a saleable house or have other assets above about $60,000. About 63 per cent of residents could have a saleable home.

So much for the minister's `absolute guarantee' of saving people from selling their homes. For an elderly person living in their own home, especially one facing the uncertainty of life in a nursing home, that person's home is the very essence of comfort and security. Norah McGuire, the National Treas urer of the Australian Pensioners' and Superannuant's Federation, said on this very subject:
No‐one wants to go in—
that is, into a nursing home—

but some feel that as long as they have got that house out there, when or if they leave, then they can keep going. They really do know that they are not going to leave, but it is a part of trying to keep going.
Mrs McGuire also said that her organisation is receiving regular calls from members of Australia's aged community who are even contemplating suicide rather than giving up their own homes.

Yet we have a minister who wants to rob the elderly of Australia of this very sliver of hope in their latter years of life. This is a minister who does not believe that the sick and the frail elderly of Australia deserve to hold on to that last ray of hope connected to their house as they enter a nursing home. But the problem runs deeper than that. It is not just the emotional torment this legislation will put our elderly through; it is to do with the two‐tiered aged care system which will develop should we allow this legislation to pass.

Let us all understand that the legislation places no cap on the size of the entry fee which is to be paid. There is no mechanism in this legislation which stops nursing home operators from charging like wounded bulls should they consider that they can get away with it. All the operator has to do is leave the patient with $22,500. If a person's home is worth $122,500, the nursing home, under this legislation, can charge $100,000 for a bed and simply leave the client with the remainder. Indeed, the most recent industry estimates have put the average expected fee at $88,000, with luxury nursing homes charging as much as $150,000.

Here we have the seeds of a two‐tier system. It is pretty obvious that an elderly person with a more expensive house to sell immediately becomes a more attractive prospect to a nursing home operator than a person with a less expensive home or a person with no home to sell at all. Such a situation will be compounded by the government's plans to provide a measly $5 subsidy for concessional nursing home residents. If a nursing home operator has to choose between a financially disadvantaged person with no house or assets who attracts that measly $5 a day subsidy and an individual with a three‐bedroom house to sell, who will they choose? Who do you think?

The derisory $5 subsidy for concessional nursing home residents signals a new low in this government's treatment of our elderly and our disadvantaged. It means, for example, that church based care facilities—the section of the nursing home industry which caters for the majority of concessional residents in Australia—will not receive the benefits afforded to private nursing homes simply because of the financial status of their residents. Churches and charities are currently running approximately 70 per cent of Australia's nursing homes. These are homes which reserve at least 55 per cent of their places for financially disadvantaged people. Obviously we are talking about developing a system with a considerable number of have nots as opposed to haves.

So say the rest of the nursing home care industry, so says Aged Care Australia and so says Graeme Croft, Federal President of the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association. The Reverend Harry Herbert, National Chairperson of the Uniting Church's Community Services Australia, stated:
The Government's offer of $5 a day is an insult . . . and would in fact exacerbate the two‐tiered system of residential care.

These people are not mouthpieces for the Labor Party. They bear no longstanding animosity towards the minister or the coalition government. These people are nursing home professionals. These people run the organisations which care for the sick and the elderly in our society on a daily basis.

A two‐tiered system of nursing home care is about to become an awful reality in Australia if these changes take place. What can we expect from such a system? Those who can afford it, of course, will get the best. And for those who cannot, what are they going to end up with? I remember the old Lidcombe men's home, with 50 men to a ward, where my grandfather went in the 1950s because he required nursing. I can see the residents again now in this bill, lined up against the wall—bed, chest of drawers, bed, chest of drawers, bed, chest of drawers. Is that the sort of system that the disadvantaged in our community are going to be subjected to by this government? Is that the type of system that the church and charity organisations will be forced into delivering, starved of the funds they require for capital infrastructure?

What of the minister's tired argument about nursing homes being the same as aged hostels? It is an argument as spurious as it is offensive. It is quite clear that people choose to go into hostels—they do not choose to go into nursing homes. People go into nursing homes because they offer the care and medication their illness or frailty demands. People choose to go into hostels because they offer increased comfort and security—not because that person cannot function anymore.

What about the fact that we are considering this bill in the absence of any information on the prudential arrangements which guarantee the safety of residents' accommodation bonds? What about the fact that there is no requirement in this legislation for the interest that a nursing home earns from a resident's entry fee to be channelled back into that nursing home? For all this government cares, certainly by the look of this legislation, the interest may well straight back into beefing up the nursing home operator's profit margin.

The haphazard manner in which this bill was quite obviously put together speaks volumes for the minister's concern and for this government's concern for the elderly in our communities. I am amazed that we have a government that is willing to bring such a flawed piece of legislation into this House knowing full well its implications for the health and the wellbeing of thousands of sick and elderly Australians. What a reckless and arrogant attitude to adopt. This government is, I believe, using the Goebbels technique—the big lie becomes the truth. They are saying, `We'll ram this bill through because it's becoming increasingly embarrassing for us not to do so. Any problems we come across later we'll do something about then.'I fear for the people requiring nursing home care in this country if that is the attitude of the government they rely upon to govern the security and equity of their care.

After a lifetime of contributing to their communities and to our society, bringing up their children, working tirelessly in their jobs and in their homes and making countless numbers of sacrifices to make ends meet, few Australians deserve to live more comfortably and relaxed than our senior citizens. Thanks to this legislation, comfortable and relaxed they are not.

Strange as it may seem to the members opposite, running a government is not like running a business or a stockbroking firm or a lawyer's chambers or a cattle property. You must govern with an eye to maintaining the spirit and the hope of the people whom you are supposed to represent. You must govern with a generous heart and make sure that your greatest resource, the people of this country, do not become divided or suffer due to neglect.

The state of a person's bank balance should never dictate the state of the health care that they receive in this country and likewise the standard of nursing home care that is available to them. Nursing home care is merely an extension of our health care system. Access to nursing home care, as with the general medical system, should be based on need and not on a person's capacity to pay.

I too have a lot more to say. I find it offensive to have been gagged on a bill as important as this and, for the first time in my federal parliamentary career, to be removed from this House because I objected to the way the minister was arrogantly handling this bill. The people whom I represent find it offensive as well. I condemn this bill before the House.

They introduced accommodation bonds in hostels to provide capital funds and an incentive for providers to invest in upgrading facilities in that sector. Now that we want to introduce accommodation bonds into nursing homes as well, all of a sudden it is a bad idea. Does that mean you introduced a bad policy? If you compare the standard of hostels to the standard of nursing homes, you would have to say that the idea was not bad at all. But why did you stop at hostels? Why did you let nursing homes deteriorate? Even after receiving advice from Professor Gregory, you buried your heads in the sand and denied that there was a problem.

BREAK.PARA: Let me just revisit the findings of the Gregory report. I realise I am not the first to do this and I certainly will not be the last, but until the members opposite admit that there is a problem we will not be able to convince them of the benefits of this bill. Professor Gregory found that over 40 per cent of residents in nursing homes share rooms with three or more people. Eleven per cent of facilities do not meet fire standards and 15 per cent do not meet health standards. The direct result of this gross neglect is: accommodation is cramped with beds less than a metre apart; people with dementia are housed in inadequate accommodation; toilets are not large enough for walking frames or wheelchairs; there are too few toilets; and there are rooms with no external view. The list goes on.

In total, Professor Gregory said that there was a need for $125 million annually to make substantial improvements. What was Labor's response? A paltry $36 million over four years. They then went on a slash and burn exercise with capital funding. In 1992‐93, $45 million was available for nursing home capital purposes. Within three years this was slashed to just over $10 million—a 75 per cent cut. Worse still, only $2,700,000 was for the upgrading of old and substandard services. The rest was for building new services. So you can see, Mr Deputy Speaker, why I have been left scratching my head. With such a poor track record and virtually no policy statement, how can Labor sit back and attack our proposals? Surely, by this stage, they can see the need for reform.

But just in case the members opposite are still having trouble, I will quickly run through it again. The aged care system, as it stands, is unsustainable. Many homes are in urgent need of repair and upgrading; the funding system is inadequate; the aged care system has too much unnecessary regulation and bureaucracy; and we have a rapidly ageing population.

The system the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) has proposed will go a long way to solving these problems. On behalf of the aged population in my electorate of Bowman, I thank her for having the cou rage and the conviction to see this matter through.

As is the case with many electorates, Bowman is faced with the problem of an ageing population. In the past month I have had three constituents approach me with an urgent need to find nursing home accommodation. One of these people was in the all too familiar predicament of being perfectly healthy one day and totally incapacitated the next. Fortunately, I was able to help this person and she found a place, close to her family, in a short period of time.

I shudder to think what would happen if a dozen people came to me with similar problems, yet this is a very real possibility. The projected population of people over 70 years of age in my electorate is well over the 7,000 mark. Many of these people will require care in the near future. Without proper planning and adequate funding, they will go without. The reforms put forward in this bill will provide those places through better funding, better buildings, better consumer protections and better training.

Unlike Labor, the government's plan for funding is based on the needs of the people, not the bean counters. This means a person will be funded according to the care they need, no matter where they live. One of the essential elements of our package is that it will allow people to remain in familiar surroundings as their care needs change. There is nothing more distressing for the frail and aged than to be shifted from pillar to post every time they need a greater level of care. They should be able to stay close to their family and friends, regardless of the level of care required. Our reforms provide for this.

We will honour our election commitment to deliver proper support for dementia care. Under our plan, the average hostel resident with dementia will receive an increase in funding of over 30 per cent. Our improved funding measures will mean improved buildings—buildings that have been largely neglected by Labor. Instead of just pouring money into the system, as Labor did with hostels, this bill sets a benchmark for building quality. To be able to charge a bond, a facility must be certified and conform to a national standard. This means that, no matter where a resident goes, they can be assured that their building will meet the standard.

We have also built in better protection—protection for people on low incomes, protection for the family, protection on the bond, protection on fees and, most importantly, protection on quality of life. Consumer protection is of utmost importance to the coalition government. With protection comes confidence, and with confidence comes peace of mind.

However, it is not easy to build confidence in the system when the members opposite are hell‐bent on scaring the population. If they really cared, they would be putting forward alternative solutions, not a scare campaign aimed squarely at the elderly and their families. Do not be fooled by this campaign by Labor. This bill does provide protection.

Those who cannot afford to contribute more than the basic fee will not be asked to. This protects those on a full pension and guarantees them a place. Likewise, people who cannot afford to pay an accommodation bond will not be asked to pay one. Every facility will be required to set aside a minimum number of places for those who cannot pay, again, guaranteeing a place for these people. As an added incentive to providers, they will receive a higher government subsidy for these people. This subsidy will also apply to those who can pay only a small bond.

We will also provide protection for the families of those requiring care, for both the spouses and dependent children. The family home will be protected where a spouse or dependent child remains there. There is also special protection for long-term carers and close family members, particularly those on low incomes. There is also built‐in protection for those who do pay a bond. People cannot be charged a bond that will leave them with less than 2½ times the single pension.

There is also a cooling‐off period of seven days after entry before they have to sign a bond agreement. Residents will have the option of paying a lump sum bond or a higher fortnightly or monthly amount. Those who choose to pay a lump sum will have six months to pay.

Protection will be given to those who have assets on paper but who cannot access them to pay a bond, and the bonds themselves will be protected. Bonds must be refunded promptly when people leave—generally within two months, or within seven days if the resident transfers to another facility. This bill also provides protection on fees.

This is in stark contrast to Labor's system. The income test takes only 25c in the dollar above the pension free area, which is half what Labor's system took. A single person can earn up to $49 a week and still pay only the base fee. The comparisons are endless. Labor's system was harsh, unfair and unworkable. It lacked protection. It did not provide a quality of life for aged care residents. Essentially, that is what this bill is all about—quality of life for those in our community who have reached a stage where they need help and deserve help. The reforms put forward by the minister mean older people will get the care, dignity and security they deserve. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the very brief time available to me, I want to make a couple of comments. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Bowman (Mrs West), indicated that she was going to deal with the facts and then proceeded to abuse members on this side, which rather undermined her argument. I want to make it very clear that this legislation will not do what it claims it will do, that is, provide adequate funding. There is a range of reasons for that.

SPEECH.PARA: I first want to address very briefly the reasons why Labor undertook a major reform of the program, which are unlike what the previous speaker was claiming. There was a series of reports in the late 1970s and 1980s which clearly outlined the very significant deficiencies in aged care at that time. Amongst those deficiencies was the fact that there were far too many nursing home beds and far too many elderly people in institutions getting inappropriate care. Yes, the balance shifted during Labor's time, and we make no apology for that.

BREAK.PARA: The findings that were outlined in the series of reports in the 1980s, particularly the joint review of nursing homes and hostels in 1986, which effectively had bipartisan support, argued that there was a need for coordinated and comprehensive reform of the aged care sector. In particular, it pointed to the following: the haphazard nature of program development, which we are seeing again; the excessive concentration on institutional care, and we may be seeing that again; the failure to develop adequate assessment procedures, and it appears that they may well be in jeopardy; the lack of coordination between various levels of government—there are signs that this government wants to hand a great deal more of aged care responsibility back to the states, which was a problem 20 years ago; and the inefficiency of the prevailing funding mechanisms. Because of all of those reasons, there was a major change.

The Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) claimed in her second reading speech that the bill represents `the most significant reform of aged care services in Australia for over a decade' which will involve what she calls `major structural reform'. In my view, the minister confuses change with reform because this is a very significant backward step, not a forward step. In her second reading speech, she made a gratuitous insult to the previous government by claiming that Labor—and the previous speaker reiterated this—had wilfully ignored the sector for 13 years. Nothing could be further from the truth.

In the last decade we have seen a major reform which decreased, quite deliberately, the number of nursing home beds per capita. It was inappropriate care for people who did not need it. Most of them wanted then, and want now, to be in their homes—not in institutions, not in nursing homes.

We saw an increase in the number of hostel beds—deliberately. Remember, these are voluntary; they are not based on need to the same extent as nursing homes are. We saw a dramatic expansion in home based care. This is what the people of Australia told us they wanted. This was based on what people wanted; it was not imposed on them as this bill is.

We saw—unlike what this government's proposals will provide for—significant increases in overall expenditure on all those components, from $1.2 billion to $2.6 billion. What have we seen in comparison from this government over the last two budgets? We have seen the successive withdrawal of over $500 million. Who pays? It is the user. It is the same old philosophy: the government withdraws its efforts and the funds are now being provided by those who can afford it.

There are very few in this community who can afford the sorts of costs that will be imposed on them. They will have to sell their homes and their assets. That is absolutely clear, even from the minister's own statements. What we saw were quality improvements and monitoring which seemed likely to be abandoned. We saw access to nursing home care on the basis of need after careful assessment and, again, that is likely to be abandoned.

What is this nursing home going to do when it tries to upgrade its facilities? It costs $20,000 to $25,000 to upgrade a room, and 60 per cent are FDPs. Where is the money going to come from, Minister? You do not consider those things.

The department does not consider those things when it draws up a national strategy. It is all geared to the Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth and Adelaide crescent. Surely some of your backbenchers—the John Forrests, the Barry Wakelins—are dealing with the same problem. What is wrong with the shadow minister's requirement to modify the bill by putting those things in? I cannot believe that you are going to play the numbers game and steamroll us. What am I going to say to people in Franklin, in the Huon, who are going to go to Elder Care? `I am sorry, but you are going to have a substandard service'; a two-tiered service that you say is totally impossible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dargavel, Steven, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments moved by the shadow minister. The dire need for appropriate objects in this legislation is brought about by the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and the government moving towards a discriminatory two-tiered system. The government's concessional supplement of $5 per bed per day is clearly not enough. It will threaten the viability of nursing homes in our community. Income from accommodation bonds will range between $10 and $19 per day, and we need to make sure that that is available.

SPEECH.PARA: There are 500 million reasons why this minister is wrong: $500 million was cut from the 1996-97 budget for aged care. There are 500 million reasons why old people have cause to be disappointed in this government.

In a letter sent to the minister and me from the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, a joint paper that was presented by eight organisations representing the major churches was cited. It said:

What we fear is that some areas will become known for their ability to meet quality standards, while others, in low income/asset areas, will struggle to provide a service which works in the interests of the residents, regardless of the good intentions of the proprietors.

That is what eight churches are saying in this country. That is what the care providers are saying. Quite regrettably, the moves by the government to introduce a class based system of care—a discriminatory two‐tiered basis of care—has generated some fear and concern in the aged community. That is understandable.

All the government can do is turn around to the individual who is valiantly trying to defend the aged in our community, the shadow minister, and attack her, not defend and debate the legislation they are presenting to this House. No, they put a guillotine on the debate. They put a guillotine on the debate because their movement in introducing a discriminatory two-tiered system is absolutely indefensible. It is absolutely reprehensible.

Some speakers have suggested that one of the organisations seeking to criticise the government's legislation is a Labor front organisation. I would suggest that the eight churches in this country could hardly be described as Labor front organisations. Indeed, I would suggest that they have independently and reasonably come to the conclusion that there is very serious cause for concern over the government's move. They say that the supplement level of $5 per day or $1,825 per year threatens this ethos and tradition and seems to be predicated on the concept of cross-subsidisation with facilities where organisations will be required merely to meet the mandated proportion of residents classed as concessional.

Clearly, service providers in this country are concerned about the government's proposals. They are calling for this bill to be put on the backburner. It is a reasonable proposition that the government take a very cautious and slow approach in the consideration of changes to this legislation. But what does the government do? It guillotines the debate and it seeks to steamroll and ramrod through dangerous changes which will, I fear, build on other more destructive changes for aged care in this country. It will build upon the $500 million worth of cuts that it ripped out of aged care in this country. It is ill prepared. It does not give the detail required for people to feel comfortable and relaxed—far from it—about the options in their old age.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that it is prudent when considering changes to this legislation that a very cautious and considered approach be taken. I fear that that is not the government's intention in guillotining the debate and introducing a two-tiered class discriminatory based system into aged care. By taking $500 million out of aged care, what we are seeing is a very dark turn of events for aged people in my community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis, Arch, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been an avalanche of concern in opposition to the proposals that the government is advancing in the Aged Care Bill 1997. That avalanche of concern has been ignored by the government in its desire to push through this legislation. In its intent in pushing through this legislation, it has gagged debate on this bill, denying many members of parliament on the speakers list the opportunity to present more fully the concerns of their electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: I do want to take the opportunity that the consideration in detail presents in a couple of minutes to make some points about this. The organisations that are actually involved in having to deal with the effects of this bill—the people who administer the aged care services, many of whom are charitable and church organisations—have made their views well known. Aged Care Queensland Inc., an organisation representing those various church and charitable organisations, has written to all federal members from Queensland this week expressing their serious concerns about what the government is doing. I just want to quote very quickly from one part of that letter. It says:

People in hostels who are financially disadvantaged currently receive a supplement of $3.50 per day. Many of the church and charitable hostels care for more than 60 per cent of those people and can therefore expect a loss of $2 per day for each. For every 100-bed hostel in this situation, the minister is taking away $43,800, which is not replaced by other income. That represents more than one job in every 100 beds and there are over 10,000 hostel beds in our membership in Queensland.

The minister at the table, the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), should contemplate their plea to her to reconsider this folly. You are stripping away $43,800 from those charitable organisations and church groups who seek to provide a service to some of the most disadvantaged people in this community who are without the strength to stand up and fight you politically. You use your numbers in this parliament to gag the opposition in this debate and to steamroll over the care for those people. That is an outrageous position for any government to adopt against any group in the community, but to do it against the aged and the frail is one of the most repugnant things this government has managed to do in its sorry 14 or 15 months in office.

Throughout the debate I have listened to members of the government stand up and defend the proposition and particularly seek to refute the view that there is any income barrier, that you will not need to sell your house or you will not be put in a position where the family assets will have to be sold in order for the aged and the family to be cared for. We on this side of the House know that that is exactly what is going to happen in many cases. People will be confronted with very substantial bills. The estimates are not unrealistically now placed in the $80,000 range. What do members of the government say in support of that? I have heard member after member say, `Oh, yes, but they don't have to pay unless they are there for more than six months.'

We know why people go into nursing homes. They do not go there for a holiday. Nursing homes are not somewhere where people go for respite for two or three weeks. People go into nursing homes because their medical condition demands that care. It is not by choice. It is not something over which they have any control. They are placed there by virtue of their need for health care.

What happens to people who go into nursing homes? Where do they go after they leave nursing homes? The sad fact is that most people leave in a box. They do not leave nursing homes to go back home or to go to a hostel. Either they go from a nursing home to intensive care in a hospital or, sadly, they pass away in a nursing home. That is the cold, hard truth of it.

Government members stand up in this debate and say, `But you don't have to pay as long as you are not there for more than six months.' They are saying to the aged and the frail who do not have a big bankroll, `As long as you die in the first six months, your family won't have to sell the house. As long as you're dead in a couple of weeks, it will be okay. The family will not have to put the house on the market.' What a disgraceful thing to be putting upon the people of Australia and, worst still, those people least able to defend themselves.

This government is seeking to protect a minister who cannot defend this bill, who has not been able to engage in proper debate with the shadow minister, and it is using its numbers to crunch through this nasty piece of legislation. When its effects are visible in the community, the people in nursing homes and their families will make it plain to the government what they think, and the opposition will reap the rewards at the next election as a result. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the next speaker, I remind members that we are dealing with the amendments to the bill in relation to the objects and that debate should be restricted to those items.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, with your reminder to us all as to exactly what this aged care legislation and the amendments that are proposed here are seeking to do, I go specifically to the issue of the capacity of people to pay for that care, which is clause 2(a)(iii). I want to introduce yet another element into this debate because I do not think, although I stand to be corrected, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) has defended in here the government's position in respect of this bill and the effect it will have on another section of the community; namely, the veterans community.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been about nine weeks since I had responsibility on our side of the parliament for the veterans community, but let me tell the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) this: I can recall that when this bill was first proposed the veterans community were very loud in expressing their concerns to me because they themselves operate nursing homes right around this country.

Their concern was for the people whom the present Minister for Veterans' Affairs—and, dare I say, previous ministers as well but more particularly this minister—and this government like to stand up in front of and trumpet how much they are going to look after them. Their concern was: what will happen to these people? Their concern was for the war heroes and the people whom the Minister for Veterans' Affairs sends out kits about and gives people badges to wear and says they have to wrap themselves up in the flag.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs should now be representing veterans' interests in terms of nursing home places. He has not been here to defend that proposition. I hope he comes in. I hope he or his staff are in front of a television and watching this debate, and I hope that he comes into this place to put a view on behalf of the veterans community because capacity to pay for care, the outcomes that people will receive and getting high quality care are all issues even more important to those people whom this country owes. The people whom this country owes are those who have fought for this country in terms of their service on behalf of this nation.

I find it extraordinary that the views of those organisations—the views of the RSL movement more generally but of a range of organisations associated with the RSL—that operate nursing homes around this country are not being considered here. Perhaps the minister's defence will be that they are a front for the Labor Party. Bruce Ruxton, I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, is not a front for the Labor Party—never has been; doubt that he ever will. He might have had a very good close personal relationship with the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, but I can tell you he is no front for the Labor Party.

But he and many other representatives of the RSL, I am sure, have expressed these sorts of concerns to the minister. He has expressed on behalf of his constituency, just as people like Rusty Priest in New South Wales and the other presidents of the RSL movement around the states would have expressed on behalf of their constituency, concerns about the impact that all of these aspects of this piece of dreadful legislation will have on their membership.

I just wonder whether they are being heard, whether or not it is perhaps proposed to issue yet another kit on behalf of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs that says, `Don't worry about it. It'll be all right because you'll go into a nursing home and there is bound to be a bed struck for you.' Or perhaps the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop) might strike a medal, but then that will be struck down. It is simply not appropriate.

As people enter their twilight years of life they can reflect on what this country means to them and what this country owes them—and certain people do have a legitimate claim to say that this country does owe them—yet I am not sure whether the Minister for Family Services or the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has given that appropriate thought.

Certainly many veterans are in the same position as ordinary aged Australians and they are, for that very reason, just as frightened. They are just as frightened about what is going to happen to the family home, they are concerned about the funding they will have to find to buy a position in a nursing home in the future and they are concerned about things like quality of care—whether they will go into a second tier system. That is really a fundamental concern that the veterans expressed to me. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I particularly want to take up that matter because, indeed, the Minister for Veterans Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) has very much been engaged with us in the preparation of the Aged Care Bill and these reforms. It is in recognition of the tremendous contribution that both veterans and all older Australians have made to this country that we have introduced these reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be remiss of us to consign veterans and others in the community to the kinds of conditions they were consigned to during the 13‐year administration of the Labor government and put them into substandard accom modation. We have given careful consideration to the special standing of veterans in our community. The Department of Veterans' Affairs will extend its special role in caring for veterans by paying a subsidy for all veterans in residential care, not just those who are in nursing homes who are already covered. So it is in recognition of and, indeed, with deep respect for our veterans and all of those who are frail and ageing in our community that we have introduced these very important reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going to make them pay.
—They will pay only if they have the capacity to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments relate to the Aged Care Bill objectives that we are talking about at the moment and I intend my contribution to be relevant, as all other speakers' contributions have been. The objectives of the bill are central to an understanding publicly of the bill, about the intent of the bill and the government's intent in these particular reforms. Many organisations in the community crucially involved and engaged in the issue of aged care in this country, many people caring for elderly people in our country and many elderly people in this nation are concerned, confused and not comfortable or relaxed about what this government is proposing. The fact is—and the objectives of the bill are an example of this—that people do not know for sure what is happening. They do not know for sure what the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and what this government are really intending to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of what they have suggested in this bill are nothing more than words. It is not in the bill. The minister says, `Trust me, I'm the minister.' The people of Australia, particularly the elderly people of Australia, have every right not to trust this minister and to have real concerns about what this government is doing. Since the election we have seen core and non-core promises being made in many other areas. We have seen a range of issues that were never issues before the election. Now major changes have been proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including this one.

—Including this one, as the shadow minister mentions. These changes that have come forward have been couched in this view of, `Trust us.' The people of Australia, particularly the elderly community and aged care providers in Australia, have every right to have real concerns about this government's proposals today. One of the proposed amendments states:

BREAK.PARA: Clause 2‐1, page 2, (lines 5 to 13), omit paragraph (a), substitute:
(a) to provide for funding of *aged care that ensures that the care provided:

PARA.TAB: (i) is of a high quality;
(ii) is of a type and level appropriate to the needs of the people who require care;
(iii) is available to the people who require care, irrespective of their capacity to pay for that care;
(iv) results in appropriate outcomes for the people receiving the care.

BREAK.PARA: I do not see anything particularly controversial in that. I think it is fair to say, and any fair-minded observer would agree, that we should all be able to agree on what is said there. But this government will not agree to it. This government again is saying, `Trust us. Be comfortable and relaxed. Stick with us and it will all be okay; it will all be all right on the night.' But, as I said earlier, many organisations who deal with aged people in this country and provide for their care are not comfortable and relaxed. They have real concerns about what this reform really means. That is why the opposition is so keen to have a full and proper debate on this issue in this chamber and that is why the opposition is extremely concerned that the government has guillotined debate on this issue, as it has on so many other issues since the last election.

Before the last election I can remember being lectured by those opposite, particularly by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), about parliamentary standards and the actions of this parliament. Much of what has happened and much of what we are seeing today from this government has been and is about denying debate, denying the proper consideration of issues before this parliament. This is not the first time this has happened with this minister. Many times we would think that, rather than being in the chamber, we were in some sort of hearing before a congressional committee in the US, because the minister is always pleading the Fifth Amendment: `I refuse to answer on the grounds it may incriminate me.' Sometimes she refuses to answer on the grounds, `It may incinerate me.' Sometimes she refuses to answer on the grounds, `I don't really understand what I'm doing here.' That comes through in the objectives of the bill. A real concern is the fact that much of what is in the bill does not correlate with what the minister says.

Other speakers have already mentioned that Aged Care Australia are very concerned about this bill and do not want it passed at this stage. They want proper consideration in the community. They do not want fluffy, puffy, pseudo-consideration. They do not want those sorts of developments within the community. They want a proper, reasoned and evaluated approach to this bill and to the consideration of these issues. This government stands condemned for its approach to this bill and its approach to these amendments, because it is denying a proper debate, it is denying an opportunity for the community to consider these issues properly and, on this issue, it is denying older Australians the safety of their position. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a very simple question for the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan). Did and does the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) support you in this legislation in its entirety?
—As I said, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) has had an association with us in the preparation of this bill and he does support this bill.

The Australian Nursing Federation have called on members of parliament to block the bill unless substantial amendments are made. SPEECH.PARA: The minister might make one of her general promises again, but what the nurses want and what older people want is a provision placed in the bill, which we are seeking to do by way of one of our amendments, to ensure that nursing care is emphasised at the start of this legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —Another Labor front.

As the vice-president of the New South Wales branch of the AMA said in his letter today:

SPEECH.PARA: The real problem lies with the savage and continued cutbacks to nursing home financing by the federal government.

That is really what is at the heart of all this. That is why we have to get rid from the objects of this bill the idea that this bill is just going to provide yet another avenue for this government to force its budget cuts on the older people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to endorse the proposals by the shadow minister for social security, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), that we have a clarification under clause 2.1, page 2 of the Aged Care Bill, with a clearly defined spelling out of the provisions for people in nursing homes. I have just been on the phone to the nursing homes in my area to find out about this financially disadvantaged persons component. I received a letter today, as I guess as most members did, from the Australian Catholic Health Care Association about their concerns, which obviously have been expressed also to the minister. I cannot find much in the way of consolation by way of guarantees from the minister that financially disadvantaged persons are going to be catered for under this new system. A press release dated 26 May from the same organisation says the following:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the proposed changes the Government will provide a capital regeneration subsidy of $5 a day per bed for financially disadvantaged people, while the payment of an accommodation bond will generate an average of $19 per bed per day for non financially disadvantaged.

This represents a shortfall of $14 per bed per day of accommodation for financially disadvantaged people. This is totally inadequate. The difference will see these people in multi-bed rooms in buildings that will reflect this disparity in funding.

For some facilities cross-subsidisation may account for this shortfall but this raises serious concerns in our sector where over 70 per cent of facilities commit at least 55 per cent of places to financially disadvantaged people.

In the interim I have been on the phone to the half a dozen or so nursing homes in my electorate. I am going to have a two-tiered system in my electorate. I have the posh nursing homes in the eastern suburbs of my electorate that are just about at the quota level of 25 per cent. As I said in a speech earlier today, Elder Care in Franklin are up around 60 per cent. One that is within a bull's roar of my electorate, St Anne's Compton Downs, in probably one of the most socially disadvantaged areas in the whole of Australia—broad acre public housing gone mad—is at 53 per cent at the moment whereas their nursing home in the posh part of town, in Davy Street, is at about 30 per cent, just above what the minister prescribes: 25 per cent. So we are going to have two‐tiered health care in the nursing homes in two disadvantaged parts of my electorate. The letter I received today, dated 3 June, from the Australian Catholic Health Care Association says:
Under the new system service providers will be required to provide a certain percentage of beds for Financially Disadvantaged Persons—
FDPs as they call them. It continues:

I agree. It continues:

However, in some regions, where there are large numbers of FDP's we fear that the elimination of the Government's general Capital Grants program combined with the new funding arrangements will reduce capital investment and therefore access.
What we fear is that some areas—
and this will be two areas of my electorate—

will become known for their ability to meet quality standards while others, in low income/asset areas will struggle to provide a service which works in the interest of the residents, regardless of the good intentions of the proprietors.

I would like a guarantee from the minister: `Well, Harry, irrespective of where people live in the electorate of Franklin, whether there are 53 or 60 per cent of FDPs in nursing homes, they will get the same sort of service as the people on the eastern shore of your electorate in the Lindisfarnes and the Bellerives and the Howrahs.'

Where a nursing home owns two different nursing home complexes, one is going to be upper crust and the other one is going to be socioeconomically disadvantaged because of this stupid system that the minister wants to push down our throats. It is totally irresponsible. The minister goes on to us about our 13 years of neglect and shameful treatment of people. This is ridiculous. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to follow the contribution by the member for Franklin (Mr Quick), because his mother lives in my electorate. I know that she would be a little unsure about his contribution, because the member for Franklin understands very clearly the challenges that confront the elderly in an electorate like Mallee in the north west of Victoria. We have people there who, when they visit their elderly loved ones, have to travel past existing aged care facilities to get to see them.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Franklin is like so many members sitting on the other side of the chamber who know that these reforms are necessary. Gregory's contribution in 1995 should have shocked and shamed all of us in this parliament, because we have neglected and let down the elderly Australians who deserve the best aged care. I am getting a little sick and tired of being cast time and time again by members of the opposition as some uncaring Australian. I care very much.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I know that you are allowing a fairly wide‐ranging debate on this amendment that we are now considering, and I appreciate that. Prior to 1990, I knew absolutely nothing about aged care, and then my family was confronted with my late father's stroke. We were shocked to discover just what a mess aged care is in. We spent two years dealing with the aged care system and, at one stage of the trauma that we were confronted with as a family, my mother said to me, `Son, for goodness sake, somebody has to go to Canberra and sort this out.'

I object so strongly to the cheap politics that are being played here. The people that count the most are not us. Put the politics aside. It would be better politics for the Australian Labor Party to do what it can to help the government to make sure that we get this major reform correct. We are not important here. The people who are important are the elderly Australians out there who have been neglected. I am not going to be churlish like the Australian Labor Party is currently being. I have spent four years in this parliament trying to get some satisfaction for my mother's dear wish. We go through these complicated CAM‐SAM, alternately state funded, federally funded arrangements and I resent the fact that it took six months off the twilight end of my father's life. That is what has driven me, and I am really pleased to stand here and support the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) who cares about the people out there.

I want to make an appeal to the Labor Party: for goodness sake get onside, give the cheap politics away and give us a hand to get this right. There are just so many people out there—I have 67 aged care facilities in my electorate; some of you might say that that is far too many, but you need to understand that my electorate represents 25 per cent of the geographic area of Victoria—who are all saying to me, `John, these reforms are necessary. Thank you.' Sure, they have some concerns and the minister at the table has been addressing those. People have been widely consulted and we have made sure that the prudential arrangements are the best they can be. They will be monitored and we will be making sure that quality standards are properly supervised. Most importantly of all, we will be making sure that every dollar is delivered to the coalface so that people like the mother of the member for Franklin can look forward to her aged care provision being the best we can offer, and not just the best state by state but the best gauged by world standards. That is the vision we are after.

My appeal to the Australian Labor Party is to forget this stupid nonsense, to get onside and give us a hand to deliver to the people who count the most—not us, but our elderly Australians who have worked hard all their lives to build a prosperous nation which we are now enjoying. They deserve the best that we can give them. Put the cheap politics aside, put the scaremongering aside and get onside and give us a hand.
