To the previous government's credit, they had the issue analysed and it was very clear that we had serious issues with aged accommodation in nursing homes.

SPEECH.PARA: The House apparently does need some reminder—although it has been mentioned many times in the last day or two—that 75 per cent of nursing homes needed fixing or redesigning, 70 per cent of homes needed fixing or rebuilding to meet Commonwealth standards, 13 per cent of nursing homes did not meet fire authority standards and 39 per cent of residents were in rooms with four or more beds—and it goes on and on. The new government was faced with that and, to the great credit of the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), she has tackled the problem and brought to the House a solution and hope for reasonable nursing home accommodation into the next century.

The member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) mentioned deceiving the poor. The great deception in this debate is not having accommodation available. It has been my experience as a member over the last four years that the greatest criticism that governments have received is the lack of access to appropriate services and to homes. There is some philosophical meandering on this debate rather than coming to the hard issue of the provision of accommodation and service. Some of the more extreme will suggest that the bill will cause a higher effective marginal tax rate. What absolute nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will.

—I say to the opposition spokesperson, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), who is at the table, that we on this side of the House do not regard the amount that we pay for our food and accommodation as increasing our effective marginal tax rate. The suggestion of trying to equate the expense of living with income tax is absolute rubbish. Regrettably, this debate has degenerated to an unreasonable degree into simple political opportunism based on the oldest political trick in the book: the scare tactic, the big scare. But I will discipline myself and try to return to the reality of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: An issue of particular interest to me and to my electorate has been the area of variable fees in hostels. It is important to note that not all hostels will be affected by the change from variable fees. Around 30 per cent of hostels charge on this basis; the remainder do not. Providers will receive additional funding as the basic contribution payable by hostel residents is aligned with that payable by nursing home residents. This will prove equivalent to 50 per cent of that which is currently provided through variable fees.

In order to ease the transition to the new system, grandparenting arrangements for existing residents will be allowed so that providers can continue to take some level of fee income from residents who are currently paying more than they would under the new arrangements.

I think it is important that the House recognises—I know the government does—the issues: the impact of the reforms and the improvements that these reforms will bring to regional and rural and remote services. The electorate of Grey covers nearly one million square kilometres and has one of the most diverse and sparse populations in the nation. As I have indicated, aged care services in this part of the world require particular attention—attention they have not received in the past.

The limited building and upgrade fund for regional aged care services will be addressed by the government in the form of capital grants worth up to $10 million a year, which will be targeted towards rural and remote areas. It is very important to understand that there is a grading of higher amounts down to lower amounts, depending on the number of places in isolated locations.
In conclusion, I would like to remind the House of a former distinguished Labor minister of this House—Gary Johns—and his total support of the government's position. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the proposed amendments of the shadow minister, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), who is in the House today. Let me put on the record that older Australians will be eternally indebted to the shadow minister for the spirited way in which she has attempted to improve this piece of legislation, the aged care legislation, now before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has the gall to call this package a package of reforms. If it were so—and it had the support of the general community—we would be prepared to entertain some aspects of this legislation. But the simple fact is that there is not a community organisation in this nation that supports this particular piece of legislation. They have put before the government their pleas for it to be withdrawn and for the issues contained therein to be re‐examined.

If the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) is as arrogant as her Treasurer (Mr Costello) on these matters she will bear the consequence. For the minister's benefit, I will relate some of the views of the Geelong community on this issue. I recently met with a representative group of Geelong aged care providers on this particular issue. Present at that meeting were Joy Leggo, President of the Barwon region branch of Aged Care Victoria and CEO of the Geelong Multicultural Hostel; Barbara Abley, CEO of the Kalkee Community; John Temple, General Manager of Aged Care Services and St Laurence Community Services; Austin Patterson, CEO of the Bellarine Peninsula Community Health Service; Sister Mary Geeson, CEO of Rice Village; Bob May, owner‐operator of Palmerston Court Aged Care Hostel, Drysdale; Joe Longo, owner‐operator of Leopold Lodge; and Darryl Rowe, Chairman of the Board of Management of the Kalkee Community.

Here we have private providers and people from charitable institutions who provide care to our older Australians. This is what this community delegation had to say to me about the reforms that had been proposed by the minister and that are the subject of the amendments that are being proposed by the shadow minister in this debate:
These proposed changes must impact on service delivery and some services to residents may have to be reduced.

That is the inevitable outcome on the ground in the regions of Australia to that which the minister is proposing in the Aged Care Bill today. As to the introduction of accommodation bonds, this is what the community delegation had to say:
The introduction of accommodation bonds to nursing homes—known as entry contributions in hostels—has also caused considerable concern and confusion within the community at large.

The providers have responded to the proposals that were made in the first budget brought down by this government. The conclusion that they have come to is that the providers in aged care are not only confused but considerably concerned about the implications of the details of this bill which are subject to the amendments that are being proposed by the shadow minister. The community delegation had this to say on the issue of accommodation bonds:

What does concern us is that the collection of these funds are to be used by agencies in the future for capital improvements on their facilities which in the past has been undertaken by way of capital grants from the Commonwealth.
The government has backed way from its responsibility in this particularly policy area and has now put the onus on the private sector to provide these. The community delegation further states:

BREAK.PARA: Under this proposal, there is going to be little incentive for nursing homes to take a hostel resident who has already been in care for four or five years.

The impact of this will be in the social area. The disadvantaged who should have access to these facilities will be denied. It is an extraordinary state of play that in 1997 in Australia the ageing population—people who have made an enormous contribution to Australia—are to be treated in this way by the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make another attempt, in addition to my previous contribution, to appeal to the shadow minister, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), who is at the table. She knows in her heart of hearts that this major reform is necessary. She only has to go back and re‐read the Gregory report. The proposed amendments to the Aged Care Bill 1997 are not much more than words. Reference is made to the need for higher quality, which is the whole purpose of this major reform.

SPEECH.PARA: In the five minutes I had prior to this contribution, I made clear the motivation that drives me and my family. This reform is a matter of urgency for the nation. I want to do what I can as a federal member of this parliament to make sure that no family goes through what my family did five years ago because of the complicated arrangements we currently have for aged care. I repeat: the people who are important are those to whom we are going to deliver.

I am tired of being portrayed as an uncaring monster by the opposition. It is simply not true. The Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), who introduced the bill, is as committed as those on the government benches to delivering to the people who count the most. Guaranteed quality is the prime motivation of this reform. It is time the Australian Labor Party agreed with the legislation instead of playing this political game of words and got on with the job of assisting us in government to deliver to the people who count the most.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Does he recall saying in question time yesterday, `In order to reduce unemployment in the sustained way over a longer period of time you need higher growth, you need an infinitely more flexible labour market and you also need taxation reform'? Did he see the Treasurer's comments a few hours later on the ABC's 7.30 Report where he said, `Taxation is not the answer to unemployment; the answer to unemployment is in economic growth and industrial relations.' Does the Prime Minister now agree with the Treasurer that a GST has nothing to do with jobs?

—Mr Speaker, I am pleased that the Leader of the Opposition has asked me this question. Once again, the opposition leader has selectively quoted from the remarks made by my colleague the Treasurer. The coalition's view is that all proposals for tax reform should be examined against three benchmarks: will the reforms make it easier to create jobs?
—No.

—So you are saying no reforms—a very interesting interjection. I repeat: will the reforms make it easier to create real jobs? Will the reforms increase international competitiveness? Will the reforms improve the living standards of the Australian people? We in the coalition are prepared to debate and discuss tax reform against those three benchmarks. They are important benchmarks against which the debate will take place. A tax system that reduces the cost of doing business and provides incentives to work and invest will obviously boost economic growth and that must be beneficial for jobs. Unlike the Labor Party, the coalition will not rule out sensible measures, including tax reform, which can contribute to higher economic growth and therefore employment.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Earlier today the Prime Minister launched the government's campaign against crime and violence. Can the Prime Minister outline the steps being taken to address violence and crime in our society?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I did launch the national strategy against violence and crime which fulfils yet another election promise of the coalition. The law and justice policy for the last election stated that every Australian was entitled to feel safe in his or her home and on the streets. We are delivering on that commitment, in cooperation with the states and territories, through the most comprehensive strategy of programs at a national level to address violence and crime. The priorities of the national campaign against violence and crime in its first year are residential burglary, domestic violence and fear of crime in young people. Today's launch was in cooperation with the states and territories and there has been an allocation of $13 million over a period of three years.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the House of the great contribution to the stability of the community and the great contribution to safety which came out of the national implementation of the firearms control from the police ministers in May of last year. Since then we have also seen the establishment of a national register of convicted paedophiles and the convening of the Aboriginal deaths in custody summit which has been set down for later this year. There have been family violence intervention projects, a domestic violence database has been established and there will be a domestic violence summit convened later this year to which the government and, I hope, all members of the parliament will be very strongly committed.

We have carried out a national women's safety survey and there have been a number of strategies to strengthen family responses to child abuse. There has also been a focus on a national youth suicide strategy and shortly after it came to office the government launched a number of youth homelessness pilot programs. There has been a rural and remote domestic violence initiative and, of course, there has been information on firearms safety.

BREAK.PARA: All of these programs have been implemented since the government came to power some 14 months ago and they are an earnest of our commitment to mobilise the resources of the Commonwealth and the states in the most effective manner to combat violence and crime. At the launch today, I outlined a number of new initiatives, all of which are designed, I stress, in cooperation with the state and territory governments, to increase the level of security and stability that ordinary citizens in our community feel. There is often debate in Australia about the proper role of government. I put it to the House that there is no more important responsibility of government at all levels than to do all they can to provide the maximum climate of physical security, security of property, the right of Australian citizens to walk the streets without interference or molestation, the right of Australians to travel on trains and buses late at night without interference or molestation and the right of people to visit sporting events without being molested or abused by people behaving in an anti‐social way.

I hope this campaign will make a contribution to improving the atmosphere of security—I am sure it will. I thank the governments of all the states and territories of Australia and I particularly thank the contribution of the South Australian Attorney‐General, Mr Trevor Griffin, who was present at the launch in the Great Hall today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following that answer from the Prime Minister, I wish to ask him a question in relation to the safety of Australians from crime. Is it not a fact that the Victorian police commissioner has said that our border controls are not working? Why then has the federal government cut funding to the Australian Federal Police by $37.6 million in the last two budgets which will cause the loss of 100 federal agents? Is it not a fact that the federal government has cut funding to Customs, AUSTRAC and the Director of Public Prosecutions? Is it not the case that, as a result of the cuts to police funding, the only drug that is cheaper in this country is heroin? What hope have young Australians got when your government is presiding over such a disgraceful outcome?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I reject the allegations contained in the question as to the impact of government budgetary decisions. I make it clear that I have not seen the particular remarks attributed to the Victorian police commissioner. So I am not in a position to know whether or not they are selectively quoted.

ANSWER.PARA: I can say only that earlier questions in the parliament to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, who is responsible for Customs, about the alleged impact of reductions in that area on our capacity in relation to border control and border protection have been very adequately answered.

I would remind the honourable gentleman that the campaign that I launched today will put additional resources into the campaign to provide a safer Australia. The most effective way to provide a safer Australia is to mobilise more effectively in a national fashion the law enforcement agencies of the various states and territories in cooperation with the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Is the minister aware of reports in yesterday's Transcontinental newspaper of Port Augusta regarding a motion introduced into the Legislative Council of South Australia to support the sale of AN and of a petition to the Senate being prepared by the workers of AN at Port Augusta? Could the minister advise the House of the increasing level of support for the Commonwealth's sale of Australian National?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I again thank the honourable member for Grey for raising these very important issues in the House. The issue of the sale of AN is causing a great deal of interest and concern in South Australia because the Labor Party has decided to block the sale of AN in the Senate. This has caused alarm and outrage in South Australia, particularly amongst AN workers who have seen the coalition government's decision to sell AN, to give it a new owner with a new capital injection and a new management direction, as the best way forward for the development of rail in Australia and for the future of AN workers.

ANSWER.PARA: With the decision the Labor Party has made to block the sale, AN workers are now going out there and expressing their concerns publicly and volubly to the Labor Party about how outraged they are at the Labor Party's action. Last week I drew to the attention of the House that AN workers at the workshops at Port Augusta had written to me and had expressed their alarm. Earlier this week I said that AN workers at Islington workshops were writing to me. I read from a letter from one of those people.

Yesterday, in the South Australian parliament, a motion was moved expressing support for the government's decision to sell AN and calling on the Labor Party to give up their opposition to this sale. Also in that debate in the South Australian parliament a number of local organisations were identified as supporting the government's decision to sell AN and opposing the Labor Party's decision to block it. The list is very long but I will read out some of them. Rail 2000, a lobby group of the rail industry in South Australia, supports the government in their decision to sell AN. The Trades and Labour Council of Port Augusta supports the government in their decision to sell AN and is opposed to the Labor Party's decision to block it. The Spencer Region Development Association, the Northern Regional Development Board, the South Australian Farmers Federation, the Australian Barley Board and the Australian Wheat Board: all of these organisations have expressed their support for the sale of AN because they see this as the way forward for rail in Australia and an opportunity to give those people who work at AN a future and some real prospects.

The thing that really annoys people is the enormous hypocrisy which has been displayed by the Labor Party in this decision. Here is a Labor Party that in government were prepared to privatise so many government instrumentalities: Australian Airlines, Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank. They tried to privatise the airports and they tried to privatise ANL but failed, of course, with those latter two. Here was a Labor Party prepared to do all of those things in government yet, here they are now in opposition doing a complete and utter backflip from their policies in government and being very opportunistic. In the process they are causing alarm and concern amongst those people who work for AN.

AN workers have now decided to put out a petition to urge the Labor Party to change their minds and not to block this in the Senate, and to let the privatisation of AN go forward. The local paper in Port Augusta, the Transcontinental, quotes from a worker who perhaps best describes the feeling of people who work at AN. It says:

This continuing uncertainty is destroying the morale of the work force that remains and we believe that a new rail operator of the workshops and the transport activities of AN would be more beneficial to ourselves, our families, the community of Port Augusta and Australia as a whole.

That is what the workers at AN want. That is what the people of South Australia want. The only people who do not want to give those people a new future and new hope and to give rail a new direction are the Labor Party who have been totally opportunistic and hypocritical in their actions to block the sale of AN. I join with the workers of AN in calling on the Labor Party to change their minds. I join with the workers of AN in asking that the Leader of the Opposition and their transport spokesman go and meet with the workers of AN. Stand up to them and hear from the workers themselves the support that the workers for AN have for the sale of AN and their opposition to the Labor Party's policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, were you correct when you said that the labour market should be infinitely more flexible? Or was the Treasurer correct when he said you did not really mean that. Or was the Minister for Industrial Relations correct when he said you did `not even have a second ripple' of industrial relations reform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We were all correct. We are always correct. The Minister for Industrial Relations and the Treasurer are always cor rect. I am sure they would say that I am always correct too.
—It's the trilogy.

—It is the trilogy—and a very harmonious trilogy. The coalition has already made the labour market infinitely more flexible than it was under the former administration. It is now up to employers and employees to grasp the new opportunities for flexibility and to implement them at the workplace level. The infinitely more flexible labour market required business as well as employees to take our reforms and exploit the enormous productivity potential that is available. By taking advantage of those reforms and transforming them into infinitely more flexible workplaces, Australians can enjoy better pay for better work and more jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: Any objective analysis of the labour market in Australia now and the laws that govern the labour market in Australia now compared with what they were two or three years ago would demonstrate that there is infinitely more flexibility now than there was two or three years ago. I refer to the capacity for people to make direct bargains at a workplace level; the fact that it is no longer possible for unions to compulsorily inject themselves into negotiations between employers and employees when they are not wanted; the fact that the unfair dismissal laws have been significantly improved, although we believe the legacy of anti‐small business practices from the former government were such that even further reforms in that area are desirable; the removal of compulsory unionism; the return of the secondary boycott protection; the capacity of business to get compliance orders from the courts and from the commission. All of those things have provided an infinitely more flexible labour market. Of the many reforms my government has implemented, I am particularly proud of the way in which we have made the Australian labour market infinitely more flexible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier during that question the Prime Minister quoted very extensively from a document. I ask that he table the document from which he was quoting.
—They are private notes.
—Was the Prime Minister reading from a document? Confidential?
—Confidential.
—The document is confidential.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training—a very popular minister, so he is entitled to an early question.
—Move onto your question.

—Constituents in my electorate have welcomed the government's initiatives in literacy and vocational education in schools as helping to improve the employment prospects of their children. What other feedback has the minister received about the government's policies which provide real opportunities for the 60 per cent of school students who choose not to go on to university or other full‐time study?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Wide Bay for his question. The government's initiatives in relation to literacy and vocational education and training are directed to striking at the heart of the disadvantages of young people in the labour market—disadvantages which they inherited after 13 years of the Labor government.

ANSWER.PARA: A document has recently fallen into my hands—a very insightful and in‐depth analysis of these issues. This analysis acknowledges the value of the government's initiatives and also contrasts and compares the government's initiatives with those of the former government. I do not know whether the Leader of the Opposition has seen this analysis yet, but I am sure he would be very interested in it.

I wonder, for example, whether the Leader of the Opposition would accept the conclusion of this analysis, that the Labor Party in government `did not pay anything like enough attention to the early years of schooling'—those years when the literacy skills, of course, have to be communicated. I wonder whether the Leader of the Opposition also accepts that `accommodating the needs of those not intending to proceed directly on to university education in the final years of schooling is something that the Labor Party did not do enough about in government'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds very objective.

—One might think this is an analysis coming from our side, but it is a very objective analysis, as the Prime Minister points out. Again, under the Labor Party education policy, it was `fundamentally unfair that the needs only of those intending to follow an academic pathway are taken into account when framing the year 12 curriculum'. The member for Werriwa might well take notice of this. In relation to adult and community education this document states that the Labor Party `always paid lip‐service to the broader goals of education' and that future Labor governments `must not repeat this failure'. I suppose people are wondering who the author of this document is. The author of the document makes it quite clear that the Labor Party's education policies failed young people, they failed school leavers and they failed adults. Indeed, that just about covers the field.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: BALDWIN

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order on my right!
—He should put it in context and quote the other things I had to say which were very detrimental regarding what you have done.
—There is no point of order. Resume your seat.

—Members might have received some clue from that point of order as to who the author of the paper was. The author was none other than the member for Sydney—importantly, a former shadow minister for education and a former minister for higher education. Of course, as we know, he has now been relegated to the shadow ministry for finance.
—What do you think of that, John Fahey?
—He is in cabinet, and where are you?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Werriwa! The member for Banks!

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! For the third time this week I issue a general warning to you all.

—Of course, the member for Werriwa, the young and the restless member for Werriwa, has been promoted to the education ministry. The key thing about this document is that it is part of the open analysis that is now going on in the Labor Party which the government welcomes. But let us never hear again the cant that your education policies address the needs of young people, because every one of these failures which has been admitted by the member for Sydney underlie the major disadvantages that young unemployed people face in the labour market.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason why youth unemployment rose to 34 per cent when the Leader of the Opposition was the minister for employment and the reason why youth unemployment has become so deeply entrenched are precisely because of these admitted failures of the Labor Party's education policies when in government. The Leader of the Opposition may be inclined to think that this is just an example of the treachery that is going on behind him, because what we have seen is the Labor Party's record in government being absolutely wiped out by these statements.

Young people have been failed, school leavers have been failed, and adults have been failed. The whole span of those relying on education has been failed by the Labor Party in government. Now it is up to your new shadow minister to show that you have any credible policies whatever to help young people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Werriwa.
—Here he is!

—Here I come—on request. My question is also addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Yesterday the minister pointed to an increase in TAFE enrolments as a supposed reason for the substantial fall in university applications. Why, then, do the budget papers show a $72 million cut in Commonwealth funding for TAFE, leading to a loss of 6,400 student places in New South Wales alone? Minister, you have admitted that university applications are down. We all know that youth employment is also down and that the budget contains swingeing TAFE cuts with a loss to student places.
—We are not going to debate the issue.
—Under the government's policies—your policies—where are all these young Australians going?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —Dear, oh, dear! Yesterday we had the member for Werriwa bringing before the House old figures on applications, completely failing to keep up with the fact that enrolments in universities have now gone up. Today he brings before the House completely incorrect figures on vocational education and training in the budget.
—No, they are your own figures, from your own budget papers.

—I do not know whether anyone has the budget papers here, but I would be very happy to take the member for Werriwa through the relevant tables in the budget papers which show the increases in vocational education and training spending under this budget.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me spell out that expenditure on vocational education and training is this year some $144 million higher than it was under the last year of Labor. In 1995-96—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it against—
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition.

—the expenditure of the Labor Party on vocational education and training was $1.2 billion. In 1997-98, expenditure by this government on vocational education and training is $1.35 billion. In other words, there has been a significant increase in expenditure on vocational education and training—not a reduction.

BREAK.PARA: This young fellow over here has absolutely no idea how to read the figures relating to his portfolio. He may be restless, but, if he could sit down at a desk for a while and actually read some of these papers, he would be able to get the facts right.

He also said that in TAFE this year there would be a reduction in respect of training. There will be some 55,000 more places in TAFE this year than there were last year, and some 43,000 of these additional places will be the result of Commonwealth funding. There is absolutely no validity whatever to the question that has been asked by the member for Werriwa. He has no interest in vocational education and training and in creating genuine job opportunities for the young people in his electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer inform the House how the budget contributes to the government's plan to encourage investment and jobs in small business? In particular, what has the government done to reduce the burden of complying with the taxation system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kooyong for his question. The budget includes a number of measures to assist small business with the taxation system with the aim of helping those small businesses with reductions in paper work and, indeed, reductions in the cash‐flow demands of the taxation system.

ANSWER.PARA: A large number of small businesses—some 300,000—will be given the option now of paying to the Australian Taxation Office on a quarterly basis rather than a monthly basis. The measures which I announced in the budget apply to those small businesses which have a withholding requirement of under $25,000 who after 30 June 1998, rather than remitting on a monthly basis, will be remitting on a quarterly basis, reducing the number of occasions on which they have to interact with the Australian Taxation Office from 12 to four—a reduction to one-third in relation to the administration requirements with the Australian Taxation Office.

BREAK.PARA: This will allow those small businesses to defer the payment of tax in 1998-99 of $500 million in terms of cash flow as a result of this measure. This comes on top of a number of other taxation measures which the government has introduced to assist small business. There was the reduction in the provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent to six per cent. There was the introduction of generous capital gains tax rollover provisions for small businesses with assets up to $5 million. Where they rollover a business or rollover an asset, they can do so without the imposition of capital gains tax. That is an option to allow small business to grow bigger.

It also came along with an option for small business to rollover into retirement up to $500,000 at a cost of $50 million per annum. In relation to fringe benefits tax, from 1 April this year small businesses are exempt from fringe benefits tax on car parking on their business premises, and the arrangements for employee taxi travel have been extended allowing taxi travel to and from work to be entirely exempt from fringe benefits. These are enormous improvements in the taxation system which allow small business the opportunity to get on with the job and to save. They are conducive to small business growth and they are conducive to employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, which option have you backed on car tariffs—the Black Jack option, which breaches our international trade obligations and is the first proposal for a tariff increase since Black Jack McEwen; or the Treasurer's option, which is to slash tariffs on the basis that he wants to sack only half the workers in the car industry in this country?
—I will give you the option I have not adopted, and that is the inconsistency option of the member for Hotham.

—My question is addressed to the Minister Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government as Minister representing the Minister for the Environment. As today is World Environment Day, can the minister outline to the House the government's sizeable achievements in boosting the environmental capital of our nation for future generations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Indeed, it is World Environment Day, and the potential to answer this question at this stage after the government has been in power through two budgets and to focus on what we have been able to achieve in the environment is welcome. There are a couple of areas I would like to highlight to the House.

ANSWER.PARA: The first is climate change. We would all recognise that moving on greenhouse emissions is fundamentally important and reductions, in cooperation with the business community, have been achieved. During the year, 30 of Australia's leading companies, 12 industry associations and one government have signed agreements to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and the government is committed to continuing that agenda.

In the area of forests, an area that has bedevilled governments throughout this country for some time, we have made significant progress. An additional $48 million will be spent over three years to expedite the completion of comprehensive regional assessments of the nation's forests. That will allow the government to fulfil its election commitment to bring forward the completion of regional forest agreements, the first of which has already been signed for the East Gippsland region and the RFA for Tasmania is currently under negotiation.

The aim of policy is to provide certainty to the utilisation of forestry, to provide sustainability of the forest assets that we have and, of course, to give job opportunities. The unique partnership between my colleagues the Minister for the Environment and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in developing these forest policies has been a major achievement of this government to date.

Another area which we do not often hear about, but in which a major milestone was reached only last week, is whaling. A national task force on whaling has been established and the report to government has been received. It is an election promise which we have fulfilled. The report of the task force was given to the Minister for the Environment this past week on how to achieve the implementation of a permanent international ban on commercial whaling.

In the area of world heritage, the Commonwealth and the Queensland governments have already successfully agreed joint management arrangements for the Fraser Island world heritage area, something which the former Queensland and Commonwealth Labor governments were unable to do. In addition, we have nominated Heard Island, McDonald Island and Macquarie Island for world heritage listing, another election promise fulfilled.

We are an island continent so, therefore, oceans and coasts are particularly important to so many of our communities. We undertook significant steps to ensure that Australia becomes a world leader in marine conservation and management with the development of the very first comprehensive oceans policy, which the Prime Minister launched recently. That will be completed and continued in the first half of next year.

As we have heard in this House, we have also established the Green Corps, a first for Australia, to focus the energies of young Australians to enhance the environment whilst at the same time acquiring additional skills to lead them down a job path and an education path that benefits the nation and those individuals. It is a very innovative program.

But, after a lot of grandstanding and needless delay by the opposition, the major program that we have achieved and put in place is the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia. Why the Labor Party opposed it, I do not know. I do not know why they hate the environment. We know the opposition leader does not like sport, but why they hate the environment and would not support the Natural Heritage Trust is beyond me. Why do they hate the environment?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the cricket?
—The honourable member for Dobell.

—We have taken steps to create the largest single commitment to the environment a government has ever made in the history of federation through the establishment of the trust, which will uniquely bring together the environment portfolio and the energy and primary industry portfolio to benefit the whole nation with a range of programs in vegetation, biodiversity, land resources, coasts, marine life and other matters that I have talked about in this House. But, in conclusion, the interesting figure is that we are spending $1.7 billion, the largest amount ever in our history in environment, from the 1996-97 year through to the year 2000-01. We care, we promise and we deliver on the environment.

—Can the Minister for Family Services explain why the government is closing all 11 family resource centres in Australia? Is the minister aware that in my electorate alone my local family resource centre services 180,000 people and that across the country these centres take care of over two million Australians? Can the minister explain why this government, who at the last election campaigned so heavily on helping families, can find $4.3 million for endangered species while at the same time making family resource centres extinct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Oxley for her question.
—You are having a bad day, Judi.
—It will be worse for you.

—Rather than cutting our commitment to families, this government has boosted funding going to families right across Australia not just in 11 resource centres that Labor put into place when they were in government but right across the spectrum of Australian families all around this country. Spending in my portfolio, since we came to government, has been $1.3 billion in the 1996-97 budget—this is for families—and $1.379 billion in the 1997-98 budget. In both budgets, the allocation exceeded the $1.1 million, not billion, which was spent by the previous government on families in the 1995-96 budget.

ANSWER.PARA: Furthermore, I would like to point out that our funding for families is direct funding. It goes to provide on the ground support, practical support measures, to assist families who are most in need in our communities. We have provided funding to expand the youth activity services in the community, practical services to assist young people and their families, and parenting education.

We have implemented the good beginnings program, a direct program to support young families in Australia right across the country. Family counselling support is also a strong commitment of this government. We have put into place a youth homeless pilot project—a strong commitment of the Prime Minister—and we delivered the family tax initiative, the centrepiece of the government's family policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —In full and on time.

—It was delivered in full and on time, and that is a very significant benefit to Australian families. We totally support Australian families. We recognise them as the basic foundation block of the whole community and indeed the nation. We have a very strong commitment to families in our community.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can the minister please inform the House about the latest progress in delivering on the government's commitment to have pharmacies in rural and remote areas act as Medicare agencies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Some months ago, I announced we were trialling pharmacy claiming agencies for Medicare at five locations around Townsville in the electorate of the honourable member for Capricornia.
—Any in Labor electorates?
—Order! The minister will resume his seat. I invoke standing order 304A in respect of the member for Grayndler. You have been warned repeatedly.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The honourable member for Grayndler thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was reading the BRW Rydges 200.
—I thank the honourable member for Capricornia very much for his support and the feedback that he has been able to give me on this trial.
—He might have found the Laurie Oakes article in there.
—Order! The member for Batman.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: you have just ejected another of our members under standing order 304A in enforcement of these new principles. Immediately after that, the Treasurer interjected. Why will you not eject him under the same principle?

—I thank the honourable member for Hotham. I only caught a portion of the concluding words of the Treasurer. I have issued a general warning, which I will now reiterate. I remind everybody that the standing order is in place and I will move unhesitatingly to protect the reputation of the House.

—We had a few teething problems. They ranged from things such as the phone lines not being of sufficient quality to adequately transmit, to the design of the form and the design of the booth. But the point of the trial was that we were able to sort those out, and we now have the first stage of the evaluation of the trial in these areas.

ANSWER.PARA: The evaluation has been very positive. From the public's point of view, of the people we surveyed, 13 per cent had used the facility in the previous month. Of that 13 per cent, 89 per cent of people said the facility improved their access to Medicare and 87 per cent of people said they would use it again in the future. Overall, the response from pharmacists has been very positive as well.

This now enables us to expand the system. Eventually we will have 400 of these agencies, but over the next week the government will be announcing a further 105 agencies. These agencies have been decided on the basis of four criteria: pharmacies should be in receipt of a rural or isolated pharmacy allowance; the percentage of direct bill claims in the postcode area must be no greater than 75 per cent; the average number of patient claims per day must be sufficiently high to justify the expense; and a Medicare customer service centre must not be located close to the pharmacy. With one exception only, they are the criteria that have been used—the exception being in Forbes, in the electorate of Parkes, to maintain an election commitment.

Payment can be made by cheque or by electronic funds transfer. Over half the people have chosen electronic funds transfer. This, together with greater electronic funds transfer capabilities and electronic lodgment in doctors' surgeries, goes to keeping our commitment to country people that we would increase Medicare access for them. It will do so substantially and it will give country people something that city people take for granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the member for Hotham. Shadow minister, why is it essential that the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 be brought on for debate in this House? What would the consequences for the Australian car industry be if that bill were not given urgent consideration and passage through the parliament?

—Before calling the honourable member for Hotham, I remind the honourable member of the tightness of the standing orders that apply to this question. I am sure you will give due regard to those standing orders before you respond, and I shall be listening very carefully.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is essential that this bill be brought on because it is the only proposal that guarantees to increase jobs in the car industry—not just to protect the existing jobs, but to actually increase them. There is no other proposal about that suggests an increase in jobs. Indeed, the Productivity Commission's hidden report has now dropped off employment forecasts, as I understand it, from its proposals.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason this bill will create jobs is that we have had an agreement with the car industry that, if Labor's plan for the car industry to freeze tariffs at 15 per cent, to continue the export facilitation scheme and to do a number of other things contained in that plan—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want you to canvass the debate. Do not foreshadow the debate.

—If Labor's plan is implemented, it will create 10,000 new jobs, it will see a tripling of component exports in this country to $3 billion and it will see the doubling of car exports from this country to $3 billion. It is the proposal backed by the Victorian, South Australian and New South Wales governments. It also is now backed by the members for Kingston and Hindmarsh. It is the proposal that the Prime Minister should support, and it is the one that should be brought on for debate in this House so we can also get it into the Senate and pass some sensible industry policy for the first time in their period of 14 months.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the government's response to the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee's report on its inquiry into consular services? What has the government done to improve consular operations in the department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and particularly recognise the interest that the honourable member has in the consular operations of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The government gives a very high priority to the consular work of my department and, since the election, we have instituted a series of reforms that I think have very substantially improved the performance of the department in that area.

ANSWER.PARA: First of all, we have established a consular response group. That is giving a specific focus to the care of families of those in crisis, such as in the Fraser hostage case in Somalia. Secondly, we have substantially upgraded the honorary consul system and our intention is to upgrade it still further. Thirdly, I have established a consular information unit in Canberra to provide relevant information to Australian travellers going overseas, and I am about to establish a 24-hour consular duty officer arrangement which will be available to callers in emergency situations overseas. Fourthly, the consular branch of my department is preparing guidelines for staff on handling the victims of sexual assaults overseas and, on my instructions, a diplomatic campaign has been carried out to encourage countries to accede to the Hague Convention on Child Abduction Issues.

As the honourable member suggested in his question, my attention has been drawn to a Senate committee report and to those aspects of the report which were unanimously endorsed by members of the committee. Of course, the committee is one which has a majority of Labor members on it. I notice in particular though that, despite the Labor majority on the committee—the usual practice is that where there is a Labor majority they defend their own kind—this committee was prepared to be critical of the performance of the previous government and obviously, by implication, the now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, part of the old guard. For example, the committee did raise serious questions about the way the previous government acted in the treatment of the families of those in consular difficulties, and the report found that inadequate attention had been given to the families of victims. I point out to the House that that has now been rectified.

There was also criticism of the previous government over the handling of the Wilson case, in particular in the context of the so-called `no comment' policy. The Labor members of the committee, along with others, thought the policy pursued by the previous foreign minister, the now member for Holt, was a mistaken policy. Thirdly, I draw the House's attention to the fact that the Labor members of that committee and others were critical of the way the member for Holt had handled the very difficult case of Dr John Flynn, who was incarcerated in India. The committee, frankly, made it perfectly clear that not enough was done for Dr Flynn.

I tell the House these things because, in my portfolio, significant priority must be given to consular cases. The Australian government does have a responsibility to do all it can within its powers for Australians in distress overseas. That was not the practice of the previous government, as Labor members of the Senate have made perfectly clear. Mr Speaker, as you can see from the reforms I have already made, that is the practice of this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Regardless of the ceremonial arrangements on 1 July, do you agree that it would be inappropriate for you as Australia's representative to be present at the swearing in of Beijing's hand-picked legislature for the Hong Kong SAR, the body which will replace Hong Kong's democratically elected legislative council?

—I must say it comes as some surprise to me that the member for Kingsford-Smith would ask a question about human rights and the protection of democracy because, after all, his record when it comes to democracy is not a very good one, by all accounts. The Blaxland preselection! The motorbike off into the night!
—The minister is digressing far from the question.
—Democracy ALP style! So there he was, once very unconcerned about democracy, according to all accounts rigging the rules, and suddenly he becomes the champion of human rights and democracy.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. You clearly directed him to not digress. He has ignored that ruling and I would ask you to insist upon him answering the question.
—I thank the honourable member for Hotham. I uphold the point of order. Minister, you were digressing—
—Mr Speaker, on a further of point of order. This is a serious question. It deserves a serious answer.
—There is no point of order. The minister will take heed of my remarks.
—My point is, of course, that the member for Kingsford-Smith is not serious about these issues and never has been. His record proves the point.
—Order! The minister will—

—As far as the handover ceremony is concerned, once we have been given information on the details of what is proposed—they are not yet finalised—clearly we will be prepared to talk about what aspects of the invitation the government will participate in and how the Australian government will respond to the invitation. The fact is, as I have made perfectly clear and as I think has been made clear by my spokesman on several occasions, the details of these arrangements have to be finalised and I am not going to start canvassing hypothetical propositions.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is the minister aware of recently publicised alternatives to this government's education policy? Does the minister have any information on the impact such alternative prescriptions would have on regional Australia's schools and education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Murray for her question, and I understand her concerns. The government supports quality education for all children and it supports the right of parents to choose the school which best suits their child and which expresses their values. Regrettably, this is in stark contrast to the policies which the Labor Party continues to peddle.

ANSWER.PARA: Last night in a personal explanation, the member for Werriwa actually told this House that the Labor Party policy which he had announced would lead to more schools opening, not schools closing. It is a great shame that he has no shame when it comes to distorting the facts. He seems to have conveniently forgotten the words of his own policy, which I shall read to the Leader of the Opposition, who is rightly looking concerned about it. When you have a look at what the Labor Party, through the member for Werriwa, has said its policy is, the words are as follows:
The ALP maintains a minimum enrolment benchmark of 50 students.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we did in government.
—There is a difference between being in government and being in opposition which I thought you might have caught up with by now. These words have a particular implication. Listen to them. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: This represents not only effective economy of scale in school administration but also a useful threshold of popular support and commitment to the representative features of neighbourhood schooling.

This useful threshold is a useful threshold to deny Commonwealth funding. What is quite clear is that the member for Werriwa believes that Commonwealth funding should not be provided on a count of schools with less than 50 students because they do not have community support, and this is an economy of scale in school administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—Has the minister concluded his remarks?
—No, I have not.
—Well he should have. My point of order is how can it be relevant to the minister's—
—What is your point of order?
—Under standing order 145, how can it be relevant—
—This is not a point of order.
—. . . to the minister's responsibility—
—Resume your seat.
—. . . to be dealing with a matter that is a total fabrication?
—Resume your seat.
—It was standing order 145.
—Then he can address the point of order in a much more definable way.

—What the member for Werriwa is clearly saying on behalf of the Labor Party is that Commonwealth funding will not flow to schools which do not have at least 50 students. The only exception to that is that he said there will be a limit of 20 students in rural and remote areas.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FITZGIBBON

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. In an earlier occasion in this place when the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy—

INTERJECT.PARA: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, on my right! Address your point of order!
—. . . selectively read from a newspaper column I wrote, the member for Canberra asked you whether it was appropriate for ministers to selectively read and therefore to misconstrue facts.
—There is no point of order. Resume your seat.
—Mr Speaker, you have—
—Resume your seat. Minister.

—The member for Werriwa went on to say in his statement of Labor Party policy that the minimum enrolment benchmark of 50 students applies to primary schools. There are well over 300 primary schools across Australia—government and non‐government—which do not meet this enrolment benchmark of 50 students. Most of these schools are in regional areas. Indeed, the policy would have a devastating effect on schools in many regional areas.

BREAK.PARA: In Ballarat there are 18 such schools. In Bendigo there are 14 such schools. In Gippsland there are 22 such schools. In the member for Murray's electorate there are 19 schools: Ballendella Primary, Bunbartha Primary, Colbinabbin Primary, Dhurringile Primary, Echuca West Primary, Harston Primary, Katunga South Primary, Lake Charm Primary, Lalbert Primary, Mooroopna North Primary, Murrabit Group Primary, Nanneella Estate Primary, St Patrick's School, Tatura East Primary, Tragowel Plains Primary, Undera Primary, Waaia Yalca South Primary, Wunghnu Primary and Zeerust Primary. Nineteen schools fall below the Labor Party's minimum enrolment benchmark.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is this relevant?
—It is germane to the question.

—The fact is that the Labor Party cannot be trusted when it comes to education. It has no understanding of the needs of small communities in Australia and the right to have their schools. The fact is that the member for Werriwa believes that schools with less than 50 students do not have community support and should not be funded. Such a policy can lead only to the closing of schools, not their opening. The member for Werriwa should make that clear.
—A point of order!
—Has the minister concluded his remarks?
—Yes.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I re-read your remarks of last week about questions and answers. I suggest you do the same.
—Resume your seat.
—You brought the Minister for Foreign Affairs to order. He will—
—Resume your seat.
—Mr Speaker—
—Resume your seat!
—A further point of order!
—The member for Newcastle on a further point of order.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a further point of order. No-one in this House could know the mind of anybody else. For you as Speaker—
—Resume your seat.
—If you want us to respect your rulings—
—I invoke 3O4A in respect of the member for Newcastle—
—I think you should. Hear, hear!
—Remove yourself from the chamber forthwith.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The honourable member for Newcastle thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker!
—The Minister has concluded his remarks. I am about to go on to the next question.
—Indeed he has. Mr Speaker, the minister was clearly quoting from two documents extensively. I request that they be tabled.
—Was the minister reading from documents?
—Yes.
—Were those documents confidential?
—Yes.
—They are confidential.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Why has the government forced cuts of 1,900 student places and $14.4 million from the University of New South Wales and forced the closure of the St George campus, the only university facility in southern Sydney near where the Prime Minister grew up, a decision described by Liberal Senator John Tierney as `an act of modern day piracy'? Will the government at least support endeavours by the New South Wales government to transfer the campus to the University of Wollongong and now offer transitional funding and student places for that purpose?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding of the situation is that the decision to close the campus was taken by the governing authority of the University of New South Wales. There is a clear policy of granting greater autonomy to universities. That is a policy of the government; a very clear policy. The decision was taken by the ruling authority of the University of New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: The government laid down a program of reforms for the higher education sector last year. I want to congratulate the minister for the courage that she displayed in implementing those policies. Those policies over time will work to the greater benefit of the university sector of Australia. I believe that those policies will provide greater opportunities for Australian students. Those policies will relieve the heavy burden carried by the working people of Australia for the education of people from middle and upper income families.

It passes very strange to me that representatives of the Australian Labor Party would continue to espouse an approach to higher education which imposed heavy burdens on low income earners in Australia. The HECS reforms, although unpopular with some sections of the higher education fraternity and unpopular with some sections of the student body in terms of social justice and social equity, are reforms that are eminently defensible. I believe they are an integral part of a program of change in the higher education sector that over years will be seen not only as correct but also as extremely courageous reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. In recent weeks a scare campaign has been mounted by various groups to justify their opposition to the government's proposal to exempt small business from the unfair dismissal provisions. What is the minister's response to these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. He is quite right; though, mind you, the mounting of that scare campaign is from a fairly limited base within the treacherous front ranks of the Labor opposition. It is incredible for them to mount an attack on the reforms that we have proposed with respect to unfair dismissal.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the problems that we have had with the unfair dismissal scheme were the creation of the Labor government when they were in office. We have gone a long way to fixing these problems. We have significantly changed the system. We have wiped away the previous minister's reliance on the international convention, we were opposed by the Labor opposition in the Senate all through the reform process on unfair dismissals and now, in this further element of change, we find them attempting to run a scare campaign against it.

We have had five questions from the opposition to the Prime Minister in the last week on the question of the operation of the unfair dismissal scheme and the proposals which we have mooted. It is instructive to look back at those five examples. The first three were presented to the Prime Minister on 29 May. In a very open way, he said, `If you could give me the details, I would be happy to give you a response in respect of those individual cases.' My office rang the office of the shadow minister and sought the details. We have had no response to our request for the details. We now know why—because then they actually nominated a specific case.

I took advice from my department. My department provided advice in respect of this statement from the shadow minister, `The employee in question was sacked for failing to implement an instruction to dismiss another employee simply because she was pregnant.' I am advised by my department that that statement is an incorrect statement of the facts of the case. I am not surprised by that because yesterday we had another case, and this time they gave us the details again. This is the case of Schafer and Coliero. The shadow minister did not tell us that this was a case brought under the old rules—under the Brereton legislation, but leave that aside. What is more important is that he did not say that, in the event of small business being exempted from the provisions, it would still be open on the facts of this case for the complainant in that case to pursue her claim that she was dismissed because of her age.

The thing they do not want you to know is that, whilst we would remove the unfair dismissal provisions, they are only part of the protections available under the workplace relations act. There is a raft of other protections available for people, which is why we say it is a fair scheme. Yet you misrepresented the facts of this case in the question that you asked.

If you look at the act, we have protections. For example, section 170CK of the workplace relations act prohibits employers—small, medium or large, regardless of the circumstances, regardless of whether they have 15 or less employees or otherwise and regardless of whether it is in the first 12 months or not—from sacking employees on the grounds of race, colour, sex, sexual preference, age, physical or mental disability, marital status, family responsibilities, pregnancy, religion, political opinion, national extraction or social origin. Those are only some of the protections; I would be happy to make the balance available to the shadow minister.

This is a useful and sensible change in conformity with the international convention and in conformity with the practice of a number of other countries in the OECD. We have done a lot to fix up the unfair dismissal provisions. We have seen a 50 per cent reduction in the unfair dismissal applications in the federal system. We have seen a bit of a pick up in the state system, but that was the design of our system. It was not the state systems that were the problem; it was the federal system put in place by the previous Labor administration. I say to the opposition: if you want to have a debate about it, let's get the facts straight for starters.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that his government's announced closure and sale of RAAF Richmond, contained in the defence efficiency review, is estimated to cost more than 3,000 jobs directly? That is more than 20 per cent of all jobs in the Hawkesbury and some $2 million per week out of the income of the region. Does the Prime Minister agree with his government's Chief Whip, the member for Mitchell, when he said, `It would be a criminal thing for Richmond to lose the RAAF base'? Will the Prime Minister now give an undertaking to the people of the Hawkesbury that his government will not close and sell RAAF Richmond?

—I am glad to have the opportunity to answer that question because there has been a lot of misinformation put about, just like the question itself. The fact is that there has been no evaluation of a number of these properties. There are several lists, some of which will be evaluated in the next five years. Some will be evaluated from 2001 to 2005. When that evaluation takes place, there will be a recommendation. The evaluation of defence properties will go on, just as they went on under Labor and just as 79 properties were sold for $180 million in the last five years.
—You budgeted for it.
—We have not budgeted for it. You are wrong. So that answers the question. You are wrong.
—So are you saying that it is not going to happen then?
—Order! We are not going to debate the issue.

—There is an amount of money which will be realised over a vast number of properties, just as you did in the last five years. The misinformation that is put out in the question is quite erroneous and should not be allowed. The fact is that these properties will be evaluated for their usefulness, as you would expect all responsible governments to do. What is more, all of them will be evaluated, if finally evaluated for sale, after in‐depth community consultation. As was the practice in the past, it will be the practice in the future.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, could you please advise the House of the importance of consistency in the development of government programs? As the government continues to meet promises made whilst in opposition, what advice can you offer to those interested in policies for the future?
—Mr Speaker, I can inform the—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The whole question asked the Prime Minister for an opinion and is therefore out of order under standing order 144.
—I uphold the point of order.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order: I did not ask the Prime Minister for an opinion. I asked him for some advice and that is not necessarily an opinion. I in fact asked on two occasions for advice—
—There is no point of order. I have ruled on the matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, did you recently confirm that antibiotics are used in the production of poultry overseas and that these antibiotics can cause, through food consumption, resistance to be transferred from animals to humans? If so, Minister, now that chicken importation has become a human health issue as well as a local jobs issue, why won't you say no to chicken meat imports from Thailand, Denmark and the United States?

—The short and simple answer is that we will take the advice of the scientists in the same way that when you were in government you insisted we ought to here and in international forums when under the relevant minister at the time you led the charge for the very arrangements that we are now committed to. The government will, in due course, take the advice of the scientists. I assume you would have it no other way.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister observed criticisms of the government's industry policy? Has he observed whether there has been any inconsistency in our industry policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the question is yes, I have. The answer to the second part of the question of course relates to the issue of inconsistency. I have to say that one of the things of which I am proud is that this government has implemented so many of the things that we promised the Australian people before the last election that we would do. One of the many things that you can say about this government is that we do not say one thing in opposition and a completely different thing in government—unlike those who sit opposite. Let me give some examples.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition has led the inconsistency stakes in recent weeks. For example, the Leader of the Opposition said in government that Australia needed to continue the process of economic reform; now he advocates policies of the past. The Leader of the Opposition said in government that privatisation was consistent with job creation; now he says it is not. He said in government that cutting the budget deficit would lower interest rates; now he denies there is a connection. He said in government that reducing the budget deficit would boost jobs growth; now he tells us the opposite. He said in government that industrial relations reform was important for job creation; now he refuses to acknowledge a link. He argued in government, almost alone—with one or two other ministers—for the introduction of a consumption tax; now he opposes any sensible debate on tax reform.

You argued in government that higher education should not be exempt from budget cutbacks; now you argue completely differently. You said in government that the Commonwealth should fight compensation claims of separated indigenous children; now you demand the opposite. You said in government that pastoralists' land was secure; now you refuse to grant that security.

Whether it is economic reform, tariffs, privatisation, deficits, industrial relations, tax, education, compensation or pastoral leases, the Leader of the Opposition has said one thing in government and said a completely opposite thing in opposition. The truth is that Beazley's light on the hill is five valleys behind him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister advise this House whether he is the same person who, before the last election, promised to maintain the system of child-care assistance but has cut almost $500 million from it; maintain Medicare in its entirety and maintain funding for public hospitals but has begun to dismantle Medicare and has cut $800 million from public hospital funding; maintain Labor's level of spending on Austudy but will cut $527 million from it; maintain the Labor Party's policy in relation to HECS but has eliminated that; maintain existing levels of funding for the ABC but has decided to cut $209 million from the ABC over four years; maintain our co-payment on superannuation but has abandoned that within this budget? Prime Minister, I could go on but isn't it just the case that you are suffering from chronic inconsistency syndrome, or is it some other condition that you are inflicting on Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am the same person who, before the election, promised that there would be a family tax initiative worth a billion dollars and have delivered on time and in full. I am the same person who, before the election, promised industrial relations reform and have delivered it.
—Keep going.

—It gets even better. I am the same person who promised some modest capital gains tax relief for small business but has massively overdelivered on that promise. I am the same person who, before the last election, promised that there would be tax incentives for private health insurance, and I have delivered on that. I am the same person who promised that we would maintain Medicare, and I have delivered on that. I am the same person who was honest enough to promise that I would sell one-third of Telstra, and I have delivered on that, whereas the bloke who asked me the question really had a secret plan to sell not one-third of it but the whole lot following his performance in relation to the sale of the Commonwealth Bank.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, I am the one and the same person who was able to look the Australian people in the eye and make these commitments, and I am the one and the same person who has overdelivered in many areas. We have seen a reduction in interest rates far below the commitments that we have made in that area.

I am also the one and the same person who, along with the Treasurer, inherited a budget deficit of $10.5 billion after having been told by the man who asked me the question that the budget was in surplus. Never let it be forgotten that the bloke who asked me this question was the fellow who ran around Australia during the election campaign, along with Paul Keating, saying the budget is in surplus.

BREAK.PARA: I am certainly the one and the same person who has delivered on those commitments—in many areas, overdelivered—and I am very proud of the record of this government and, what is more, we have demonstrated a consistency. I say to the Leader of the Opposition: over the last few days you have demonstrated a chronic inconsistency, and it is a very big telltale sign of the rumbling and the treachery about which you were so defiantly eloquent yourself.
Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to add to my answer to ensure the record is correct.
—The minister may proceed.
—Part of my statement should read, `In both budgets the allocation exceeded $1.198 billion spent by the previous government in 1995-96.'

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have two questions for you. QUESTION.PARA: Secondly, while the responsible administration is the Department of Communications and the Arts, I understand there are four principal tenants of old Parliament House: the National Museum of Australia, the National Library's National Portrait Gallery, Australian Archives and the National Film and Sound Archive. Would you consider, and report to the parliament in due course, what accommodation the officers and departments of the parliament use outside Parliament House, where they are, the footage that is taken up and the cost of that footage so that all members can look, make a comparison and perhaps make recommendations so that you might take up some of the space now required within old Parliament House and bring it back within the purview of the parliament itself?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the right honourable member for New England. You are raising an issue which is very dear to the hearts of many of us. The President and I have actually had some preliminary discus sions with Senator Alston about the future of Parliament House. Your encouragement to take the issue up with the Prime Minister is very good and I react enthusiastically to it. —In question time today, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp), by selectively and misleadingly quoting from a policy discussion paper which I released, sought to portray me as condemning the former government's record in the education and training area.
