INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — I have received a letter from the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the government to protect manufacturing jobs particularly in regional Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The report today in the Australian says it all in terms of the government's decision on car tariffs in this country. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) has won over that pathetic Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) and has got his own option up. The Treasurer of the nation, the pretender to the throne, went on TV last night to take on the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) because the member for Flinders and Leader of the House (Mr Reith), who has just slurried out the door, got a favourable report last Sunday, and following that appearance the Leader of the House had to come in today to try to toughen up his credentials. Pretender he may be, but this proposal from the Treasurer will sell out Australian car workers, it will sell out the regions and it will be the forerunner for what happens in the textile, clothing and footwear industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Where in all of this exercise is the Prime Minister? The Prime Minister is in hiding, collecting the passports, the tickets and the entry passes to the members stand at Lords—lunch at Lords. The Prime Minister said five weeks ago on the Ray Martin program—he who must be obeyed—`I am going to Newcastle soon', and still he has not turned up. The Prime Minister loves going to Hawks Nest as his retreat. Why can't he make a little diversion to that smoke‐stack city that is reeling because of the government's inaction.

What we have is a Prime Minister who has hidden from the union movement bringing a submission to him today to support the car industry, just as he was hiding yesterday from a delegation from Geelong, until the urgings and pressure from the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) shamed him into meeting with them. This is the person who wants to express concern for the battlers of Australia but will not lift a finger to help them.
And what have we got? Who is in control? The Treasurer, the pretender to the throne, the hyena from Higgins, the sneer from ear to ear, the person who is all over the Prime Minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Hotham should withdraw that description of the member for Higgins.
—Which one?
—The hyena from Higgins.

—I withdraw. The person who is over the Prime Minister like the loaded dog, all over him, slavering at the mouth, running around all over the place causing mayhem. Yesterday, when the national accounts figures came out showing the manufacturing sector of this nation in recession, the Treasurer came out and said, `These are where we want the numbers to be.' I almost heard the former Treasurer say `the beautiful set of numbers'. Next we will hear that they are bringing home the bacon. This Treasurer goes home at night and watches replays of the former Treasurer performing his act in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is, this is the Treasurer who is running government policy, that is the person who again has rolled the industry minister, and the Prime Minister tries to come forward and say, `This proposal for a 10 per cent tariff, not 15 per cent, is a compromise.' The wisdom of Solomon! You do not go for five per cent, you do not go for 15 per cent; you go for 10 per cent. Presumably the principle is that by going for the compromise you only lose half of the jobs in the car industry: the jobs of the 47,000 people who depend on this industry directly and the 300,000 who depend on it indirectly; not just the four companies—Ford, Toyota, Mitsubishi and Holden—but the 200 component plants around the country which have gone into export markets because of Labor's car plan and have created thousands of jobs in the industry.

I have been today to a rally in Albury, the electorate of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer). Where was he? He was in hiding too, overseas, selling out car workers in this country. That is what he was doing, and he should have been at the rally.

The fact of the matter is, this government has no industry policy and it has no commitment or strategy to getting manufacturing jobs up in this country. Quite frankly, to come into this place and say that all the jobs are going to come from services is absolute nonsense unless you have a manufacturing sector. It is true that there will be enormous job growth coming off the services sector, but what do you service if you have not got a manufacturing base? A country without a manufacturing base is a country without a heart, it is a country without a direction and it is a country without a future. That is why this government needs to support the manufacturing sector.

The government has presided now for 14 months. We just heard the Prime Minister trying to tell us how we had not broken any promises. Look at the programs he has slashed in the manufacturing sector. Of the last four quarters of the national accounts figures, three of them in the manufacturing sector have been negative. That is some performance, some great contribution to the future of this nation!

What we are told concerning the car industry is that we have a compromise solution, the Costello solution—again, some compromise. We have two options—another day, another option with this government. Every time you read the newspaper there is a new option. You have the Treasurer of the nation leaking to John Short, telling him how tough he is. `I'll give you the story, John, you run it in the Australian'—`Treasurer wins greater tariff cuts' is the end result. The day before it was the industry minister leaking to John Short telling him how he had this great proposal to put forward. I will tell you how good the proposal was. It was contrary to our bindings under APEC and contrary to our obligations under the World Trade Organisation, and he succeeded in being the first minister in this country since Black Jack McEwen to have proposed a tariff increase.
Where is this government coming from, Mr Deputy Speaker? I know from your party, if they were actually putting tariffs up in this country—

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the member for Hotham that the occupant of the chair at the time has no part in it.

—I will point to you over there, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have seen an interesting little press release today from the National Farmers Federation which says, `The 10 per cent cut is not enough and, if you are not going to cut it further, why did you cut our sugar tariffs?' Well they may ask. This government is one that has no consistency and no commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: My challenge and the opposition's challenge to the government today is: if that is your plan, bring it on in the parliament. Make our day. Give us the opportunity to debate this ridiculous proposition. We want to debate it because what will happen under this proposal to cut tariffs to 10 per cent is that investment will dry up, and job and export opportunities will be lost.

Today it was almost a bit of a revelation for the Prime Minister to hear what our car plan is. Our car plan actually creates jobs—you know, on the plus side. I know you have not had too many figures on the plus side; they have all been going into the red as far as manufacturing is concerned. Our car plan actually increases jobs. We have a commitment from the industry that if what we have proposed is put in place—the freeze at 15 per cent; the review, but having regard to what our international trading partners are doing; the retention of an equivalent of the export facilitation scheme; the retention of the duty free allowance; and the restoration of some research and development incentive—there will be 10,000 new jobs, together with a trebling of car component exports to $3 billion and a doubling of car exports also to $3 billion, which means $6 billion of exports.

I might be wrong but I thought this government were saying their prime task was to create jobs and to address the current account. Yet here they are, presented with a plan that does both, and they squib it—they blink and hide. That is the Prime Minister: a pathetic leader. His hand is off the tiller but he is still at the back of the boat with the telescope, looking backwards: back to the GST, back to industrial relations reform and back to high unemployment, stunned that he has not managed to get the double of high inflation too because that is his track record. This is a Prime Minister with no commitment, no vision and no compassion.

Whilst the Prime Minister does not want to live in Canberra, you cannot get him out of Kirribilli. He will not attend anywhere except, of course, Lords. He will go to the opening of a test match. He is the one who has been arguing most passionately for the retention of one person's job only—Mark Taylor's. Why doesn't he go to Newcastle and argue for the 2,500 steel workers? Why doesn't he support Labor's car plan and support the jobs of the 47,000 car workers? Why doesn't he give a signal to the 100,000 textile workers that their futures and their plans will be safe as well?

What we had today was the Prime Minister getting up stunned because of the interpretation of the Costello challenge last night. The dog was all over him; now we have the tail trying to wag that dog. We have this pathetic excuse for a Prime Minister limply coming into this place, trying to sound tough and telling us about all the promises he has honoured, but he will not honour his promise to go to Newcastle. He would not meet a delegation in the parliament today. He did not even have to go to these people—they were prepared to come to him. But he still would not see them. What sort of a person is this?

It is no wonder that you have divisions on your side of the parliament in terms of this car tariff issue. You have the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes) already saying she will cross the floor if the Costello proposal is carried. We have mild indignation from the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), who says she does not support my bill. I think the members at Mitsubishi will be very interested to hear that because the members down there damn well support it. Yet the member for Hindmarsh is quoted as saying she would not rule out crossing the floor. So bring it on and test your strength. It is the same thing with the sugar tariff; you have tried to hide it in regulation so that you will not get a revolt from the National Party. We will use every device possible to make sure this issue of tariffs, and the legislation associated with it, is brought into the House.

This is a government that promised greater accountability and that it would use the forms of the House more openly and have more debate. Where are they? Hiding. Today the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) attempted to have the Aged Care Bill debated, and they gagged that. They have introduced a guillotine. They want to shorten debate on aged care and not even have debate on car care. What a pathetic government this is. Where is the leadership really coming from? Skulking back to the oval office, collecting the passports, collecting the tickets to Lords and picking up his first‐class ticket. Maybe he got it on frequent flyer points, because he likes to be a bit morally superior on these things. But he is not going to Newcastle. He is not going to Geelong. He is not going to Adelaide. He is not going to the regions of this country that depend on the manufacturing industry.

If you do not think the interventionist policies of government work in industry, let me quote you these figures. Between 1980 and 1996 manufacturing employment declined in this country by 120,000. All of that decline occurred from 1980 to 1985, when there were 140,000 jobs lost. They were the legacy of this government's former reign. In the period 1985‐1996, when Labor actually developed industry policy and supported industries, manufacturing employment increased net 10,000, despite the recession of 1990. That is why these policies matter. That is why people are saying to you time and time again, `Get real and get an industry policy.' That is why we are saying to you, `Wake up.' We are prepared to be part of a bipartisan exercise to support you in industry policy. We are prepared to go out and work with industry, and to identify the things that matter to them and that get commitments from them to grow investment, grow jobs and grow exports.

This is not about protection and looking inwards; this is looking outwards. This is about getting us into the export markets where the real opportunities are. But you need government assistance to do that. That is what Labor is committed to and that is what this government refuses to face up to. Worse, where we have industries that have actually succeeded, like the car and the steel industries, the government will not lift a finger. They will not even move their feet. The Prime Minister will not even get on the VIP jet and fly there at short notice. He will not even visit them. The government do not care and they do not deserve to be returned. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last 30 seconds of his speech the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) offered a bipartisan industry approach. It rings hollow; it is utterly untrue. Why did he spend 14½ minutes of his contribution abusing, in the most personal terms, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the Treasurer (Mr Costello), the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore)? Suddenly, he thinks, in the dying seconds of his contribution, he can throw this hypocritical olive branch towards us.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things he did not tell the House was the Labor Party's track record on manufacturing jobs. He did not tell the House that in the automotive industry between 1983 and 1996 the number of jobs fell from 70,000 to 45,000. He did not tell us that in the textile, clothing and footwear industries between 1986 and 1996 the number of jobs fell by a massive 35,000.

There is no doubt that when the honourable member addressed the rally in Albury a short while ago he did not tell them that in the textile, clothing and footwear industries in 1986 there were 130,000 people employed and when they left office 10 years later the figure was down to 95,000—a loss of 35,000 jobs in 10 years. The Labor Party is the party of jobs destruction. It is utterly unconvincing and outright hypocritical for members of the Labor Party to now preach job creation in manufacturing.

With regard to the automotive industry, the honourable member spoke about the Button plan and their plan for the future. Let us look at what happened during their years in office. In 1984, shortly after Labor came to office, car production in Australia stood at around 370,000 units, yet when they left office in 1996 production was just 314,000 units. Nissan had closed down production entirely and Australia had lost the capacity to produce small cars like the Ford Laser. In 1984, import penetration was 20 per cent. In 1996, it had more than doubled to 50 per cent of the market. So the opposition has no credibility. They had their chance in government and they devastated the textile, clothing and footwear industries and the automotive industry.

Now, of course, they want instead to try to resurrect their credentials with the trade union movement, the work force and the general community by pursuing this high tariff policy. Again, they do one thing in government and say another in opposition. For instance, the honourable member for Hotham, who has now left the chamber, said this at the National Press Club on 14 August 1991:

The trade union movement, I must say, took a long time to come to grips with this question, because they saw protection, tariff walls, as somehow protecting jobs, but all it did was to weaken the manufacturing capacity of the country . . .
That is a clear, unequivocal, unambiguous repudiation of a high tariff policy. On the ABC program The World Today , on 28 February 1991, he said:

BREAK.PARA: . . . all that tariffs did was to make us look inward. All that tariffs did was to protect local production.
Again, he was deriding the notion of tariffs being a protector of manufacturing or Australian jobs. On the ABC television program Lateline on 4 February 1992, he said:

Well, I am not a believer in the level playing field, but I am also a believer in the fact that part of the reason that we have got into the industrial mess we have is because we relied too heavily on tariff protection in the past.

That is completely at odds with what he would now have the parliament and the Australian electorate believe. But he is not alone in this regard. Other senior economic ministers, and those who held other portfolios under the Hawke‐Keating governments, are now totally reversing their stance on the issue of tariffs as an input into industry policy, now that they are in opposition. Let us look at what the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) said in a ministerial statement to the Senate on 12 March 1991:
. . . the most powerful spur to greater competitiveness is further tariff reduction.
However much our competitors might bend or break the principles of fair trade, our own self‐interest is served by a steadfast refusal to return to the days of protectionism.
. . . worse still, tariffs are a regressive burden—that is, the poorest Australians are hurt more than the richest.
. . . this Government—
the Hawke government—
deliberately and determinedly set about pulling down the tariff walls.

Yet now we have a succession of opposition spokespeople saying that the solution to loss of Australian jobs or to manufacturing decline is tariff protection. They have no credibility. Their record in government was not to set in place the wider economic settings that truly determine industry policy and upon which manufacturing survives or fails, expands or contracts.

The classic case is that of another former ACTU President, the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) who was interviewed on the ABC radio program AM on Wednesday, 13 March 1991, the day after the then govern ment's 1991 industry statement, and the textile, clothing and footwear unions had alleged that further tariff reforms would lead to job losses. In defence of the government of the day, and endorsing the tariff policy, he said, `It's all about investment in our long‐term future.'

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), a former employment minister and former finance minister, was a great one in the old days—that is, in his government days—for pulling down tariffs. In November 1996, while visiting Indonesia, the Leader of the Opposition said that pursuing APEC's free trade goals was vital to the long‐term economic prosperity of Australia.

Of course he supports the need for Australians to develop market access. True industry policy is based upon investment and all the microeconomic and macroeconomic factors that will determine international investment or the decision to expand investment by domestic companies, innovation and investment in research and development by both the public and private sectors, and also market access overseas.

Of all the cheap and unnecessarily cruel jibes of the member for Hotham, the worst was to accuse the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) of being deliberately absent from a meeting concerned with the textile, clothing and footwear industry in his home town of Albury earlier today. He did himself no credit with that. I would have thought that nobody in this House, no fair‐minded or rational person, would believe that the Deputy Prime Minister is doing anything less than a splendidly successful job promoting Australian interest overseas. He is at the vanguard of tearing down the tariff and non-tariff barriers erected by other economies and countries to block Australian imports. To say that he should have been in Albury when a trip overseas promoting overseas exports had long been in the planning and execution is really below the belt. But it is so self‐evident it is not worth dwelling on.

We have to remember that the Labor Party, as represented by the member for Hotham today, brought about the highest unemployment rates in decades. In 1992 the unemploy ment rate hit 11 per cent, and youth unemployment was a record 34 per cent. Even so, we on this side of the House would show some understanding and tolerance of the Labor Party in opposition if it put its views sensibly, calmly, rationally and consistently. But on none of those criteria does the Labor Party succeed. Every day you will get a different statement or a different perspective on industry policy and economic policy more generally.

We know from the published paper of the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) what he thinks about the member for Hotham in his role as shadow minister for industry and also about the member for Holt, as shadow Treasurer. The rhetoric of the Labor Party simply does not live up to its track record and its actions when it was in government. The truth is that Labor's policy has been the cause of unemployment, which this government is tackling with such resolve and determination, particularly in regional areas.

We need a sensible debate on industry policy. Today's MPI just heightens the difference between the government and the opposition on this vital issue of public administration. Their industry policy in 13 years of government is best characterised as a mates policy. They had a small number of sectoral policies covering a small number of industries. They generally ignored the rest of the economy. They did not tackle industrial relations reform, despite the pleadings of industry. Nor did they tackle waterfront reform, tax reform—except to increase it continually—or the budget deficit, which has the effect of pushing up interest rates.

Why should the Australian people take this discredited former government, and increasingly discredited opposition, seriously? We, instead, are getting on with the job. We have turned around the $10½ billion deficit that we inherited on coming to government to a surplus of $1.6 billion next year. A down‐payment on that mammoth, herculean task is already available to Australians with a three per cent fall in official interest rates. That is going to be a stimulus to not just the housing and construction markets but industry more generally.

We have locked in low inflation. We have brought about a substantially more flexible and responsive labour market. On top of that, we have introduced a great many regional policies for country areas. Despite the MPI today being phrased in terms of job losses in country areas, did we hear a word about it from the member for Hotham? Of course not! It is extraordinary. His idea of a regional centre, at the very best, is Geelong or Newcastle. Of course they are regional centres, but another 20 per cent of the Australian population lives in country and rural areas. There was not a word from them.

The government has published its Regional Australia: leading the way policy following the budget. It is a collection of all of the initiatives of the government and the respective funding for regional and rural Australia. It is a very impressive document. Work for the dole, Green Corps, the National Heritage Trust and the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund are skewed towards country and regional Australia. The funding is some $4 billion. Whether it be on health policy or road funding, this government is providing for country and regional Australia, thereby leading to a creation of jobs.

But there was not a word from the member for Hotham because he in opposition is just reflecting the mind set of the Labor Party in government, that is, government policy, industry policy and job creation stop on the outskirts of the metropolitan areas. Instead, we see the prosperity of regional and country Australia depending on not just the general economic settings that the government is putting in place but also specific initiatives. Those initiatives are available for all to see in this publication.

Let us see the Labor Party put together a regional Australia publication which puts together their initiatives. Especially, I would like to see whether they were fully costed. On the one hand they talk about a balanced budget and, on the other, the need to spend money. We never see the two balanced, let alone come into some sort of sensible equation.

The government's industry policy is something which will put in place a sustainable long-term job creation result. Only by having in place the different aspects of industry policy and economic reform will you bring about true job creation. It is not enough to make noise about sectorial plans, whether it be in regard to car manufacturing or textiles, clothing and footwear. You actually have to put in place genuine sustainable programs.

For instance, with the steel plan you speak of, you keep harking back to the Button plan. When are you going to tell us where one cent of the Button steel plan was paid to Newcastle BHP for steel production? Not one cent of the Button steel plan was paid to BHP Newcastle for the production of steel there. What they needed was investment in new technology to make sure the plant was viable for years to come. Yet your policies failed to ensure that that would happen. Despite the carping, the rhetoric, the exaggerations and the fearmongering of the member for Hotham, this MPI is utterly discredited.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —After only 16 months in office, we now have a failed government. We have a failed Prime Minister (Mr Howard), a failed Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) and now a failed Treasurer (Mr Costello). There is an old adage in politics: never return to the scene of the crime. Yet here we have a Prime Minister who, after only 16 months in office, is returning to the scene of the crime. The crime was the economic mess that he left the Australian nation in in 1983. He left the Labor Party a legacy of high unemployment and high inflation but, more than anything else, the criminal neglect of the Australian economy was evidenced by the fact that he left an Australian economy that was in a state of negative growth.

SPEECH.PARA: What have we here in the national accounts figures that have been presented to the Australian people over the last couple of days? We have a manufacturing sector in this country that has entered a technical recession—minus 2.2 per cent in two successive quarters. The crowning achievement of the Prime Minister of this country is the potential decimation of the manufacturing industry in this country. The Prime Minister made this particular commitment on economic growth to the Australian people:
This is a government that welcomes growth, and I have to tell you to expect more of it. Expect more growth under the Australian economy by the time we take all the measures Labor failed to take.

You have had two budgets to put in place those measures that are going to engineer at least the same level of economic growth that Labor left you with when it left office in 1996. What have you achieved? We left you with a growth rate of 4.9 per cent and you have now delivered a decrease in economic growth to 2.4 per cent. Is that your crowning achievement?

The absolute economic illiteracy of the government is evidenced by the fact that the Treasurer comes into this House day after day and tries to tell the Australian people that the legacy of Labor was a legacy of economic neglect. He must be the only Treasurer in the Western world who can categorise a four per cent growth rate over four successive years as economic neglect but, as we see in the national accounts figures, this government has failed on economic growth and it has failed on job growth as well.

The Prime Minister promised jobs to regional areas when he came to power in 1996. That is the subject of this discussion in the House. What has he delivered to the regions of this nation? Along with the metropolitan areas, he has delivered a program of job losses and a program of declining economic growth. When he came to power, the Prime Minister promised the Australian people that he would deliver 200,000 new manufacturing jobs. There is absolutely no hope that the Prime Minister or the Treasurer can deliver on that particular promise.

He promised the Australian people and the people in regional areas that he would reduce the unemployment rate when he came to power. What has he done? He has driven it forever upwards, and the people who are paying the price of the policies of this Prime Minister and this Treasurer are the people in regional areas and the people across the length and breadth of the rural areas of this particular nation.

BREAK.PARA: The Prime Minister is leaving the country soon, as the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) pointed out. He is going to Lords to see the cricket. He cannot make it to Newcastle to see workers who are going to lose their jobs by the thousands, but he can go to Lords to see the cricket. The problem is that the workers in Newcastle who are going to lose their jobs cannot even see the cricket that the Prime Minister is going to Lords to see because, when they turn on their TV sets tonight to see the first session at Lords, they will not be able to see it because the Prime Minister has broken another promise.

The Prime Minister said on the Sunday program in February that he was going to change the law so that Australian workers could watch the cricket. He has not done that. Tonight, as Newcastle workers look down the barrel of losing their jobs, as Geelong workers look down the barrel of losing their jobs in the car industry, as the textile, clothing and footwear workers in Geelong and across the length and breadth of this nation look down the barrel of losing their jobs and as they cannot see the cricket tonight, the Prime Minister will be away over there watching the cricket that they cannot watch.

There are very good reasons why this situation of low growth, rising unemployment and a technical recession in the manufacturing sector has occurred. It is obvious to all in this nation that this government lacks an industry policy. Businesses have been saying it for months. The only persons who are not hearing the message are the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and, of course, the industry minister.

We have seen inaction on the steel industry and now we see a paralysis occurring in the major regions of this nation because of the incapacity of this government to reach a decision on car industry tariffs. But, more than anything else, it is the industry minister, the minister who should have been sacked according to the Prime Minister's own ministerial code of conduct, who has dragged down the confidence of the manufacturing industry in this country in its own future.
The government has introduced two deflationary budgets that have really sucked the confidence out of regional areas. It has withdrawn support for regional areas in a raft of industry programs.

If you go and talk to the manufacturers in regional areas, they are saying that this is a dumb government without an industry policy, that this is a rudderless government with a Prime Minister paralysed and incapable of making the key decisions that are necessary for it to have confidence in its future, to invest and to create more jobs.

There is a very good reason why the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) is in here today. He is safe in here; he is not safe in Geelong. There is a very good reason why he will hang around here today, tomorrow and on the weekend and we will not see him front one of the great manufacturing regions of this nation—because Geelong's Judas, for 30 pieces of silver, has sold out the car industry work force in Geelong.

There is a very good reason why the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes) is not in the House. I happened to be walking down the corridors earlier today, and there was the member for Kingston with her suitcase scurrying out of Parliament House. Somebody must have delivered the message that the member for Hotham's private member's bill—a bill that is going to protect car industry jobs—was going to be put on the table in this House.

I said to her, `You're leaving early, Susan'—through you, Mr Deputy Speaker; she is the honourable member for Kingston—and she said, `Yes, I've got to get back to South Australia. I have been paired.' Too right she had been paired. She knew what was coming down the barrel here today on the floor of this House—that is, critical debate on the car industry. She has said that she is going to cross the floor. We will see the colour of her money if you bring the debate on.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I just want to inform the House that the member in question has had a threat to her family and her home. She had to leave for that reason. Her home is under the guard of the Federal Police.

—I thank the honourable member for relaying that information to me here on the floor of the House. Let me say that we will test the honourable member for Kingston. If you bring on the bill, we will test her statement in the South Australian press that she will cross the floor on this vote. She said she will cross the floor on the vote, but we will see where she stands and where the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) stands on this important issue.

BREAK.PARA: The car industry workers in South Australia are bleeding. The families of the car industry workers in South Australia are bleeding, as they anticipate the decision of this government on their future. The car industry workers in Geelong are also bleeding. There is no monopoly on sentiment as far as this issue is concerned on the floor of this House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) has just been given 10 minutes by his own colleagues to speak on behalf of his constituents in Geelong. Throughout the 10 minutes, he never put one practical proposition to this House on how the car industry might grow.
—The bill is on the table.

—No, he did not speak to the bill. He only mentioned the bill. Check the record. Let me quote something that was said by the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) in his address to this House. He said, `Our car plan actually increases jobs.' Let me say that it is a pity he did not try that policy during the 13 years that Labor was in government.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a document here that was delivered to me yesterday by the delegation from Geelong, whom I gave my time to very honestly. It is signed at the back by the Mayor of Geelong and the Vice-Chancellor of Deakin University. I think it is a pretty authentic document. What does it tell me on page 5? It tells me that:

Between 1990 and 1996 unemployment in Geelong soared from 4.5% to nearly 11.0%. In 1990 it was 2% cent below the national average but today it is 2% above. Restructuring in the automotive industry caused over 7,000 jobs to be lost.

Now, tell me who was in government between 1990 and 1996. Not us. We were in govern ment for only a month or so of that period. It was the Labor Party in government for all that time. That quote was not my words. Here is the document, and it will be quoted from. It tells us what your car plan did to jobs down there. God save us from your car plans. That is what I say.

We heard a lot of talk about Newcastle. What is Labor's solution for Newcastle? Send the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) up there to have a chat. What is that going to achieve? The achievement we are planning for Newcastle is to find solutions for their inherent problem. Their problem has a lot more to it than the profitability of BHP. It has a lot to do with the fact that the new fundamentals of the steel industry are not coal and iron ore. The fundamentals are gas and iron ore, and they happen to be available side by side in Western Australia, so other interests in my electorate are going to spend $1.6 billion on a new steel industry.

What are the solutions for Newcastle? Maybe it is to involve them in this $25 billion offshore gas and energy development. What is needed for that? For a start, as the press informed us yesterday, they need to be able to overcome native title problems and environmental problems. Where does the present opposition stand on that? They do not want to fix the environmental problems or the native title problems which just might create those jobs, which just might make Newcastle's facilities suitable for the manufacturing of all those offshore units for which a lot of the facilities and a huge quantity of expertise exist now.

No, Labor will go on demanding that a major company in Australia goes broke by being kept open. Who will that help? Nobody. That shows no sense whatsoever. That is the sort of thing we get from the Labor Party.

Let me go on, because there are solutions for the industry. What was Labor's approach in government? They knew what the trifecta for industry policy was: it was reform of the tariff system, it was reform of the tax system and it was reform of the labour market. That is the trifecta. You cannot operate with only one. But of course the ACTU knocked the Labor Party out on tax reform. They tried that, but the then Prime Minister and Bill Kelty had a meeting in a grubby little motel room and that went out the window.

Then, of course, you never even dared mention labour market reform. What was the result? You were left with the blunt instrument of tariff reform. You used it and you created a situation where employers had only one choice. They moved offshore to where the tax regime and the employment arrangements were much more attractive and they exported back into Australia where you had lowered the tariffs to a point where they could have access.

What do we find today? You go into K-Mart and see all those `great Australian' brands. They still have the brand name, but what does the little ticket that goes at the back of your neck tell you? `Made in China'. Of course, now we have a situation where you could not walk away from that if you wanted to because it has had a substantial effect on the cost of living in Australia. As much as a lot of people would like to see our industries protected, they do not want to pay any more for the things they buy at K-Mart. They are not too happy about paying much more for a motor car either.

But don't take my word for it. The member for Corio does not hang around to get some advice as to how he might practically and positively help his people. He is much more interested in criticising the government. He is much more interested in trying to build up the electoral prospects of his party.

Those opposite do not want to talk about fixing the native title situation so that $11.6 billion of steel consuming and vehicle consuming industries come on in Australia. That is what is held up by the current arrangements in the native title situation. I gave ground on my preferred philosophical position, recognising the national interest, and you cannot do it yet. Let us read what the Bulletin told us on 3 May.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what Laurie Oakes had to say today.
—Laurie, never interject on me, mate. You give me a temptation to spend my next five minutes on you, but I'm not going to bother. You are below my contempt. The Bulletin stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Car buyers pay 22% wholesale sales tax on new vehicles, almost twice the "normal" rate of 12% and possibly the highest rate in the developed world.
Who put that up to 22 per cent? That was the price that was put on after the l-a-w election. What else does it say? It says:

Vehicle buyers are responsible for only 3% of all purchases of goods and services, yet they pay 27% of all sales tax—more than double the amount paid by the second‐biggest victim, the drinker. Whitegoods are taxed at 12%, and travel, housing and clothing are not taxed at all—
and listen to this—
but they compete against cars for the discretionary dollar.

And you cry crocodile tears about the people in Geelong! If the tax on cars were reduced to the more general rate of 12 per cent, the cost of a six‐cylinder family car would fall by almost $2,000 and every year 60,000 more Australians would be able to afford a new vehicle. Has the member for Corio ever thought of that simple fact? Has he ever stood up in this parliament and thumped the table for tax reform in the interests of his constituents? No, not him. He does not want to see the national interest improved.

For instance, the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur)—I stand here and say it because I have heard his thoughtful contributions in our party room and in our committees—understands what is best for his people. The reality is that it is not standing up in this place crying crocodile tears when your own policy has failed and you are putting all the hurdles in the way of clearing the decks for better policy. It goes on to say:

If Australia had a GST, it would cover all goods and services at a flat rate of perhaps between 12% and 15%, would do away with such inflationary charges as payroll tax . . . and would be rebated on business inputs.

What does that mean? It means that the 250,000 Australian manufactured cars that go to the fleet market, half of the total manufacture of cars, would pay no government taxes at all because the GST applicable, to replace the sales tax and everything else, would be fully rebated to that business. They could buy and turn their cars over quicker. They would go as good quality vehicles on to the second- hand market and—surprise, surprise!—we might just get rid of those environmentally polluting bombs. And what would we do in the process? We would double, treble, possibly quadruple the number of cars consumed in Australia. The more cars you make, the more jobs you get. It is simple commonsense. But not from that side.

What are the problems? Tax reform, labour market reform and tariff reform—and they are against all three. You chuck in as well native title reform and a sensible environmental policy, and they just want to put the shutters up on that as well. You sure believe in miracles, but you had a simple solution. You just borrowed money to pay the unemployment relief for those who could not get a job due to your policies. It is all in here. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move opposition amendment No. 6:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 4‐1, page 9, (lines 4 and 5), omit "except as provided in an agreement under section 4‐2".

The Aged Care Bill has a number of significant clauses in it which would give the minister power to transfer responsibility for all of aged care to the states. The minister needs to be aware—this is important for the House to consider in looking at this amendment—that everybody is opposed to the transfer of aged care to the states.

The last time responsibility for aged care was with the states we had the most appalling level of care in this country. That led to a major review by a Senate select committee on private hospitals and nursing homes headed by then Senator Giles. I want to quote a couple of fairly horrific examples of things that went on in nursing homes when the states were in control. The idea that this government would even consider putting in this bill the power for the minister, without any reference to the parliament, to transfer responsibility for aged care to the states or to any one state reflects very badly on this minister.

Major complaints were made to this review that Senator Giles headed about the poor quality of food, about the poor staff-patient ratios, about the way in which patients were left. There are horrific examples in this report about the quality of care, considered to be inadequate or poor, to quote this report.

These were some of the things that were mentioned: patients being showered at 4 a.m. to 6 a.m. to reduce the strain on daytime staff; patients left shivering naked outside showers waiting for nursing staff to return with towels; patients who did not have full use of arms and hands not adequately assisted in the cutting up or feeding of food; patients left for long periods of time in wet or soiled bed linen; patients not frequently turned or repositioned in their beds to avoid the development of bed sores; nursing staff quickly lost patience with patients who did not readily comply with their routine demands.

This is what Labor had to confront when it came into government in 1983. This was the state of nursing homes in this country. The idea that this minister might even consider transferring responsibility for aged care back to the states, back to these horrific situations, is nothing short of reprehensible.

I want to ask the minister what has been the response of the states and where any discussions that she might be having are up to so that we can reassure the community that the minister has no intention of proceeding down this path. I also foreshadow that we will be opposing the sections in this bill that give her that power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We are seeing Labor in a constant state of confusion over this issue and a number of issues. It was when Labor was in government that they commenced the COAG discussions with the states and territories in the interests of trying to put into place more efficient and effective policies. That was under old Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: Now we have the young and the restless in the new Labor ranks. They are in a complete state of confusion as to where they want to go with some of these issues. The shadow minister wants to keep living in the 1980s. We have moved on, and we need to keep improving. That means continuing constructive dialogue with the state and territory ministers in the interests of looking to provide more efficient and effective services to our frail, older citizens.

We will continue to have that dialogue. In answer to the shadow minister's questions about where we are at—and my colleague the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has supported me in this—we have said that we will not proceed to transfer any services to the states unless we can be absolutely assured that there will be better outcomes for the future of older citizens in this country.

We need to keep talking. We need to keep moving on. We are not going to live in the past, like the shadow minister does in the 1980s. As I said, they are in a constant state of confusion. We want to keep the door open, and we want to keep the dialogue going.
Amendment negatived.
Clauses, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 4‐2 and 4‐3 taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate how horrific it would be if this government proceeded to transfer any responsibility for aged care to the states. Labor had no intention of transferring aged care to the states. It spent 10 years getting aged care off the states—10 years of hard work improving the horrific mess that aged care was in when it was the responsibility of the states. It certainly was not intending to hand responsibility for this very important policy area back to the states.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a government that is out of control. This is a government that wants to hide the important issues. This is a leader of House business who scurries out, slurries out. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words on the Aged Care (Consequential Provisions) Bill. This bill provides a smooth transition and considers the transitional issues that need to be considered. We have adopted an approach that provides security and minimum intrusion into the lives of those persons already receiving aged care. The approach minimises the disruption also to service providers and allows a smooth transition period.

SPEECH.PARA: One mechanism to ensure this smooth transition is the provision of a number of grandparenting arrangements. An example of those grandparenting arrangements include the formal agreements between hostel providers and the residents concerning entry contributions and fees. They will be maintained as resident agreements under the Aged Care Bill. This will protect these residents from having to pay any more in entry contributions than they have already paid.

Variable fees which have already been agreed between a hostel provider and a resident will also be allowed to continue. This will ensure hostel providers maintain an income stream that they have relied on as they make the adjustment to the new arrangements. Agreements between nursing home proprietors and residents will be maintained as resident agreements under the Aged Care Bill. Residents currently receiving exempt status services will continue to receive these services and will pay the same exempt fee and will not be income tested.

The bill specifically allows all existing approved operators who are not incorporated at the time of transfer to choose not to incorporate. This decision will not penalise these service providers under the system or impose any additional financial burdens. The bill also amends relevant legislation of the Department of Social Security and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. As I said earlier today, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) has been working with us on the reform of aged care. The Commonwealth departments will take account of the new aged care provisions and again ensure the smooth transition of these arrangements.

There are some additional matters. The Aged Care (Compensation Amendments) Bill is required to amend the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Care Charges Act 1995 to take account of the new aged care provisions. This act currently refers to nursing home benefits and this will be amended to refer to the residential care subsidy. The Health and Other Services (Compensation) Care Charges Act operates in tandem with the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Act 1995. They allow the Health Insurance Commission to collect on behalf of the Commonwealth, amongst other things, money paid for the provision of nursing home care that is included in a compensation settlement. The Health and Other Services (Compensation) Care Charges Act is necessary, as the recovery of money originally paid as a benefit to a resident is regarded as imposing a tax on the resident. Therefore it is also necessary to have a separate bill where amendments to this act are sought.

Labor have talked a lot about process during the passage of this bill, but they really have no right to talk about process. When they were in government, they did not have any process in relation to managing the crisis in nursing homes and legislation that they took through at that time. But they also talked a lot about substance. What did the shadow minister, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), and her colleagues have to say on the substance of the bill? It seemed to me that they had very little to say of any relevance about our reforms. Their main message seemed to be, `Look at Labor's record of achievement in aged care.'

In fact, they are very confused about what their role was. We have heard the shadow minister say that she was a consultant to Brian Howe on the national health strategy—`Nothing to do with aged care'—yet we have heard her time after time in this House try to convince everyone that we cannot extend the successful arrangements that have applied to hostels for 10 years to nursing homes because they are part of the health system. She cannot have it both ways.

In addition to that, we saw the opposition, when they were in government, go to extraordinary lengths to put into place a monitoring system, which was one of the positive things they did, but they put in place a monitoring system that was ensuring that nursing homes were not hospitals, that they produced a home‐like environment. So again there seems to be considerable confusion about what they want.

BREAK.PARA: The member for Jagajaga pointed to a number of changes that Labor introduced—some improvements, as I said, in funding arrangements, outcome standards and a few other changes. They were improvements; I have never hesitated to acknowledge that. They responded to the issues of the day, or at least to some of them. Those reforms, though, were started over 10 years ago and things have changed. As I said before, things have changed quite considerably. We have a new set of problems—problems which were more visible even back then but which are far more urgent today.

We have a growing ageing population and we have had a very major change to the social organisations of our community. Many women who had formerly been the major carers of our old and frail citizens are now in the work force and unable to take on that role in many cases. So we see considerable pressures on the sector, on the government, on the communities and on families in providing adequate care for the frail aged. So the world has clearly moved on, but Labor clearly have not. They are stuck in the mid-1980s in terms of their policy. They could not get back into gear and get it going again. So we have new Labor with old Labor views.

There was a crisis when Labor left office. They had nothing to offer in relation to finding a solution to that crisis. They had all the reports. We saw the Gregory report and other reports. We saw those reports consigned to the bookshelves gathering dust. We never saw them act on those reports or do anything about them. What did they tell older people in the aged care industry? What did they offer them? They said, `Forget about today. Don't worry about tomorrow. But look at what we did yesterday.' It is not good enough.

We inherited this problem and we are going to do something about solving the problem and providing the older, more frail citizens of this nation with the comfort, the dignity, the security and safety that they deserve. We are responding to today's problems in a positive way. We are creating a system to ensure quality of care for older Australians, not only today but to meet the increasing and growing demands of our future generation of older people.

We have had the accusation thrown at us today that we have not consulted. There has been more consultation over the last 12 months than there ever was under Labor. We had five working groups working through the implementation issues with us. These people will tell you that they felt they were actually being listened to by us and that they were actually contributing and that they were partners in the process. They certainly never got that under Labor. Even Dennis Jones from the Australian Nursing Federation said on radio yesterday that, as a minister, I had consulted with them and I had been listening to what they were saying. So we have gone through a very vigorous consulting process.

Our aged care reforms will get rid of the tiers that Labor keeps talking about—the two‐tiered system. This is a system that will go a long way towards fixing the two‐tiered system which existed under Labor. If you went into a hostel, you paid an accommodation bond, you got decent accommodation—safe, secure, private accommodation—but if you were assessed by the Aged Care Assessment Team as needing to go into a nursing home the chances were that you went into a facility where there were four or more people sharing a ward, sometimes up to eight, with row after row of beds. There was no dignity, no comfort and certainly no privacy and no place to put personal belongings. That was the two‐tiered system. The two-tiered system also meant that, if you went into an aged care nursing home under Labor, you went into a system where we know that 11 per cent of the facilities did not meet the basic fire safety requirements and 15 per cent of the facilities did not meet health and safety requirements. That was the two-tiered system under Labor.

Certainly people live in different kinds of accommodation. We all do out there in the community. I live in a three‐bedroom, one‐bathroom house whereas my next door neighbours have a two‐storey, four‐bedroom, two‐bathroom house. So we do live in different kinds of accommodation, but the fact is that we believe that all frail older Australians have the right to live in basic, decent accommoda tion that meets proper fire safety regulations, proper health and safety regulations and that provides them with some dignity and the safety and security that they deserve. They deserve our respect. They deserve better than we have had in this country over the last 13 years.

We inherited this problem. We take the responsibility to fix it, and we will. We will put into place the important and necessary safety nets that will protect those in the community who cannot look after themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five bucks a day. What does everyone think about that?

—The shadow minister talks about the $5, or the five bucks, as she calls it. It is more than they ever had under Labor. Our aged care reforms will get rid of Labor's two‐tiered system. Our reforms will deliver quality accommodation, quality care and choice and flexibility. They will put in place the very important protections for those in the community who are vulnerable. They will ensure access based on the clinical needs of residents, not on their means. They will deliver funding according to the care that is needed and they will also provide appropriate support for dementia, which is a growing area of concern in our community. Many more people that have severe dementia are entering facilities.

BREAK.PARA: Labor's answer to the problem of dementia, according to the policy they took to the last election, was to provide an extra 18c. So that problem was never considered under Labor's plan. We saw dementia residents not being properly cared for and we saw dementia homes and dementia wings in nursing homes having to close down for lack of appropriate recurrent subsidies. That is a great tragedy, and what we have done will address this.

We will actually spend more on residential aged care than Labor did when they were in office. How we will make the savings in aged care is not by taking away any services at all from the aged but by asking those who have the capacity to pay to contribute a small amount to their care. It is very, very important that people understand that the measures we have taken produce savings not by dimin ishing services to the frail aged in our community but indeed by asking those who can pay to make a small contribution towards their care. We have put into place a sustainable system that will serve not only today's frail aged but also those in our community who may become frail and vulnerable in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aged Care (Compensation Payments) Bill highlights the difference between us and those opposite. Labor sees care for aged people as being the government's responsibility because old age is not a permanent state. People are not born old and frail and in need of nursing home care. Old people have made a lifetime's contribution to the development of our society and our economy, and they deserve our respect. They have paid a lifetime of taxes. But how does this government reward this service? By allowing nursing home owners to strip their assets, including the family home. This bill is short sighted and mean spirited. It is motivated by the government's desire to abdicate its responsibility for care for the aged.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1996‐97 budget slashed funding for aged care by over half a billion dollars, with a $244 million reduction on outlays on capital commitments, a $253 million reduction to subsidies paid to nursing homes for care and $72 million saved by introducing a system of user pays for home and community care programs. The 1997‐98 budget has allocated some funds to aged care but after the devastation of the 1996‐97 budget it is a bit like robbing someone of all their possessions one day and the next day returning the toaster and saying, `You should be grateful for this.'

The 1997‐98 budget has allocated $10.2 million over four years for dementia support. But this is very poor compared to Labor's $31 million over five years as part of our national action plan for dementia from 1992. Furthermore, a one‐off grant of $600,000 for dementia facilities is simply for show. During the 1996 election campaign the Liberals promised to introduce grant funding for specialist facilities commencing on 1 January 1997. This simply has not happened. The paltry $600,000 offered is not enough to build even one dementia specific centre. In last year's budget we learnt all about core and non‐core promises. Obviously we need subgroups within the core promises: substantive and non‐substantive funding perhaps.

BREAK.PARA: This government is not interested in the welfare of aged people. It is only interested in reducing the size of government services in the naive belief that market forces—those caring, benevolent market forces that the minister's mates in the real estate industry support—exist only in the minds of the coalition and will have the interests of all Australians at heart. This is really fairyland stuff.

The electorate of Grayndler, which I represent, is fairly typical of many inner metropolitan electorates. Most of the older residents in my electorate have lived their whole lives in the area. In the main they are not wealthy. They do not have big savings. In June 1995 there were 12,500 aged pensioners living in Grayndler, which comprised about nine per cent of the total population.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have they got $88,000?

—They certainly do not have the $88,000 which they would need if they wanted to get into a nursing home. For most of those people, the most valuable and indeed only asset that they have is their home. After 1 October 1997, most people requiring nursing home care who own their own home will be forced to sell it. The people in Grayndler are no exception.

BREAK.PARA: There are around 2,000 nursing home beds in Grayndler, which works out to be 180.2 beds per thousand head of population over 70 years. The Australian average is 59 beds per thousand over 70 years. So the people in my electorate have a vested interest in the future of nursing home care in Australia.

I have tabled a petition in the parliament which contains the signatures of almost 1,000 residents in Grayndler who are genuinely afraid of how this legislation will affect their access to quality and affordable nursing home care. I feel it is my duty, on behalf of the older people I represent, to speak out against this proposed legislation which will result in an unfair two‐tier system of care.

Those who argue that this is in the interests of elderly Australians are simply kidding themselves. If you adopt the market model then you must accept that profit rather than accessibility and affordability becomes the goal. That is the primary problem with this bill. If the government is not prepared to put up the funding for capital works and upgrades then developers must take up the slack. You cannot argue that developers work on a charity model; developers work to make a profit and the bigger the profit the better. It is shown by the fact that friends of the government's legislation in this area are on the top 200 BRW rich list, as I pointed out earlier on today.

Owners of nursing homes will not be obliged to use the interest earnings on patient care or on upgrades. They can take it as profit if they wish. There are no controls in this bill. The bill is designed for the owners of nursing homes, not for the residents. As I noted before, this legislation will result in a two‐tier system: one for the rich and one for the poor. There is no incentive in this legislation for homes to be built in poorer parts of the country, just as there is no incentive for homes to accept the less well off as residents.

The government has said that nursing home owners will be compensated if they take residents with little or no savings, but it has already set the subsidy for concessional residents at a paltry $5 a day. This is a pathetic response and is an insult to all those who have a genuine care for elderly Australians. It is absurdly low and it provides no incentive at all. It has had a negative reaction from private and not‐for‐profit nursing home providers alike. These providers consider the absolute minimum satisfactory amount to be $12 a day. Five dollars a day is just a joke. What will happen to people who have no assets? They will be shunted into substandard institutions, possibly a long distance from their family and support networks.

The legislation is fundamentally flawed because it is designed as a cost saving measure by this uncaring government. The government should take responsibility for aged care services and should ensure equal access and high quality care for all Australians. The government has a responsibility to care for elderly Australians, not simply to represent the interests of its mates such as the Moran Health Care Group. The Moran Health Care Group have two responsibilities: one is making massive profits which have led to Mr Moran ending up at No. 40 on the top 200 list and the second is providing a retirement home for failed Liberal politicians such as Bob Woods and John Hewson.

The fact that the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) joined in today in defending the Moran Health Care Group shows that she is keeping her options open in case, after the next election, she needs to get a job with the Moran Health Care Group as well. The fact that that particular group is taking responsibility for drafting the government's legislation—taking credit for this bill before the House today—says a lot about who will stand to benefit from this disgraceful bill which represents an abrogation of the government's responsibility for aged care.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
