SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to entering parliament, I was fortunate enough to work for the Australian trade union movement for 20 years. As part of that service, I had extensive experience in the Northern Territory as a result of an amalgamation between my old union, the Miscellaneous Workers Union, and the North Australian Workers Union. That union had widespread coverage and developed a very close working relationship with the indigenous people of the Northern Territory. I also had the opportunity of working with them to represent them in both the public and the private sector. That included responsibility, for example, to represent stockmen in the cattle industry; to negotiate the first Central Australian Aboriginal Congress Award; and also to try to do what we could in our own small way to assist in the improvement of opportunity for education and health services for those people in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: It therefore came as a surprise to me—and I think to most members of this House—to read the report on the indigenous stolen children entitled Bringing them home. I specifically refer to the start of that report which reads:

This report is a tribute to the strength and struggles of many thousands of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people affected by forcible removal. We acknowledge the hardships they endured and the sacrifices they made. We remember and lament all the children who will never come home.

That takes me to the Northern Territory and I specifically refer to Wave Hill. Wave Hill is important in the overall struggle for land rights, but Wave Hill also features in this report. I refer to page 131 and I quote:

The removal of the children from Wave Hill by MacRobertson Miller aircraft was accompanied by distressing scenes the like of which I wish to never experience again. The engines of the `plane are not stopped at Wave Hill and the noise combined with the strangeness of an aircraft only accentuated the grief and fear of the children, resulting in near‐hysteria in two of them. I am quite convinced that news of my action at Wave Hill preceded me to other stations, resulting in the children being taken away prior to my arrival.

I turn to page 140 of this report. I suppose it reminds me of my work representing cattle industry workers in the Northern Territory. Page 140 relates how some of these children were treated. It says:
I know many stockbreeders who would not dream of crowding their stock in the way that these half‐caste children are huddled . . .

That is a quote from a submission by the Labor Party with respect to this report. At page 145 there is a reference to Croker Island, which is also known to me. I suppose it goes to responsibility, admission of guilt and the question of an apology. This is what it says at page 145:

There was an active program of fostering children in which the government elicited the support of the churches . . . The churches would provide the Northern Territory Welfare Department with lists of names of people willing to be foster parents. Children from the age of four upwards would then be placed in a foster placement here in South Australia . . . It was a direct arrangement between the church and the Welfare Department in the Northern Territory.
So much for an admission of responsibility. To continue:
In my experience, nearly every foster arrangement resulted in those children going back to search for their roots—nearly everyone tried to find out . . .
What was the end result of this arrangement? I quote from confidential evidence on page 150 of the report:
I started looking at my hands and wondered, why am I the colour that I am? Why are you white?
On page 152, a young woman is quoted:

Most of us girls were thinking white in the head but were feeling black inside. We weren't black or white. We were a very lonely, lost and sad displaced group of people. We were taught to think and act like a white person, but we didn't know how to think and act like an Aboriginal. We didn't know anything about our culture.

I think it is a question of accepting responsibility and facing up to our obligation to give the indigenous people a full apology. It is not an admission of guilt that we ought to be ashamed of; it is a statement that we wronged those people and a clear public statement that we are going to do something to fix our wrongs. It is about leadership. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has failed. Australia expects better. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Model Criminal Code Officers' Committee: Discussion Paper

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elson, Kay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on a matter which has caused a great deal of concern for many of my constituents. There has been a lot of debate recently—as well there should be—about chapter 5 of the discussion paper of the Model Criminal Code Officers' Committee, which relates to sexual offences against the person.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand there has also been a great deal of misunderstanding about both the content of the paper and the federal government's position. Firstly, I would like to state categorically that the concept of lowering the age of consent to 10 years is as abhorrent to me as it is to all parents. I cannot conceive that anyone could make such a suggestion. I understand that the chairman of the Criminal Code Officer's Committee, Judge Rod Howe QC, has stated that it is not the intention or suggestion of the discussion paper. I am sure that will be a relief to many people.

BREAK.PARA: However, it is clear that this discussion paper does suggest a liberalisation—if I can use the word—of laws relating to consent, incest and sexual activity between children. As a mother of eight, I strongly share community concern at the prospect of providing a greater scope for criminals who perpetrate sexual offences. This cannot and will not be tolerated.

I strongly believe that our children need increased protection and that our justice system needs to be tougher on those people who do the wrong thing and are a great threat to the vulnerable in our community, particularly our children. That is the bottom line. I know it is a sentiment shared by all members of the government, particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

I would like to take this opportunity to assure my constituents that the content of the discussion paper does not in any way reflect the views of this government. The fact is that back in 1990 the previous federal government, with the support of all state governments, established a committee to develop a model criminal code. This was established under the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, which is not a federal government body but a committee made up of all state and territory Attorneys-General as well as the federal Attorney-General. The federal government's ongoing interest in this is only to encourage and develop a national criminal code, which I believe is a good idea, as long as it reflects very clearly the growing community feeling that we need a justice system that considers the views and feelings of the victims of crime rather than placing the emphasis on the rights of the criminals.

A tough national criminal code would provide certainty and uniformity, which I think would greatly benefit the community. However, the views expressed in chapter 5 of the discussion paper clearly do not reflect those of the community, which is why I am very pleased to note this is only a discussion paper for community input. I want to stress that this is not proposed legislation and it is not a binding document. Thankfully, it is only a paper for community discussion. In that sense, it may prove useful in that the community's reaction has clearly shown that parents are concerned about this issue and that we want greater protection for our children.

Once the committee takes into account the community's submissions to the paper, it will write a report. Even then the document will be available for public input and debate before it finally goes to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. Even then it will be up to each individual Attorney-General and state government as to whether they adopt any recommendations for the criminal code.

I want to stress that the federal government has no power to implement laws in relation to the criminal code. That is entirely under the jurisdiction of the state governments. I am pleased to note that the Queensland Attorney-General has ruled out Queensland adopting this aspect of the criminal code. The Queensland government is taking a tougher approach to law and order. I support them in this. Queenslanders support them in this also.

I want to assure the local residents of Forde that the federal government in no way endorses the views of the Model Criminal Code Officers' Committee. As a federal member, I will fight tooth and nail any suggestion that criminals be given a greater scope, particularly when it comes to criminal offences against children. I know that my federal government colleagues would join me in opposing any such suggestion. In fact, I am pleased to say that this paper is not a federal government document. It does not reflect our views, just as it does not reflect the views of my constituents.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to add my witness on the stolen generation and call for compassion, reconciliation and apology—a recognition we ought to feel ashamed about because it is long overdue. We ought to reject the extraordinary claim of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that the pendulum has swung too far on recognising Aboriginal rights and that it ought to swing back. I am glad that the honourable member for Forde (Mrs Elson), who just spoke about criminal offences against children, is in the House.

BREAK.PARA: I am not sure that balance, getting the pendulum to swing back, is what we are looking for. The novelist Anatole France once wrote of `the majestic impartiality of the law which forbids rich and poor alike from stealing bread and sleeping under the bridges of Paris'. I quote from Bringing them home, the Wilson report, the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families, chaired by Sir Ronald Wilson, the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I begin on page 152:

We were completely brainwashed to think only like a white person. When they went to mix in white society, they found they were not accepted [because] they were Aboriginal. When they went and mixed with Aborigines, some found they couldn't identify with them either, because they had too much white ways in them. So that they were neither black nor white. They were simply a lost generation of children. I know. I was one of them.
That was from a New South Wales woman removed at eight years with her three sisters in the 1940s and placed in the Cootamundra Girls' Home. Another extract reads:

There was a big poster at the end of the dining room and it used to be pointed out to us all the time when religious instruction was going on in the afternoon. They had these Aborigine people sitting at the end of this big wide road and they were playing cards, gambling and drinking. And it had this slogan which they used to read to us and point to us while they're saving us from ourselves and giving our souls to the Lord. It had, `Wide is the road that leads us into destruction', which lead up into hell. The other side they had these white people, all nicely dressed, leading on this narrow road, and, `Narrow is the road that leads us into the kingdom of life or the Kingdom of God'.

When I was 14 years old and going to these foster people, I remember the welfare officer sitting down and they were having a cup of tea and talking about how they was hoping our race would die out. And that I was fair enough, I was a half‐caste and I would automatically live with a white person and get married. Because the system would make sure that no-one would marry an Aborigine person anyhow. And then my children would automatically be fairer, quarter‐caste, and then the next generation would be white and we would be bred out. I remember when she was discussing this with my foster people, I remember thinking—because I had no concept of what it all meant—I remember thinking, `That's a good idea, because all the Aborigines are poor'.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Woman removed to Bomaderry Children's Home as a baby in the 1940s.

BREAK.PARA: There is some evidence from the 1960s, which is as follows:

I ran away because my foster father used to tamper with me and I'd just had enough. I went to the police but they didn't believe me. So she [foster mother] just thought I was a wild child and she put me in one of those hostels and none of them believed me—I was the liar. So I've never talked about it to anyone. I don't go about telling lies, especially big lies like that.
Another one from a confidential submission in New South Wales states:

I led a very lost, confused, sad, empty childhood, as my foster father molested me. He would masturbate in front of me, touch my private parts, and get me to touch his. I remember once having a bath with my clothes on `cause I was too scared to take them off. I was scared of the dark `cause my foster father would often come at night. I was scared to go to the outside toilet as he would often stop me on the way back from the toilet. So I would often wet the bed `cause I didn't want to get out of bed. I was scared to tell anyone `cause I once attempted to tell the local Priest at the Catholic church and he told me to say ten Hail Mary's for telling lies. So I thought this was how `normal' non-Aboriginal families were. I was taken to various doctors who diagnosed me as `uncontrollable' or `lacking in intelligence'.
Another states:
I was being molested in the home by one of the staff there . . . I didn't know what she was doing with me. I didn't know anything about sex or anything like that, we weren't told.
I have time for one very short one:

I've seen girls naked, strapped to chairs and whipped. We've all been through the locking up period, locked in dark rooms. I had a problem of fainting when I was growing up and I got belted every time I fainted and this is belted, not just on the hands or nothing.
I find it beyond credibility that the Prime Minister can say we do not need to apologise. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In my electorate of Gilmore, over 65 per cent of residents are on social welfare benefits and 60 per cent are on an income of less than $30,000. That is why the provision of quality aged care in our area presents us with an even greater challenge. The beautiful coast of southern New South Wales, the proximity of the region to Sydney, the relatively low cost of living and the wonderful community that exists are all things that make Gilmore an ideal place in which to retire.

BREAK.PARA: While we have always made recent arrivals to our area feel as much a part of our community as those who have lived there for generations, the strain on the aged care system has been all too apparent. My work as the local federal member has seen me come into contact with the very human face of aged care, people who would probably resent being referred to as simply part of the statistics that I have just mentioned, for they are all elderly Australians who have worked hard all their lives making important contributions to the stability, security and prosperity of this country and now require government and community support in the last days of their lives.

Many of these citizens have very real stories to tell, stories which all too often describe inadequate facilities and the type of neglect that no citizen of a modern society should ever have to experience. I have also personally been touched by the plight of the aged, having a mother who requires a high level of care and who is constantly afraid of losing her dignity in the eyes of those who love her.

As Australians, there is no better way to express the respect we have for our elderly than to afford them the opportunity to spend their final years in the comfort of well‐run, quality care and quality nursing homes. Unfortunately, this is not always the case in many parts of Australia. For this reason, I fully support the reforms announced by the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) in the area of aged care, and I have done my utmost to keep my electorate informed of any changes. I have also made a point of discuss ing the issue with those who are best qualified to understand the issue—that is, the care providers themselves.

May I comment on how fortunate we are in Gilmore with the staff of 10 aged care providers working selflessly around the clock to provide and create a happy and healthy environment for those residents of our nursing homes and hostels. It would also be fair to point out how desperately short of nursing homes we remain in Gilmore, with waiting lists for areas such as St Georges Basin, Kiama and Berry. Therefore, the reforms of this government will allow capital expenditure to be directed at those areas in need. Just today, we have had allocated $100,000 for the place I just mentioned in Berry, the masonic village.

However, I am the first to admit that the proposed changes have caused some concern to the people in Gilmore and this is partly due to deliberate political misinformation, something which I see as unforgivable in such circumstances when political point scoring has the effect of causing anxiety and fear among the most vulnerable members of our society—namely, the elderly. There is something terribly wrong with the way we conduct debate in this country, for it is our elderly who are least able to defend themselves. I am deeply ashamed of the tactics being used by the opposition, in particular by the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin).

However, some concern in my electorate is also due to honest misunderstandings. While I have been responding to these concerns, I have noticed that in many cases it is not those who are entering the nursing homes who do not understand the changes but often family members, relatives and friends of those entering the homes who are fearful of extra costs that may be incurred. Fortunately, in 99 per cent of cases, the fears of both the elderly and their families have been misplaced.

The government has had the guts to do what the previous government did not. The minister's aged care policy is reasonable and fair. Many of the people in my electorate have come to recognise and understand the changes, and the overall response has been very positive.

Last Friday I invited the Department of Family Services' Jane Holten to meet with constituents of mine interested in a better understanding of the recent changes. It was a well‐attended meeting and I am glad to say that we were able to reassure those who initially had feared the changes.

It is surprising the extent to which people in the industry actually recognise the need for reform. This belief that the government can do better has made service providers far more receptive to the changes than I had previously thought possible. They are the people who know only too well that between 10 and 50 per cent of nursing homes have significant problems with regard to fire and health hazards. Indeed, some of them may have had to work in environments which were far less than satisfactory and therefore are eager to support a way out of the rut that the previous government's lack of initiative has placed us in.

I also gained an assurance that concessional placements will be made on a needs basis. For example, the need for concessional placements in, say, Sydney may not be as great as in my electorate of Gilmore; therefore, adjustments addressing the situation can and will be made.

We must also stop the practice of families being separated. It is intolerable for a person to be in a nursing home literally hours away from his or her partner or to have your loved one in another town with no public transport to enable regular visits. This happens today in Gilmore, and the minister's aged care package will introduce now a single classification which, in my electorate, is wonderful news for our dementia sufferers and their families. It is known that the government will pay an extra—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to hear that the honourable member for Gilmore (Mrs Gash) thinks it is intolerable to be separated from families. Read the Bringing Them Home report and you will find just how intolerable it is.

SPEECH.PARA: Like many of my Labor colleagues, I wish to read from the report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families, Bringing them home. I have seen many comments in the newspapers about this report but, with sincerity, I would suggest that before people put pen to paper and show their ignorance, they should firstly read this report.

It was my intention to tell some stories about the Kinchela Boys Home, because much of my early life was spent at Kempsey on the north coast of New South Wales, which is the nearest town to the Kinchela Boys Home, and I knew it well. It was Kinchela where the boys were sent and Cootamundra where the girls were sent. The story of Cootamundra has been recorded, not least in Half A Sixpence. But the story of the Kinchela Boys Home on the Macleay River remains very much to be told.

I was going to talk this evening about John's story on pages 166 to 167 of the report, but the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) graphically illustrated this in his report to this House on 28 May. I will have to read another couple of extracts from the report regarding Kinchela Boys Home. One extract from confidential evidence says:

These people are telling you to be Christian and they treat you less than a bloody animal. One boy his leg was that gangrene we could smell him all down the dormitories before they finally got him treated properly.
Confidential evidence 531, also from Kinchela, states:

At the time, we used to get a lot of coke. You got to fill the coke bins up. That's what you got to kneel on—on the coke [as a punishment]. You got no long trousers, [only] shorts and bare‐footed. You know what we got to eat? Straw and buns. That was our tea. That's besides getting the cane. Get straw and buns. Quite naturally you're going to pull the straw out and chuck it away. You do that and you get caned. You're supposed to eat it.
Another one, not from Kinchela, on page 257 states:

The police came one day from Halls Creek when they very going on patrol to L. [pastoral station] and found me, a half‐caste kid. They told the manager to take me to Fitzroy Crossing to wait for the mail truck from Derby to take me to Moola Bulla. . . When the manager's wife told my Mum and [step] Dad that they were taking me to Fitzroy Crossing for a trip, they told her, `You make sure you bring her back'. But little did they know that I would never see them again.
Another report from confidential evidence 284 on page 338 states:

There's letters written here in my handwriting and I go berserk, I can't handle it. I can't go near them because I see my handwritten letters there as a little kid. You know, `May I see my brothers and sisters? I haven't seen them for a long time. They're dear to my heart'. `Do you know where my mum is? Can I please see my dad?' There's letters written back by them that my behaviour didn't warrant visits. There's letters there saying that if I didn't improve my behaviour that I would not be able to be with my brothers and sisters and that I would never see my parents again.

This is not a black armband recording of Australian history. This is Australian history. This is part of our history, and it is a part of our history that we should be aware of. There is no way we can escape this.

I believe that this report will affect everyone. I think there should be many, many more of these reports made available, and I would urge everyone to read it. I honestly do not know how anyone could read these individual reports and not be moved by what they read in them. Regardless of what their views are on many issues, I think we have a duty, especially as members of parliament, to read this report and make it as widely known as possible. I think we should be moved by it and we should try to understand it. I challenge anyone who has read this not to be convinced that we need to apologise for what we did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on what has become known as the stolen children report. This report is of fundamental importance to all Australians. It represents the scars borne by the stolen generation of indigenous Australians. It leaves an indelible impression on any person who has a semblance of compassion for their fellow Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a part of a government that strongly endorses the loving and caring environment of the family. Even if children are born into an environment of poverty, hardship or disadvantage, there can be no substitute for real parental love for a child. Unfortunately, this has not always been accepted.

As the report so graphically illustrates, previous federal and state governments, churches and the police forces in particular believed that the best way to provide an Aboriginal child with a future was to remove them from their environment of abject poverty and disadvantage and place them in a white man's refuge.

My deep and emotional revulsion at this concept is palpable. I abhor institutions that seek to play God with human relationships. It is the most heinous form of social engineering and it defies the most basic laws of nature. My reaction is, however, tempered by the acceptance that I may unwittingly be responsible now for an act of the state for which my children might judge me harshly in the next century.

The accounts in this report are terrifyingly haunting. The voices and tears of these children reach out to, and cannot fail to affect, the hearts and minds of my generation. Just as moving are the statistics outlined in the report. Nationally, it is estimated that between one in three and one in 10 indigenous children were forcibly removed from their families between 1910 and 1970.

Children were sometimes ripped from their mother's arms by the authorities. Over and over in this report I was struck by one line: `I never saw my mother again.' For both children and mothers, this separation and the abyss that it created in their lives forever is difficult for many to understand.

Insidiously, attempts were made by authorities to deny the children their heritage. Often they were given new names and identities, and care was taken to ensure that the children never saw their families again. Children were discouraged, often by physical means, from speaking in their native tongues, thus effectively destroying any hope of communication between family members for those fortunate enough to find their relatives in later years.

Ironically, at the same time that indigenous children were being removed in the 1950s and 1960s, child welfare procedures in relation to non-indigenous children were being influenced by a UN report which stressed that child welfare services should aim to assist families to keep their children with them.

Of course, there are accounts which acknowledge the loving environment provided by foster families as well as gratitude for a sound education, but many conclude that they still lost their sense of belonging, their history. As one of the children said, `In terms of having a direction in life, how do you know where you're going if you don't know where you've come from?' I found the words of Greg, returning to Cape Barren Island, where he was born, to be particularly moving. He said:

I just looked back to where we used to live as kids. My whole life flashed before me and I just collapsed in the sand and started crying . . . And when I composed myself . . . I just sort of reflected on things and . . . I guess I just wanted to be part of a family that I never had. I just wanted to be with my mum and my grandmother and my brothers and sisters.

I tried to imagine what it would be like to be removed from all that was familiar to me as a child—my parents, my siblings, my family home—to be removed from a loving environment and placed in a sterile institution and told that my birthright no longer existed. No matter how graphic the evidence may be, my generation can never understand the real effects of the separation.

I will not buy into the meaningless, base politics of a national apology on this matter. I can only speak for myself. The capacity to feel immense pride in the achievements of one's nation must be balanced with a capacity to feel shame for its wrongdoings. So we as a community and as individuals should recognise the wrongdoings of the past. We should try to help to heal the pain and we should ensure that our nation never forgets and never repeats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to speak on the report Bringing them home and the issue of the treatment of Aboriginal young people and their removal from their families in years gone by. As has been said by other speakers, this is a particularly difficult part of the history of this nation, something about which I think many of us are filled with great shame—I will speak on this on another occasion—that this actually could occur in this society, in this country that I am so proud to be a representative of in this parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As others have done, I will read into the record a number of cases set out in the report which I think highlight some of the appalling things that occurred to a number of people under this policy. I think all in this chamber would recognise education as a key issue. Education is something which was in many ways systematically denied these young people. The first case:

I wanted to be a nurse, only to be told that I was nothing but an immoral black lubra, and I was only fit to work on cattle and sheep properties . . . I strived every year from grade 5 up until grade 8 to get that perfect 100% mark in my exams at the end of each year, which I did succeed in, only to be knocked back by saying that I wasn't fit to do these things . . . Our education was really to train us to be domestics and to take orders.
Another one:

I was the best in the class, I came first in all the subjects. I was 15 when I got into 2nd year and I wanted to . . . continue in school, but I wasn't allowed to, because they didn't think I had the brains, so I was taken out of school and that's when I was sent out to farms just to do housework.
And again:

. . . as I stood with my father beside by grade 8 teacher, he told her of my ambitions to study medicine, and she responded that I didn't have the brains to go on to high school . . . notwithstanding that I had always had an above average academic record through school.

That last case was in fact from New South Wales Aboriginal magistrate Pat O'Shane. In addition, employment and wages and conditions, an issue that often comes before this parliament, was an area of discrimination:

They sent me when I was 16 from Parramatta Girls' Home out to M, a property 137 miles from Nyngan. We never had a holiday. We weren't allowed to go into town with them. If you did go in or go anywhere and you saw any Aboriginal people, you weren't allowed to speak to them. So you had to live that isolated life. We never, ever got our wages or anything like that. It was banked for us. And when we were 21 we were supposed to get this money, you see. We never got any of that money ever. And that's what I wonder: where could that money have went? Or why didn't we get it?
And again:

[Chief Protector] Neville got our money. We were working on a station. Some of them worked six or seven years. And the money come down here to that office here in Wellington St [Perth]. When I finished up, coming back from the Territory, I told who I was and I said, `There's money supposed to be here'. I got 30 shillings—one pound ten—a red, white and blue blanket, and a pass to the Settlement [Moore River]. I said, `Hey, I don't want your pass to the Settlement. I can go to the Settlement. That's my home.
Again:

I was sent out when I was eleven years old to [pastoral station]. I worked there for seven and a half years. Never got paid anything all that time. [Even] Aboriginal people I was working with used to get 30 bob. Yet we didn't get nothing. I used to say, `Where's my money?' `Oh, they put it into the trust account.' So I worked there for them. Oh rough, hardly any food or anything, put out in remote area on me own, drawing water and that, looking after cattle . . . no holiday, no pay. I never received one pay that seven and a half years I was there.

Reading this report, as many of us are doing, you find yourself going through your own personal journey of regret and shame. Certainly I believe an apology is warranted as one part of the necessary steps in order to try and address this historical wrong. I, on my own behalf and whoever I can speak for, believe that an apology is necessary and certainly give it with a great deal of personal feeling. I certainly hope there will be opportunities to speak on this issue again, because this issue is not going to go away and it shouldn't go away—not until we have had a chance to address these issues. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace, Elizabeth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May it was my privilege to be at the dedication of four plaques honouring the 1996 Australian recipients of the Victoria Cross. These plaques have been placed in the Keith Payne VC Park in the suburb of Stafford in my electorate of Lilley, the suburb where Keith Payne lived until he recently moved to Mackay. Keith Payne was one of four soldiers who was awarded the VC during the Vietnam War.

SPEECH.PARA: The dedication service was organised by Kedron Wavell RSL sub‐branch and Brisbane City Councillor Jim Wilding. For the president of the sub-branch, Mr Whalan, and Councillor Wilding it was the culmination of a project which had begun in 1995 as part of the Australia Remembers celebrations. The second stage of the dedication on that Sunday saw the unveiling of four plaques dedicated to the VC recipients from the Boer War, World War I, World War II and the Vietnam War.

Pupils from Stafford State Primary School and Stafford Heights State Primary School have planted trees in the park, one for each VC recipient, and have assumed the responsibility for the care and maintenance of the park. Both the schools were represented on Sunday by their school captains: Sarah Hills and Katherine Nicholls from Stafford State Primary School; and Stewart Hancock, Susie Doran and Alexander Coe from Stafford Heights State Primary School.

Each student spoke on an aspect of the Victoria Cross, its meaning, its history and the men who were awarded it. Katherine Nicholls from Stafford State Primary School expressed the feelings of everyone at the service when she said:
. . . fortunately, it was impossible for the children of today to really know what war is like but we can still appreciate the sacrifices that have been made for us . . .

The Victoria Cross is a medal of plain bronze inscribed with the words `For valour'. The Victoria Cross is awarded without discrimination. It can be gained by officers or other ranks, generals or privates, but only for the highest act of valour and self‐sacrifice.

Clive Mitchell‐Taylor, the National President of the Vietnam Veterans' Association of Australia, was in Brisbane for their 18th national conference which was held on Bribie Island on Saturday. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) was the keynote speaker at that conference. Mr Mitchell‐Taylor read a message at the service from Keith Payne, who was in England having tea with the Queen Mother and joining other recipients of the Victoria Cross and the George Medal at a re‐dedication service and biannual conference.
Keith Payne said in his message that he hoped all who had been concerned with the concept of the park would feel proud of what they had achieved. Clive Mitchell‐Taylor went on to say:

When talking about valour and self-sacrifice, we are not talking about the Knights of the Round Table, or Superman, or Batman, or the Green Lantern or the Phantom. We are talking about flesh and blood Australians who made a conscious decision to put their own lives at risk because there was a chance they could help someone else.

The Victoria Cross winners are a magnificent example for our young people. It must be remembered that wars are not fought single-handedly and that there were thousands of Australians who were involved in the different wars and who made their own sacrifices, worked and fought hard and for whom there is no Keith Payne VC Park.
I would like to quote a Jewish prophet from the Old Testament. More than 2,000 years ago he said:

And of others there is no memory—they have perished as though they had never existed, they have become as though they had never been born; they and their children after them. But these were also godly men, their righteous deeds have not been forgotten; their wealth will remain with their descendants, and their inheritance with their children's children.

This is an eloquent and passionate appeal from long ago for people not to forget the lives and deeds of their forebears. Ongoing support for the work of the RSL and the veterans association in the work they are doing both spiritually and practically in the caring for the health and welfare of veterans is essential.

I was happy to hear that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs announced at the dedication service that his department had made available a grant of $10,000 for the work of the commemoration in the Keith Payne VC Park. I would like all of us to remember that their righteous deeds have not been forgotten. Their wealth will remain with their descendants and their inheritance with their children's children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to closely associate myself with the comments that other ALP colleagues have made with regard to the Bringing them home report. I believe an understanding of the report is essential to the process of reconciliation in Australia. Indeed, it is essential for all Australians to understand the full history of this part of Australian heritage. It is not something that Australians of any generation can be proud of. It is not something the Australian Labor Party takes any political satisfaction in.

SPEECH.PARA: I was pleased to hear our leader, Mr Beazley, express an apology on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, particularly those Labor Party governments at state level that had been associated with these practices. It is a moving set of reports and instances of the human side in the Bringing them home report.

I pay tribute on this occasion to Carol Kendall, who is a resident in the south‐west of Sydney. She has been exceptionally active not only in Aboriginal causes in our region but also in ensuring that the Bringing them home report has been resourced and receives recognition around the country. She has dedicated a good part of her life out of her own personal circumstances to this process. I pay tribute to her efforts.

I note her own circumstances, which have received publicity. It is hard to imagine how, as Carol did, she could get to know her biological sister first as a friend and then, out of instinct, out of some association, talk about what they knew of each other's family history and then trace it back to the point where they could connect the family tree and recognise that they were much more than friends: they were sisters who did not know their proper relationship in a family sense.

To sit down, as I did, and hear her story was certainly something that awakened my consciousness to the seriousness of this matter. No Australian with any decency in their heart could feel anything but great sorrow and look for a source of reconciliation, wanting to do good things out of this sad episode in the history of so many Australian families.

I was rather disappointed that at the national reconciliation conference last Monday week the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) did not develop or embellish the theme that has been central to his politics over 20 years—the centrality of the family in Australian society, whether those families are Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal. That really should have been the basis of his approach: a national unifying theme to say that these things, whether they happen in Aboriginal or any other Australian family, are unacceptable and that as a nation we owe some form of apology.

Mr Eoin Cameron to move—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hatton, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking yesterday on the 1997 Aged Care Bill, I said that the Howard coalition government was mad and bad and dangerous. I did so for what I think are quite good and pertinent reasons. I wish to speak today in this budget debate on aged care and the impact of the aged care changes in that bill. I also wish to speak on the changes in this budget on superannuation. In both of those areas, what is being proposed and what is being done is dangerous, firstly, to the health and care of our aged in terms of the aged services bill as an integral part of the government process, and, secondly, because what is being done with superannuation is dangerous in terms of the future of our national savings.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take up a point that I made yesterday and did not explore adequately. Today, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) will be announcing a $13 million program, to run over three years, in relation to crime prevention and to lowering the level of violence within the community. I made the point that he is the George Bush of Australian politics, because what he is introducing now—and we saw it during the last election—is an American Republican mode of electioneering. This program that he will be announcing today is touchy‐feely and emotive politics. This program is directed towards non‐Commonwealth government responsibilities.

The Prime Minister, when he announced in the House the day before yesterday that he would be undertaking this program, said, `Well, yes, it wasn't really a Commonwealth government responsibility.' Fighting crime, making sure the police forces work properly, undertaking measures in relation to domestic violence, monitoring particular violence programs and so on, have always been, and are still, central state government responsibilities. Yet what the Prime Minister has indicated is that the Commonwealth government is willing to spend $13 million on a program that it has no responsibility for.

What will actually be done with that program? First, the core is that the Commonwealth government will not be taking on responsibility for crime fighting. It will be taking on a responsibility for monitoring what is done in state crime fighting programs, trying to work out a best practice model and examples, and working up that model on a pilot basis. We have seen in the 1996 budget and the 1997 budget lots of pilot programs. There is a pilot program for work for the dole—for 10,000 placements. We have seen the Green Corps, which is effectively a pilot program. Forty people are employed in Queensland under the Green Corps—and of those 40 people, 15 have previously been employed. They went out of paid employment to go to work on the Green Corps.

There is a sloganeering, electioneering basis to a number of coalition government programs and to the way in which the Green Corps and work for the dole is pushed, with 10,000 people on pilot work for the dole programs, not the majority of people who are unemployed. And the Prime Minister indicates that he will actually take the jump and effectively go into electioneering mode on what is not Commonwealth responsibility. It is in an area where we know that people throughout Australia—whether they are the aged, the infirm, the disadvantaged, the poor, the rich—know and understand that there is violence in the community, there is crime in the community and there are burglaries in the community.

Most people understand that they are state responsibilities. The American Republicans also have been extremely good at arguing on an emotive basis across a range of issues that are like fairy floss. George Bush was not campaigning on the hard‐core issues such as jobs, education and social security. The American Democrats said to George Bush, prior to him being thrown out of the presidency, that the core message that had to go to George Bush was, `It is the economy, stupid.' I think we could still say that to the current Prime Minister: the core problem here is the economy and jobs, but we could also say, looking at the 1996 and 1997 budgets, `It is also the society, stupid.'
The message here is, quite simply, that we not only live in an economy but we live in a society as well. Living in a society, looking at this year's budget and comparing it to last year's budget—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 9.56 a.m. to 10.18 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just come back from a division in the House, which was based on the question of what should happen to the Aged Care Bill 1997. The member for Pearce, the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), has just initiated the process of guillotining this bill through the parliament. Lots of members of the Australian Labor Party and coalition members who would seek to speak on this bill will be denied their right to speak on the bill so that this damaged and dangerous bill can be run through the parliament.

BREAK.PARA: I restate that it is dangerous for this reason: I alluded yesterday to the Bankstown City Frail Aged Persons Homes Trust and a letter from the general manager of that trust, Mr Terry Madden. I quoted a fair amount of that letter and I will quote some more of it now because it bears on the core problem of this bill. The letter states:
An amalgamation of hostel places and nursing home places, as this bill proposes—
the bill that has been guillotined through today—
has an effect on the city of Bankstown in terms of our current provision.

In 1985, with then coalition opposition support, the federal government put through a new way of looking at aged care services for the community. It was a tripartite manner of dealing with those problems. Instead of people who were at home with virtually no assistance being forced into decrepit nursing home conditions, as outlined in the Giles report of 1983, because they had no other recourse if they became unable to care for themselves, and if their relatives could not, we brought in a system where people could have a choice—individual choice and family choice—about how their relatives could be cared for and could care for themselves.

In the new way of looking after people who are aged, there were three choices. Firstly, aged people could stay at home to be supported under the home and community care program. In that way nurses from the community could come in to assist people and help to bathe and wash them and do whatever had to be done in terms of looking after their personal care. Secondly, they could also get help from home care for mowing the lawns and dealing with the normal day‐to‐day problems that people who were slightly infirm or who had difficulties would need help with. Thirdly, they were also supported in terms of carers who chose to stay with those people if they needed more help.

This was in the national interest in terms of the government's budgetary position because the tripartite system of helping people to stay within their own homes, if they chose to do so, was better than building hostel places at 15 per cent a year, year on year real expenditure, and creating a massive expansion of hostel places. Then there was the renovation on a progressive basis of nursing home places, essentially through capital funding.

Those three elements over a 10-year period built a strong, balanced, open, sensible, aged care system. However, what this bill does is collapse the hostel program into the nursing homes program. Over the past decade or more, societies such as the Frail Aged Trust, a not-for-profit group, have built hostel places in Bankstown. They have allowed people entry into those at no cost because 60 per cent of the hostel places in Bankstown are concessional. They are for people who are relatively disadvantaged. They are for people who are already on pensions, who do not have large disposable incomes and who are not asset rich. They are for people who did not have their own homes, who were in rented accommodation. There are also people who did have their own homes, did pay their way into the hostel program if they got a hostel place in another place, but in terms of the Frail Aged Group there has been no entry fee whatsoever.

There have been four hostel groupings in the Bankstown Frail Aged Trust. They are spread throughout the city of Bankstown. They have been very successful because they have been for people who chose not to stay at home or who could no longer be looked after as well as they might be at home. They could go into a hostel and be relieved of the burden of the 300-foot backyard and all of the associated maintenance problems of the homes that they had grown up in and where they had brought their children up.

Those people could go into a hostel situation where there was a central meal facility, where there was central nursing help, and where they had the companionship of all of those other people living with them in the hostel. These were people who, prior to 1983, would have been forced to go into a nursing home entirely inappropriately. Those hostel places that were built in Bankstown during the period of the Labor government have delivered services to the aged people of Bankstown. But this bill coalesces two standards, the nursing home standard and the hostel standard. We are back to Fraser government days; we are back to one possibility, one standard.

You may think that is just a rhetorical point, but there is a core problem here in terms of what we do with infrastructure for the aged community in my electorate of Blaxland, in the city of Bankstown. The core problem is that with a relatively modern housing stock for hostel groups, they are built to level 3 standard. They are not built to nursing home standard, which is level 9. The not-for-profit trust has never had to go to a mortgage originator, or to a bank, because it has been supported by the people of Bankstown, by the registered clubs, by other charitable groups, and by the Bankstown Council.

However, the trusts are now faced with the situation that they will have to abandon the hostel stock that they have. It is absolutely perfectly utilisable, as it has been for the past decade, but they will have to abandon that stock. That has come about because what is implied in this bill is that it has to be of nursing home standard.

If they choose to upgrade all of that infrastructure from level 3 to level 9, they will need about $5 million to do it. They will have to go out and borrow it, because they did not charge any entry prices for those concessional hostel entrants. They will not be able to recover the cost of that, except over at least a five‐year period, if not a 10‐year period, to get back to square one. They can spend a lot of money on upgrading to level 9.

They will then be faced with the problem that those hostel places are dispersed around the city of Bankstown. They are not on the same property as the nursing home that they have built. The bill impresses people into consolidating on one site. It is fine for the three major for profit providers—the Moran group and others who already have that model—it is perfectly fine for them. It is also entirely understandable that that is reflected in the bill because, of those who gave advice directly to the minister, by and large the advice that was accepted came from the for profit sector. So the model that is being imposed is what is already there.

But the bill does not impose upon those for profit providers that they should actually spend the extra amount of money that they will get from the Commonwealth or the extra amounts that they will get in terms of the interest on the accommodation bonds, on building new capital stock in the nursing homes. It is very vaguely worded. They can in fact pocket it, as used to happen prior to 1983.

Those people who are against this particular aged care bill and the philosophy that runs throughout the last two budgets are the major charitable associations within Australia. Those who have brought these proposals into question are the Alzheimer's Association of Australia, the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, ACOSS, the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, Baptist Care Australia, the Churches of Christ Network of Aged Care Services, Community Services, Australian Uniting Church and Salvation Army. They are some of the most prominent social welfare organisations in the country and they have all jointly expressed their concern to the government.

The impact is very real. When the bill first saw the light of day and was suggested, the price of an entry fee was suggested to be about $26,000. In fact, the figuring was entirely wrong because what the government and the opposition and the community at large were using as a basis for figuring did not take into account a lot of the rebuilding costs. In the aged care community at large, it is now recognised that the probable average cost will be $88,000. That $88,000 is there because, over a 20‐year period, you need in fact to rebuild a nursing home. For the Bankstown City Frail Aged Persons Homes Trust, they have this to say in relation to the problems they face:

All nursing homes are built with a 20‐year life cycle. After 20 years, technology, the frailty of the residents, changes in diagnosis and illness of residents, and fire safety requirements are such that what was built 20 years ago needs to be modernised or rebuilt.

What this means is that, when a charity builds a nursing home, it needs to budget for between $250,000 and $300,000 per year to rebuild the facility or modernise it after 20 years life. In the past, the Commonwealth government has provided a large share of those funds by way of its capital grants.

The government now expects that money to come from residents paying accommodation bonds, and the charities will invest those bonds, putting the interest into a capital works account, putting the $2,600 per annum drawing down allowance from the bond into the same account, and also putting into that account whatever government subsidy is given to compensate the charity for taking any resident who cannot afford to pay a bond. These three ingredients added together have to equal between $250,000 and $300,000 per annum.

Mr Madden goes on to point out that there will be a dramatic shortfall for not‐for‐profit groups such as the frail aged trust—a shortfall of something in the order of $77,000 a year—and that over a 20‐year period of time $1.5 million would be ripped away from this charitable institution and they will not be capable of rebuilding their capital stock. This bill will force them to rebuild their hostel stock which is not in need of rebuilding at the previous hostel standard of level 3. They will be forced to move up to the nursing home standard of level 9. So that previous capital infrastructure spending will effectively go to waste because it will have to be done again—there will be a duplication of it.

In this critical area, in terms of the Commonwealth actually being in place and doing something that the Commonwealth government has absolutely total, complete and utter responsibility for, this coalition government under Prime Minister Howard is effectively walking away from its responsibilities. And where is the justification for that? It is in the National Commission of Audit report. This yellow tome is effectively the heartbeat of this coalition government because in last year's budget and in this year's budget, line for line and word for word, the National Commission of Audit's philosophy informs these budget papers and the legislation that has come through.
The National Commission of Audit had this to say about aged care. These were the crises underlining the changes this stupid bill has put into place:
The government should urgently implement measures to reduce the potential for longer term aged related funding increases . . .
The government should take action now to change expectations of reliance on government assistance, by reducing aged and health related outlays.

Just as Airservices Australia has changed the flying patterns over the Sydney basin and we have got an impact in terms of preparing people for a second airport, so this government, with the backing of the National Commission of Audit—which they brought into being—have suggested preparing the aged in the community. Start to take away resources. Start to take away government assistance. Charge them more for the home and community care assistance they have got. Charge them an entry fee and accommodation bond—a significant one of $88,000—into a nursing home. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that in the debate on appropriations there is considerable licence given to members on the range of matters they may address, but I would suggest to the gentleman who has just spoken—who has obviously delivered his speech on aged care—that there is a debate going on in another place at the moment that is dealing with just that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: When he complains about the guillotine, he might wish to remember that in fact there has been extensive debate allocated in the main chamber on that bill. He might wish to remember that his side of the House—which has something like half the numbers of our side of the House—have had their full speaking allocation each, whilst our members have in fact cut their allocation by half. I think there has been more than enough time for debate in the main chamber on that particular bill. It seems to me that to come here and regurgitate much of that argument is probably a bit of a nugatory exercise from his point of view.

However, I will move on to talking about the nation's broader economic aspects, which of course is relevant in terms of the appropriations bill. I think it is important that we put in context the nature of what the government is trying to achieve with this budget, because this budget is one of a series of budgets which have a central premise.

We saw in last year's budget, followed up by this year's budget, a government that has been determined to try and get the country's economy back on track. We are, of course, all aware that members on the other side will come into this place and they will undoubtedly stand up one after the other and try and criticise individual measures. They will complain about something being cut or not being done or why more money has not been spent in this area or that area. In fact, that characterised their 13 years in government and what happened was that there was such a concentration on the minutia that we did not in fact get the big picture right.

I want to talk this morning about some of those big picture items. What happened when the Howard government took office was that we discovered that there was a huge debt. I think we are all aware that the country has got a huge debt and the government's expenditure on a year by year basis has not been in balance. With last year's budget we saw the first moves taken to try to put that budget right, to try to make sure that the federal government did not finish up in the red each year and to try to get us back into the black—as we all have to, not only at a government level but also at a family and personal level.

There was some pain associated with that. That is inevitable. It is regrettable, but it has to happen, because you cannot continue to live beyond your means. If you do of course the national debt just gets bigger and bigger. One of the problems when you get into debt is that you have to start to borrow. When you borrow, you have to start to service the interest associated with that borrowing, which adds to the debt problem on a year by year basis. What this government has been about is putting the national accounts back into good order. It is an ongoing process: it will not be achieved in five minutes but we have made a start and that is important from a national perspective.

I want to talk about a few other matters this morning that continue that theme. It seems to me that when you are trying to get the nation's accounts back in order it is not only about good housekeeping but also about looking at how we encourage our country to export in order to start earning money overseas and to start paying off some of the debt rather than just stopping the rot, which was the first step along the road. It is important to look at our place in the world and remember that, whilst geographically we are a large country, in economic and population terms we are actually a very small country. We cannot therefore go out and dictate to the rest of the world what happens to suit us or how we want them to behave. We cannot use economic muscle to require other people to do the things that we want them to do.

In terms of economic activity in the world, Australia accounts for less than one per cent—we are a mighty mouse in economic terms. We cannot in fact go out there and dictate, as perhaps the United States can or as perhaps a united Europe or Japan can. There is another major thing that this country has to come to grips with in economic terms. Whilst a lot of our history has been orientated towards the United Kingdom and Europe—and quite clearly that relationship will continue to have be an important strand for this country for some time—it is no longer the dominant strand in our economic future.

Similarly, the United States has been important to us and continues to be an important trading partner. But the reality is that, in our trade with the United States, the United States does overwhelmingly better out of that trade than we do. We have a significant trade imbalance, in their favour, with the United States.

But I think we are all beginning to realise that our future in fact is going to be much more orientated to the Asian part of the world, in which we are located. It is perhaps a hackneyed phrase, but we used to talk about the `tyranny of distance' when we talked about our remoteness from Europe and the United States. It seems to me that we now have the advantage of proximity in terms of the future development in Asia.

I think we are all aware that the booming economies in the world are those that are associated with Asia, whether it is Japan, Korea or Indonesia, which is starting to grow rapidly, or even the Philippines, which has started to put into place some economic measures to make it a potential tiger economy. Then there is Thailand and, of course, the big one—China. If we accept that we live in the part of the world that has those booming economies, we have to think about how we deal with those booming economies, how we take advantage of that.

It is worth noting up front that we have to be careful that we do not spoil the game before we get into it. That is where I certainly take some exception to some of the comments made by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). What you will find, if you travel around Asia these days—I have had the good fortune in recent months to visit a number of countries in Asia—is that increasingly people who would send students to this country are in fact asking, `Is it safe to send my student there?' Malaysia sends 10,000 or 11,000 students a year. Indonesia, Singapore and Hong Kong do the same. We have something like 60,000 overseas students in this country at any one time, and they bring in several billion dollars to our economy. Education is big business in this country.

Everywhere you go in Asia, and in the South‐East Asian area in particular at the moment, people ask, `Is it safe to send our students? Should we be sending them to America or Britain?' That is potentially going to do us great damage. You have similar questions in terms of tourism and similar statements in terms of investment. When I was in Singapore recently, a number of men from large businesses were saying to me, `Why should I come and invest in Australia when, quite clearly, the support that has been generated for the member for Oxley shows that you are not really interested in Asian investment. I'll go and invest my money in another country—whether it is Brazil, Indonesia or some other country.' So it seems to me that we have to make it very clear to our neighbours in Asia that we do want to do business. That is the first and the prime lesson that we need to understand.

Just recently, Ross Garnaut from the Australian National University has published his annual assessment of the Asian economies and where we stand compared with many of those economies. This is in a document called Asia Pacific Profiles which is an analysis of 15 nations. Professor Garnaut looks at the growth factors and at a whole range of factors that are relevant to where we are going and how we compare with other countries. It is interesting that on his league tables, for example, China is at the top of the pile in terms of growth, followed by Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore and Korea. Then we get down to some of the less well‐known, but certainly potentially booming, economies of places such as India and the Philippines. Taiwan is there of course, as is Thailand. Hong Kong, albeit only a country of six million people, ranks well above Australia. Australia is not scoring very highly at all—we are only just marginally in front of Papua New Guinea and New Zealand. Japan, in fact, is below us in terms of growth because it is coming off a far higher plane and therefore you would not expect it, as a mature economy, to be showing the same degree of growth.

One of the other interesting points that Ross Garnaut makes in his report is something that I think has started to hit home to people in this country just in the last few weeks. The report says that, from the second half of 1996, Australia began to lose manufactured exports momentum, an event so far unremarked but indicative of a decline in international competitiveness that is sure to influence the looming protection debate. It is very interesting that a number of manufacturers are telling me—and I am sure they are telling other members of this House—that manufacturing has been in the doldrums for some time and that any stimulus that may have been given to the economy by recent interest rate cuts has been filled by taking stock off shelves, rather than making things and restocking the shelves. So we clearly have a number of challenges in that direction. That is a problem which this government is going to have to face, but which we as a nation have to face. With our small population we are not going to drive a huge domestic market; what we have to do is to become much more export orientated. We perhaps have to look much more at what we do overseas.

I would like to take a few minutes to talk about a recent trip I was fortunate enough to make to China with a number of colleagues from both sides of the House. It was my first visit to China and I came away mightily impressed with what I had seen. We went to Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen. It was very interesting that the development that is going on in China is on a scale and at a pace that takes the breath away. Quite clearly, since Deng Xiaoping started the economic revolution in China some 18 years ago they have made huge strides. Shanghai is an example. For those who have not been to Shanghai, it is built on the west bank of the river, where it comes out to the ocean. It is a large city, with something like 13 million people, and a well‐known one, having been a centre of the economy in China for many, many decades. But the east bank has traditionally been farming ground, because the river is about 1½ miles wide and, historically, it has been difficult to get across.

Seven years ago, the Chinese government decided they would develop a new industrial centre on the east bank. They have built some tunnels under the river and some bridges over the top and, five years ago, they started to build. When we went to Shanghai, we went down to the riverfront where there is an esplanade called the Bund. One of my colleagues was there five years ago. He said that he had stood on the Bund and looked across to the other bank at an area that is now known as Pudong, and that it had all been farms. But when you stand there today, you can see nothing but skyscrapers and buildings for factories and accommodation and offices and so on. There are now several million people living there, and that is in a five‐year period.

Shanghai has 17 per cent of the world's overhead cranes. You just think about that. Almost one‐fifth of the world's overhead cranes are in one city in China, because of the amount of building that is going on. The elevated roads that are going in in Old Shanghai, and all the new factories and so on, are absolutely mind blowing.

We went on to a town called Hangzhou, which is about 180 kilometres south of Shanghai and inland. It is a relatively small city in Chinese terms: it has only 1.6 million people. We went to the Hangzhou Universal Joint Factory where they make metal joints that go into car engines. They make just seven products. It was started by seven farmers 18 years ago. Today, they employ 6,500 workers on the shop floor. It was just one factory, but with building after building with rows and rows of employees turning out product.

We had some engineers in the party who looked at these things and told me that the quality was absolutely outstanding. The workers are working eight‐hour shifts in a five‐day working week. It is not sweated labour. Certainly, compared with our wages, theirs are poor; but, compared with where those workers were at five years ago, they are in absolute clover. The standard of the housing which we saw is improving dramatically. That company had a $US150 million turnover last year, of which $50 million was in exports. So it is that sort of thing that we are actually going to have to compete with.

We went on to Shenzhen, which is just across the border from Hong Kong. Sixteen years ago, when the Guangzhou area which encompasses Shenzhen was declared the first special economic development zone of China, it was a fishing town of 20,000 people. Today, Shenzhen has 3½ million people, wall‐to‐wall skyscrapers, factories, accommodation and so on—a huge amount of economic activity. They are building skyscrapers there at the rate of one floor every 2½ days. They built a new international airport which was opened not long ago, which took three years from go to whoa—from start to finish in three years.

We cannot even make a decision as to where to put Sydney airport, after 20‐odd years of arguing about it. I have to say that both governments have been at fault in that respect. I am talking about an Australian problem, a problem which we have to come to grips with. You can come away from China as I did, and you can say, `I feel thoroughly intimidated. What hope have we got? This country of China is going ahead at such a rate of knots economically that it will become the dominant economic power in the next century. We are going to be a bit player and we are going to be taken over economically.' Alternatively, you can come away saying, `There are tremendous opportunities in that market for Australia, but we have to get our act together.'

Not all is perfect in China. For a start, there is very little environmental protection going on there, and there is some pretty terrible environmental degradation happening there as a result of the huge growth. Occupational health and safety is not exactly high on the agenda in some of those factories and so on that we saw. So there are opportunities for us. We are generally regarded throughout Asia as being very innovative. We have a number of areas where a highly skilled and highly trained work force can be successful—in new construction techniques and environmental management, and even in legal services, education, health and information technology and communications. There are tremendous opportunities for this country in such places as China and elsewhere throughout South‐East Asia. But we do need to have an orientation towards exporting. It seems to me that that is something in our culture, if you like, that we have not developed sufficiently in this country.

To help companies do some of that, this government now needs to not only put the housekeeping matters of the year‐to‐year budget in order, which was an essential first step, but also to go on and do a few other things, and I am sure it will. For example, the government needs to look at the taxation system, which is an absolute disincentive to companies to export. There is no question about that, and that is part of the argument about the current car industry.

We also need to sort out things such as the waterfront. Increasingly, the car industry is not about building a car lock, stock and barrel in Adelaide or Melbourne or somewhere overseas. It is about sourcing from a variety of countries different components at the best price, bringing them together and assembling them. That means that transportation and shipping is absolutely fundamental, so this government needs to move on and deal with things like the waterfront, the taxation system and probably more industrial relations reform.

We also need to look at the enforcement of standards. If our companies, when they go overseas and do business, are going to be subject to all sorts of safety standards, we have to look at those issues when companies bring their products into this country as well. We have to do more in terms of savings and investment because we have not got a savings base in this country. We do not have the base, therefore, for investing in our companies, and that is another reason why we need to attract investment from overseas, another reason why we do not need to turn off those Asian investors who might come here and invest in opportunities in this country.

It seems to me that the bottom line is that we as politicians and members of this parliament, and political leaders at all levels, need to make sure that we start getting out there and selling the message that the economic restructuring that is so necessary and which this government has to pursue over the next few years is for the long‐term good of Australia.

We also have to get the message to business that they have to get a culture of getting out there and selling overseas. Whilst there is a lot of uncertainty undoubtedly out there in the community, the man and woman in the street has to start to be educated, in a sense, and informed as to why it is so necessary that we see our future in Asia and what we need to do to make that successful. If we show by our attitude that we do not care about Asia we will go down the drain, but if we grasp the opportunity that is there this country can once again be very prosperous indeed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98. Firstly, the government is taking a great deal of satisfaction at the low inflation rate that Australia is currently enjoying. I think this is a considerable achievement. I believe that it is fair to say that the previous government had a part to play in breaking the cycle of high inflation, but I do not want to detract from the current performance and I believe that, into the future, it is really important that we maintain low inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to make the point, though, that there is always a trade‐off between the level of inflation and the level of unemployment. One of the consequences and one of the factors of relatively high unemployment is the very low level of inflation. Some economists might argue—of course, they are always arguing—that perhaps it might be worth while having a half a per cent more inflation, or even one per cent more, to get the unemployment rate down. But I do not want to enter that debate, because I think we need to be constructive and I certainly support the government position in that regard. I think that is what the people of Australia expect us to do, to try to see what is in the best interests of the country, and then give credit where credit is due—and I am happy to extend that in relation to inflation.

But I must say that there are things that really do disturb me. I notice in the Sydney Morning Herald today that we have some very disturbing headlines. I am sure you would have liked to have read it but, in case you have not, the main story is `Recession hits factories'. I think that is a very uncomfortable headline for us all in electorates such as those of Fowler and mine, because what it really means is that unemployment is going up. And in the business section of the Sydney Morning Herald a headline reads, " `R' word is back. The Government blames the dollar."

It is true when we were in government that in fact the number of people employed in the manufacturing sector did go down and stabilised somewhat but at a time when manufacturing output had increased. These are very disturbing statistics. I will read from the Hansard record an excellent table that sets out sectoral growth. Manufacturing in the March quarter declined by 0.1 per cent and the annual growth is 2.2. Health in the March quarter declined 1.1 per cent and the annual growth is 0.4; retail trade is declining from 1.7 per cent to 1.3; education declining from 1.8 to 1.3.

This is part of the issue that I want to focus on. In the first budget we saw an expectation of higher growth but the government was not able to deliver it. I must say with this budget, I do not believe—and I see now where economists and writers are joining in that—that the growth targets predicted in the budget are actually going to be met. Again, I say we can talk here in abstract figures about whether we are achieving this growth or what growth is desirable, but at the end of the day when we leave this chamber and go back to our electorates we are talking about people who do not have jobs. These statistics actually translate into human beings. Whether they are older workers or young workers, they are human beings.

One of the tragedies of modern society is, in fact, this unacceptably high level of unemployment. In an electorate like mine, I have had to cross a major bridge. Basically I am very much an optimist and that bridge was to come to believe that we are now going to have a core of people who will never find a job. How does society give them dignity? How does society give them a worthwhile activity? If we do not, the social costs of not trying to address that problem will be horrific.

The member for Fowler (Mr Grace) will remember that, when the Keating government was looking at One Nation, trying to tackle this issue of unemployment, there was a very furious debate in the caucus. The point at issue was whether we should, in the year 2000, aim for five per cent unemployment or should we have a lower target.
