I have to confess that I was one of a minority who argued passionately that we really had to go for a lower number. In any event, when we did announce the five per cent target, people felt that this was an ambitious target but backbenchers like me and the honourable member for Fowler, who shares a concern for his constituents, very much believed that this was achievable.

It is really disappointing to see unemployment being stuck unacceptably high. It is predicted we can get unemployment down from 8.7 per cent to eight per cent. Firstly, I do not believe you are going to hit the mark and, in any event, I believe eight per cent is far too high. In electorates like mine it means that there is an even higher level of unemployment.

BREAK.PARA: In the last three years of our government—and I do not want to harp on this—we were hitting 2.8 per cent growth in jobs in the economy. The level of full-time jobs was very respectable. In the first Howard budget, the target set that was not met was just 1.5 per cent—only 1.5 per cent but it was undershot. I think you are going to find that you get the same situation.

I have made comment previously that one of the most disturbing features of job growth in the economy, as it exists, is the way we are shedding full‐time jobs and replacing them with part‐time jobs. I do not want to get into an argument about the value of a part‐time job or a full‐time job. All I am saying is that I think the balance is being worryingly disturbed with such massive numbers of jobs being part‐time jobs. If this trend continues, I wonder how long it will be before we start talking, in a bipartisan way, about the fact that people may be unrealistic to aspire to a full‐time job. It is a thought that neither you, Mr Deputy Speaker, nor I have had to contemplate in our working lives, but I wonder what will happen with the modern generation.

I also want to say a few things about the current tax debate. Firstly, the most important statement about taxation has not been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) or the Treasurer (Mr Costello) but by the Commissioner of Taxation. He said that the lack of people paying taxation, particularly in the black economy, is costing Australia, in his estimate, between $3 billion and $15 billion. Indeed, the Treasurer had to come in because he had said it was between $3 billion and $5 billion but it is between $3 billion and $15 billion.

I know that we have had billionaires address parliamentary committees saying, `Of course, any businessman will want to minimise and will have experts to minimise taxation.' But if we see this as a virtue, and people are able to succeed in doing that, it really means that governments—whether it is your government or my government—will not have the money to put into infrastructure, education and other areas. If we want to have a taxation debate, we need to focus on this issue. Even if this estimate of between $3 billion and $15 billion is half right, we are still talking about $1½ to $7 billion. I have noticed when we get estimates like this that they tend to be very conservative and that, in fact, the figure is much higher.

The other point that needs to be made is whether Australia should be moving to a goods and services tax and whether a goods and services tax would obviate the concern about the tax money. Indeed, those countries that have a goods and services tax still have this problem. So it is, if you like, indifferent to the type of taxation you have—whether it is wholesale sales tax, income tax, the company tax regime that we have in Australia or a GST as in some other countries.

I notice that very soon after this budget was delivered the Prime Minister got into saying, `Tax is back on the agenda.' I suppose if we are genuinely interested in the issue of taxation—particularly on the Labor side—it puts us in a difficult position. Firstly, it is a matter of history that we tried to have a taxation summit. We tried to get all of the interested players in Australia into Canberra to discuss what needed to be done and to put options before that tax summit.

I notice that some Liberal members have been very keen to pull out from the Hansard statements that I have made. It embarrasses me not in the slightest to say that I was an advocate of option C at that time. I really believed that we should be trying to overcompensate those people on fixed incomes. But history has shown that it was the business community, in particular, which was the critical body that walked away from the taxation debate and reform.

I think, in retrospect, they have bitterly regretted that because the climate was ideal then to introduce it. John Hewson, as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, certainly did that in 1993, and I have always admired people who have the courage to put political ideas in the marketplace. Indeed, some say that the coalition was robbed of victory in that, but we had hardened our attitude to the GST.

If there is going to be a sensible debate in this country on taxation reform, you cannot do it in isolation from the opposition. If there is going to be a sensible taxation debate in this country, we cannot try to use it as a method of political point scoring. That is, the opposition of the day, one way or another, is going to have to be included. Maybe it gets me no brownie points praising the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) for his idea of a parliamentary committee, but I have to say that I feel there is some merit in his suggestion. On the Labor side, we want to explore all the issues of tax minimisation and tax evasion, matters given even more relevance by the Taxation Commissioner's comments about the black economy. We have, of course, also a great interest in those wealthiest 100 people. So we would want to take the committee through all those issues before we would want to make a leap to a change.

But I have noticed that you can have some very controversial issues before a parliamentary committee without necessarily fracturing what I think is one of the essential qualities of these committees. We are not trying to score points in a partisan way as members of the Liberal, National or Labor parties, or as Democrats, but as members of the House or Senate we are trying to come to grips with a critical issue or problem and to find worthwhile solutions.

But time is running out on that debate and time is running out for sensibly encompassing the opposition in a debate about taxation. I have to agree with the Treasurer—again, I apologise and hope that this does not lead to any attacks by my colleagues. Taxation is not going to solve the country's unemployment and growth problems. Yes, it is always worthwhile looking at tax, its equity and its fairness. But it is not going to solve what are the hardcore problems in this economy.

We had a good and a bad thing announced in the savings arena in this budget. The good thing is that a government has stood up and wanted to reward savings. And, like the previous coalition speaker, I do not think there is any debate in the country about the need to increase personal and national savings, but there is certainly a debate about the best way to go about it.

I want to put on the record that the coalition has for the first time rewarded savings but, in doing so, members of the coalition have broken a fundamental promise. The coalition—and I am reading from the election manifesto on superannuation and retirement incomes policy—said:
The coalition will meet the government's—
that is the Labor government's—
co‐contribution commitment.

Part and parcel of introducing this savings scheme was to abandon the coalition's policy statement made in March 1996 by John Howard. This is flip‐flop, this is inconsistency and hypocrisy. I think that it is regrettable because it lowers our standing when you do this. I need to point out the impact of what you have done.

If you take a worker on average weekly earnings—and the majority of workers do not earn average weekly earnings—he or she would have been contributing $1,000 towards his or her superannuation. It would have been fully matched by $1,000 co‐payment. So the first year the government gave $1,000; next year it gave another $1,000, matching the $1,000 year after year. The best this worker can do by making the same contribution towards his superannuation under your savings scheme is to get $150, not $450. I do not think it is extreme to say that in breaking this solemn pledge the coalition made at the last election, a worker on average weekly earnings is actually having $850 ripped off their future retirement incomes policy.

I have said in this House before that I was proud of the things that we had done in terms of superannuation. They were not perfect, too many changes—make all those criticisms—but I was proud because we were well on the way in terms of superannuation savings of providing huge funds for investment, and investment equals jobs in this country.

It is history repeating itself I regret to say. It was the Menzies government that absolutely destroyed the fully funded superannuation scheme that older Australians remember so well—the national welfare fund. I can understand the coalition coming in after 13 years with a lot of enthusiasm and new ideas, but in an area so important for people in their old age and so important nationally for our economy, I think it is a tragedy that they would once again, by a number of measures, not just this one, absolutely destroy Labor's superannuation plans. We are going to see as a result fewer people contributing to superannuation than they were under what was a legislated or, if you like, compulsory scheme. I know their party stands for choice, but no matter how much money people have, if they are raising families there are always reasons to spend extra money on the children, instead of setting it aside for the future. The children will always be first priority.

Last but not least, the Treasurer takes a great deal of satisfaction in some of the benefits of low interest rates. He says to new home owners, `Look, on an average loan, you are saving $292.' And that is true. But I want to make the point that not everyone is buying their home and those people that are in rented accommodation have not seen those savings. Thirty per cent of Australians who usually have the least amount of income compared to home owners are not getting an extra $75 a week. Ask the pensioners who are in housing department accommodation—their rents have gone up. I am not saying saving home owners mortgage repayments is a bad thing. Of course I am not. But I am saying those sorts of savings are not being passed on to each and every Australian. I wish the Treasurer might just remember that when he justifiably with some pride talks about lowering interest rates. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak today. Before discussing the budget, there are just a number of issues on which I would like to comment. Two weeks ago there was a terrible car accident. My mother was killed instantly and my father was very seriously injured. They have both been special people to their immediate and extended families. The sympathy and kindness extended to me by my family, friends and colleagues on both sides of the House, my constituents and community leaders with whom I work, are very much appreciated and I thank them.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been recent publicity that Labor and the Democrats will block the sale of Australian National in the Senate and also in the Legislative Council in South Australia. I hope this proves to be wrong and that good sense will prevail. Any members or senators from South Australia who seek to block the sale will be guilty of an act of treachery against South Australia. The Australian National workers know and understand this. They knew what was going wrong at AN well before the Brew report. They knew that Labor had let them down badly.

For some time now I have been working with AN employees at Islington to get not only the best deal for them, but also solutions to ensure a viable rail industry. I have appreciated the working relationship and the trust which has developed. While senators and upper house members are no doubt fine people, they do not have the opportunity to represent as personally and directly those who live and work in one's own electorate as we in the House of Representatives do.

I challenge any senator or upper house member who thinks it will be a smart thing to block the sale to come with me and meet with the men who work there—those men who knew what was going wrong when the previous Labor minister was claiming that all was well.

In the past few days I have had more than 20 written submissions from AN workers on the sale of AN. I have been assured that faxes have also been sent to the shadow minister so I do hope he is sharing that information with Labor's leadership. I would like to quote some of what has been sent to me. It says:

It is my belief that Australian National should be sold because we, the employees, are sick and tired of being in limbo. Labor started the demise of Australian National with the introduction of the National Rail Corporation and are now extending the agony by blocking the sale of Australian National in the Senate. I think it is unfair to prolong the uncertainty and urge you and your fellow ministers—
unfortunately, I have been promoted—
to do all in your power to allow this sale process to continue with the sale taking place as soon as possible. I believe that it is our only hope to some sort of future in the industry.

I think that it would be fair and equitable that ALL Australian National employees be made redundant and the choice of employment with the purchasers be left to the successful tender and the relevant individuals.
That letter is signed by A. S. Crimes, locomotive maintenance. Another letter reads:
Can you please answer the following questions because I cannot possibly see any political mileage in the non‐sale of the skeletal remains of Australian National.

1. Why is the Federal Labor Opposition opposed to the sale of Australian National when it was a Labor government that started the demise of Australian National with the introduction of the National Rail Corporation?
2. Why doesn't the Federal opposition allow the sale of Australian National so that employees know where they stand so they can plan their futures instead of being used as a political punching bag?

This is signed by D. Platten, locomotive electrical. As the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has already pointed out, Labor's failure to understand the workers at Port Augusta and Islington—the bulk of AN workers—and their support for the sale of AN shows how out of touch and how arrogant Labor is. Labor sold the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas but now wants to play political games which will hurt AN workers and their families. For AN to have a future, it needs new capital injection, new management and new direction. Again, I challenge those who would block the sale to come and talk business with those who know the full story.

On a much happier note, I am pleased to report that the first monument to South Australia's ex‐service women of World War II is in place, prominently displayed on King William Street. On 20 April, when I unveiled the monument, I said:

Today is also the culmination of a two year battle for funding through to today's final unveiling and dedication. In the beginning there seemed to be insurmountable difficulties, but as good people and the three levels of Government began to co‐operate and work together, the ex‐servicewomen's dream became a reality—they now have their very own monument.

I would like to acknowledge the State Minister, Diana Laidlaw, for the funding delivered and project management provided by Art for Public Places. The Adelaide City Council, in addition to assistance with funding, also helped with site preparation.

The Australian Women's Army Service of South Australia provided $1,000. There was another $1,000 from the combined efforts of the Ex‐Prisoners of War Association and their women's auxiliary and the second‐third gun Battalion.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Bruce Scott, has also asked me to convey his best wishes. I know he was very impressed with the efforts of everyone involved in this project and was pleased to be able to assist, under the Commemorative Activities Program, with a grant of $7,000.
Of course today's ceremony would not have been possible without the commitment and unfailing dedication of delegates of the Council of United Ex‐Service Women of South Australia.

The Council's objectives of maintaining the bonds of friendship, preserving the memory and record of those who have died, and preserving the interests and standing of women serving in the navy, army and air force are truly reflected in this project. This is in addition to the very valuable work members do in assisting and advising the ex‐servicewomen and helping them with their accommodation needs, such as the independent living units in Lower Mitcham.

A special commendation must go to your President, Coral Farrelly. She has been the backbone, the driver of this magnificent project—a tribute to the war time efforts of her countrywomen. For more than 2 years she has continued to lobby for this memorial, inspiring those around her and enlisting the willing help of delegates to ensure the well‐earned recognition of local women who served our country during World War II.
Today your efforts have been rewarded. This monument, the first in South Australia, will be a lasting memorial to those women who enlisted in the Defence Forces of Australia between 1939 and 1945.

The monument is the work of local artist Janette Moor. It features Coral Farrelly, Women's Auxiliary Air Force; Jean Copley, Women's Royal Australian Naval Service; Helen Heathcott, Australian Women's Army Services; Cora Sinclair, Australian Army Medical Women's Service; and Betty Bradwell, Australian Army Nursing Service representing the nurses of the three nursing services. It is wonderful to see them here today to witness this unveiling and dedication ceremony.

There is not one person here today who has not been touched in some way by the events of World War II. It was a catalyst for major, social and economic change. It is part of our history, our heritage and the price we paid for the freedom we enjoy today.

This monument is a lasting memorial to the thousands of South Australian women whose courage, commitment and dedication in all theatres of war during World War II helped shape our nation. We salute you.
It was a gratifying experience to be involved with this project over a couple of years and to see the end product.

The member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) still manages to damage Australia's international reputation and at a local level causes division and hurt. I have said before that I believe the issues of reconciliation, of indigenous health and education and Commonwealth funding to Aboriginal communities and individuals are far too important to be underresearched or incorrectly represented. Everyone has the right to engage in the debate surrounding these issues but, if positive public policy is the desired result, the dialogue must be based on accurate information.

If the member for Oxley had drawn attention to the large amount of money spent in some areas which have clearly not advanced the wellbeing of Aborigines, and sought ways to improve their health, education and special needs, I could have agreed with her. If she had called for a calm, sensible look at immigration, including issues such as sham marriage arrangements and the balance between skilled migration and family reunion, she could have legitimately been part of the debate. She did neither.

BREAK.PARA: What she has done is introduce a number of untruths into current racial debates which may be immediately palatable to some sections of the community left isolated from Paul Keating's big picture, but they divide and they hurt. The member for Oxley has challenged anyone to tell her how Aborigines are disadvantaged: Aboriginal people have a shorter life expectancy, are more prone to disease and poverty, have a poorer standard of housing, and are more likely to go to jail and to be unemployed. Disease, effectively controlled in white society, still runs rampant in some rural and remote Aboriginal communities. Aboriginal people have a one in three chance of living to the age of 65.

The member for Oxley also claims that we are in danger of being swamped by Asians. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for 1991 show that 0.5 per cent of people in Australia were born in China; 0.3 per cent in Hong Kong; 0.4 per cent in Malaysia; 0.4 in the Philippines; 0.7 per cent in Vietnam. These figures hardly indicate that we are being swamped by Asians. In looking for a cure to Australia's dole queues, the member for Oxley says that immigration must be halted. However, academic research suggests that immigration has a neutral or slightly positive effect on unemployment. It is also common knowledge that part of the solution for Australia's economic problem is a greater push into the huge Asian market.

The member for Oxley's comments have the potential to economically harm the very people she claims to be standing up for, namely, hardworking Australians. The member for Oxley would have us return to the White Australia Policy, and she quotes one time Labor Party leader, Arthur Calwell, to make her point but on other occasions she asks us to forget the past. She hits out at Asian immigrants, claiming that they have their own culture and religion—as if that were a crime. She seems to have forgotten that, apart from indigenous Australians, we are all immigrants, all with different backgrounds and beliefs.

In relation to the United Nations, she says Australia must review its membership. I would argue that, five years after the end of the Cold War, it has never been more important for Australia to contribute in this international forum. As a result of a recent Australian initiative, more than 100 countries have signed a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty.

The member for Oxley further claims that the government should cease all foreign aid immediately. Her call is completely out of step with the vast majority of compassionate Australians. Compassion has been sadly lacking in the public utterances by the member for Oxley. She also attacks the World Health Organisation. Apart from providing aid on very good humanitarian grounds, there are many practical reasons why Australia should contribute to reproductive health strategies, the alleviation of hunger and famine, immunisation programs and the eradication of infectious diseases before they can impact on our own population.

Perhaps one of the most extraordinary claims made by her is that abolishing the policy of multiculturalism will save billions of dollars. Dr Mark Wooden, Deputy Director of Labour Studies at Flinders University, has been quoted as saying:
There has yet to be a credible academic analysis of the fundamental cost and benefits of multiculturalism.

The key idea of multicultural Australia is that migrants should be able to retain and celebrate their individual cultural heritage while at the same committing themselves to the values, goals and aspirations of Australia. This has resulted in an Australia we can all be proud of for its diversity, tolerance and understanding.

We live in a world of rapid change—my parents rode horses to school and my son communicates on the Internet. There can be country to country instant exchange of information. We must be seen internationally as an attractive democracy. The member for Oxley, and those who support her, would have us live in isolation. We cannot do that. Change must be embraced and used to our benefit.

Australia requires a highly skilled work force because there are clever ways of doing old things. We not only export traditional products, but also mining equipment and mining services, medical equipment and medical services. Tourism and overseas students are an important component of our economy. I would urge the member for Oxley to start thinking about what is good for our country rather than what is good for her own promotion and publicity. I would also urge the people of Adelaide to not protest violently against her next week when she lobs into town—that just gives her further publicity. There will be an opportunity to celebrate cultural diversity, and that is the more appropriate way to go.

The economic mess left behind by Labor cannot be reversed overnight. It is dangerous to believe or argue that it can be. Simplistic solutions put forward by the member for Oxley and those who oppose budgetary constraint shown by this government in its effort to reduce the national debt do their fellow Australians no favours at all.

Phil Raskell, writing in 1993 in the Australian Left Review, lamented that `there is no quick fix' and that the trends in social and economic inequality followed long-term cycles. But Labor, as he and other supporters of the opposition well know, had 13 years to reverse those trends. Far from improving or even stabilising the growth in disparity between the rich and the poor, Labor presided over unprecedented growth in inequality and isolation from the political process. Little wonder that the voices of hate and division, such as those of the member for Oxley, are now given media and public attention, unjustified by the facts.
Alternatively, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is in the position, as suggested by David Pemberthy of the Advertiser:
. . . of having taken impressive strides towards returning the Budget to balance and receiving little credit for it.

The key election promise of the Howard government was to return the budget to surplus in its first term in office. With $7.2 billion in reduced expenditure in the last budget and a further $1.7 billion reduction in this year's budget, that objective is now within reach. In 1995, almost 20 per cent of the gross domestic product of Australia each year had to be accounted for by way of debt. By the year 2000, the coalition government will have cut that commitment in half. This will free up valuable resources to meet the challenge of the new century with money that has been created by Australians for Australians.

If you are a young person, you need economic honesty on the part of the government in order to have economic opportunity in your lifetime. No country can remain prosperous or sustain a level of lifestyle such as that enjoyed here in Australia if the current generation cheat their children by leaving them crippled by debt. If we do not reduce debt we will be responsible for mortgaging their inheritance. In doing so, we will have compromised their opportunities, freedoms and, perhaps most critical of all, the safety nets that support us all when we are unemployed, sick or elderly.

If we as a parliament can get this right, Australia has the opportunity in the 21st century to be both prosperous and inclusive, a more diverse yet vastly superior society. That is an opportunity that should not be confined by partisan bickering and negative campaigning. Nor is it the preserve of any individual, no matter what their position. It is a matter of all Australians standing a little bit taller. Our future and that of our children is worth that extra effort. For its part, this coalition government intends to break a vicious cycle. This year, for the first time in nearly a decade, the Commonwealth will not go into debt.

All over the electorate, many families are enjoying the benefits of interest rates being at their lowest level since man first walked on the moon. Let us not forget that during the 1980s, business interest rates hit 24 per cent and home interest rates peaked at 17 per cent. Since coming to power this government has saved business about $3.6 billion in interest payments. It has also put local economies on the path of long term, rather than on the boom-bust cycle that was typical under Labor.

Also saving is now a real option for many residents in Adelaide. Saving rates are not exclusively related to levels of disposable income. Currently lower income earners have no incentive to save and it is little wonder they may choose to spend any disposable income on other lifestyle choices.

By 1998, however, this government will have delivered a 15 per cent tax rebate for the first $3,000 of taxable income from savings or personal contributions to superannuation funds. A study undertaken by Bankers Trust has shown that people earning less than $40,000 held 70 per cent of all savings incomes, which is eligible for the rebate. Again, lower middle income earners, about six million of them, are the winners in this budget by having a coalition government which stands for real equity and fairness.

Older members of the Adelaide community have also benefited from this budget. For the first time, the government has budgeted for pensions to be held at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. Self‐retired members of the community will also be able to access the 15 per cent savings rebate on the tax they pay. Those who choose to continue in the work force after they reach 65 years of age and subsequently qualify for the single age pension will qualify for up to $21,000 tax free under the deferred pension bonus plan. This offers older members of the community real choice about their lifestyle and provides added security.
From July 1998, all Australians will be given greater choice about the fund or retirement savings account, where their superannuation guarantee or contributions are invested.

The increase of the domiciliary care benefit of 28 per cent or $16.60 a fortnight to a level similar to the child disability allowance is also welcomed by the many dedicated carers in Adelaide. On top of the $36.7 million that this government allocated in the last budget to implement the national respite for carers plan, a further $16 million has been allocated to go directly to supporting carers and those they assist in the community.
The coalition's economic strategy is an insurance policy for the future. It is not paying for an unsustainable future with money that has not been earned. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford, Rod, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I first want to simply say to the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), congratulations on your contribution today, which was made in pretty difficult circumstances following the tragic loss of your mother and severe injuries to your father in a road accident. I can well understand. I remember losing an aunt of mine on the Karoonda Road when a car rolled over in 1983. She was my second mother basically. I know that today and for quite a while into the future it will be quite difficult, so I congratulate you. Well done.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, talking to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) today really has a touch of the weird and the bizarre. One could be excused for believing that you are on the set of a science fiction series like X‐Files, trying to identify a UFO—not an unidentified flying object, but an unfinished operation or, to put it more bluntly, a useless financial offer to the Australian people.

BREAK.PARA: I cannot remember a budget that disappeared so quickly and sank into the swamp. No wonder that happened. For some reason, known only to themselves, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) thought that a mere outcome driven budget, without any rationale whatsoever, without any coherence whatsoever, would be accepted by the commentators and the electorate. Desperate about the rising number of nervous nellies on the back bench now realising they had little to sell in the electorate, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer sought alternative agendas.

On the run, they manufactured and reworked the GST debate and tax reform to fill the hole they had so dramatically dug for themselves. On the run, the Prime Minister addressed angrily an equally angry group of pastoralists at Longreach. On the run, an angry Prime Minister resorted to simply that at the reconciliation convention in Melbourne. These diversions and these behaviours exhibited by the Prime Minister were deliberately initiated to desperately dig his government out of the hole he had dug for his government.

This 1997 budget is almost universally acknowledged as nothing more than a do nothing, directionless, shapeless, vision lacking statement that actually absented itself from addressing the major issues identified by Australians prior to the 1996 election. Unlike what the government promised, this budget is evidence for all to see of an absence of responsibility to assume leadership and originality.

Prior to the budget, 70 per cent of Australians considered that the government's first task was seriously to tackle unemployment and to implement strategies other than just the economic levers to create jobs. The government's response to this budget is simply breathtaking and cynical in the extreme, with one mention of unemployment—just one sentence.

The tragedy of unemployment is one of the modern developed world. However, it is a problem that, if not effectively addressed, will lead to civil disorder of the sort we saw on our television screens in Sydney the other night. Current economic orthodoxies or, indeed, past economic orthodoxies appear incapable of solving the problem. Just fiddling around with the economic levers and economic growth alone will not solve the unemployment problem. Yet the fundamental role of a nation's economy is to provide job opportunities to all who want them. Basically I am horrified at the general response to unemployment in this country—not only of this government but also of the leaders of business, of the bureaucracy, of academia and of the media.

There are creative solutions to unemployment that are put forward from all sections of the community but they seldom see the light of day. The so‐called logic of the market prevails to the detriment of almost 20 per cent of the Australian community. These critics take little or no account of the social costs of unemployment—increased crime and suicide—nor do they mention an inefficient economy with high unemployment, occupational health and safety problems, lost productivity caused by boredom and fatigue and increased compensation claims and redundancies.

The simple fact of the matter is that job creation is beyond the imagination and the skill level of this government. Unemployment in this country has risen to 8¾ per cent, the so‐called official rate, but well under the real rate of about 13 per cent plus. Youth unemployment in my state is a staggering 42 per cent. It is outrageous—42 per cent youth unemployment in South Australia. I get the distinct impression from this government that it wants to get a so‐called official rate of unemployment like that in the United States—five or six per cent—but it ignores the four per cent in prison, the up to four per cent permanently engaged in crime and the up to four per cent on the streets.

In the first year of the Howard government, unemployment actually increased. There are 31,500 more people on the dole queue than there were at the last election. The number of long‐term unemployed, a more worrying feature, has risen by 44,000. Yet not once in the budget speech did the Treasurer even mention unemployment.

I am the first one to admit that the election result in 1996 clearly demonstrated that people wanted a change in government, but it has not been a change for the better on jobs. In this coming year, Australians look to a worsening unemployment rate: 16,500 Public Service jobs will be lost; nearly 9,500 defence jobs will go; 1,000 Medicare staff go; and 700 meat inspectors from AQIS will go. In addition to those job losses, 12,000 jobs are threatened in Australia's pharmaceutical industry, not to mention the jobs in the steel industry and a threatened loss of jobs in the car industry and its component parts industry. To cap it all off, one only has to raise the coalition's promise of an additional 200,000 jobs in manufacturing by the year 2000. Now that was a pretty admirable aim, but it will never be attained by this government because the minister and the government believe there is no role whatsoever for government in manufacturing industry.

The 1996 budget saw a $2.9 billion assault on assistance programs to industry, but this budget gives no sign whatsoever of any rethink of industry policy. What there is though is a massive projected decline in assistance to manufacturing industry. From 1997‐98 to 2000-01, assistance to manufacturing will decline from $561 million to $146 million.

Government members have a much bigger role to play in stimulating growth, development and job creation than merely sitting on their hands, wearing smirks on their faces, mouthing empty words and being self-satisfied that low inflation and low interest rates will solve the unemployment problem. It will not. This government needs to engage its intellect. The Australian people expect this government to lead, to accept responsibility for the levels of unemployment in this country. The 1997‐98 budget is shameful in that unemployment is totally ignored.

Over the last three weeks, my staff and I have examined very carefully the Howard government's budget in order to see just how it has affected people in my electorate of Port Adelaide. I have to say our findings are very disturbing. I have already pointed out this budget offers absolutely nothing for those seeking work, or even hoping to secure work. But it offers little or nothing for pensioners either, and little or nothing for the overwhelming majority of families in my electorate. It offers no sense of direction for Australia. Hope, that very fragile piece of human behaviour, is diminished.

By the government's own figures, economic growth and jobs growth have stalled. We have a growth rate of 2.4 per cent. That means unemployment will continue to rise. And this is at a time when the country needs strong and innovative leadership to lift us out of the doldrums, to provide opportunities, and above all, to offer hope for a more secure future.

This is particularly true in my state of South Australia, as it was acknowledged by the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), who was here just a moment ago, when she said in a subheading in her column in the Australian yesterday:
The domestic car industry already has a loaded gun to its head.
Quite correctly, and with other government backbenchers, she points out:
The electoral backlash would result in the loss of two, perhaps three, seats in South Australia and an equal number in Victoria.
Quite correctly again, she implores the government to get into the real world. She said, and it is a very good quote to put into the Hansard :

In the real world, as the State premiers and local MPs know, labour leaving the automotive industry doesn't move into other industries but goes on the dole. Capital taken out of the automotive industry doesn't move to other industries but goes offshore.
Exactly. The government ignores reality and the real world at its peril.

Fifteen months of this government have meant a litany of broken promises involving health care, education, the environment, industry policy, jobs training and welfare services. As a result, the trust of the Australian people has been breached, and this budget further breaches that trust. The frail aged in our community have been let down. About $500 million has been cut from aged care services. The cost of nursing home care has soared and people requiring care, despite what some government members say, may now be required to sell their family home to pay for it. That is a broken promise.

The cost of medicines for pensioners and concession card holders has gone up and will soon go up again. The budget slashes $700 million from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, and this is on top of a cut of $500 million from last year. Only the wealthy will get access to the latest drugs through the imposition of a new drugs tax of up to $20 a prescription. The battlers and pensioners are to get the drugs that they can afford. An amount of $600 million is to be saved by making it more expensive for Australians to get drugs to lower blood pressure, cholesterol, treat ulcers and depression. A few of us will be paying a bit more, Mr Deputy Speaker. An amount of $112 million is to be saved by abolishing the subsidy for a number of medicines. Pensioners will pay up to $9 more for these medicines as they will no longer be protected by the $3.20 payment.

The government that brags it governs for all Australians is a bit over the top when it comes to the closure of Medicare offices, one of which is Kilkenny and located in my electorate of Port Adelaide. Of the 44 offices to close, 24 are in Labor seats, and 14 are in seats that were previously held by Labor and in the not too distant future will come back. There are just six closures in what could be termed safe Liberal seats.

So begins a two‐tiered health system under the coalition. They have a two‐tiered education system. Why not a two‐tiered health system? Why not a two‐tiered social welfare system? One for the rich, who will get the newest, safest and most effective drugs and another for battling Australians who will have to make do with cheaper, less effective and less safe drugs. This is nothing but a new medicines tax.

On the surface, if I can mention a better thing, it is welcome news that the budget allocates $54 million for additional accommodation for people with disabilities. However, like everything the government does, one needs to read past the big print. This allocation is severely tempered by the 1996 cut of $80 million and the introduction of user fees which cost older and disabled people $90 million. In other words, $54 million in return for a cut of $170 million.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have only ever shown contempt for education in this country. So I suppose no‐one should be surprised that promises to education should be broken in such a dramatic way. About $400 million away from schools, $250 million from vocational education, $900 million from universities. Add in the additional burden of HECS charges on families trying to provide a decent education for their children, the $2 billion from jobs programs and all will begin to appreciate the lack of wisdom of this government in ignoring the need of this country to develop an appropriate skills based work force.

For younger children, the reality gets worse. The government's 1996 budget took almost $800 million, $500 million out of child care. The 1997 budget continues the trend in taking out a further $321 million out of child care. Working parents will find it even harder to afford quality child care and it will put it out of the reach of ordinary families. Increases from the 1996 budget of $20 to $40 dollars a week in child care fees are now beginning to bite and many families with young children will and are being forced to abandon child care.

This in turn will force closures of child‐care centres and even more job losses and the closures are beginning. In my electorate tomorrow on 6 June 1997, the sixth child‐care centre in South Australia closes, the Parks. It closes its door to the local community. The Adelaide Advertiser reported the story yesterday. It said:
The worst part of Lisa de Vries' day—
and Lisa de Vries is the director—
is when distraught parents start crying at the Parks Child Centre. . . `The impact on people's lives is enormous'. . . `Parents are looking at pulling out of work and study to look after their kids.
It's devastating for the whole community.'

The Parks Child Care Centre is the sixth South Australia child‐care centre to close in . . . six months . . . `They simply cannot afford the fees so we have fewer and fewer children coming. This centre is viable but the hike in fees has ultimately destroyed it'
`I'm incredibly angry,' said mother‐of‐two Ms Julie Martin yesterday.
`The Liberal Government has shown an astounding lack of concern for the low‐income earners in Australia.
`They're just taking away from the people who need it most.'
The State Minister—
Liberal—
for Education and Children's Services, Mr Lucas, . . . was very concerned by the decision.
`We have expressed our concerns about the removal of operational subsidies in some of the rural and lower socio‐economic areas to the Federal Government'—

Labor's superannuation scheme has been abandoned, taking $3.7 million from the pockets of working people and replaced with a savings rebate which will be of no benefit at all to most Australians—another broken promise. The savings rebate is an example of how the very well‐off will benefit, while most Australians will get nothing or next to nothing. The superannuation will go to those with about $60,000 sitting in the bank earning interest.
A cartoon in the Australian Financial Review summed up the savings rebate pretty well. A mother of two young children says to her husband sitting at the table:

I've worked it out. If we cut back on groceries and heating, if I go back to work full time and we sell the Corolla then we just might scrape up the $3,000 in savings necessary to get the tax rebate of—
wait for it—

That is less than 50c a week. The well‐off get the $450 rebate, including all of us, but meanwhile working people in their mid‐30s on average weekly earnings will lose about $110,000 of the lump sum they would have had at retirement under Labor's superannuation scheme.

The well‐off get a $450 rebate, but families get next to nothing. Full‐rate age pensioners get nothing but increases in a medicines tax. This is a government that is very fast running out of excuses. Many of them believe they are looking forward to what we call the `lolly budget'—the `gimme' or the pork‐barrel budget—in 1998 and that will save the nervous Nellies and fool the electorate. I see the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) nods. He is one of those believers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to sleep!

—I am not so sure. The member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) too? Interesting—we will see what happens. I believe the role of government is much more serious than this government shows it to be. It should maximise opportunities for people; this budget minimises opportunities. It ought to enhance a sense of security and confidence in the future; this government does exactly the opposite. It ought to try and create a unified, responsive and compassionate nation—and I acknowledge the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) who in a speech here earlier said basically the same thing. Yet every announcement by this government works against the basic ideals that I think are the strength of this country and that are being threatened by some rather mad and alternative groups of people.

BREAK.PARA: Instead of promoting unity, this government is promoting division, even if it is unintentional, because it will not take the responsibility for what is going on in our nation. Instead of creating opportunities, they are wiping out jobs. Instead of leading, they are merely content to meddle with the status quo. It is interesting that the Prime Minister and Treasurer quite often will mention outcome, outcome, outcome. That is fine. But where is the rationale and the coherence, where are the necessary processes that make that trinity of thought and action coherent to the people of Australia? They are merely absent. I think that is what is most disturbing about this budget and about the direction of this government.

This is a government seemingly intent on punishing those most in need of assistance. It is a government which has broken promise after promise that it made to people at the last election, and it is a government that is fast running out of excuses. I think a lot of people, even some in my own electorate, who voted for a change at the last election are seeing, or will come to see, that it has not been a change for the better. When they examine the job opportunities and their job security, I do not think people are feeling calm and relaxed. When age pensioners and people on concessions and other benefits feel the impact of this budget, they will be no better off, they will be worse off. Families, which this government purports to support so grandly, are going to be gravely disappointed. I do not think a lolly budget at the next election will save many people on the government back bench. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —After 13 years of Labor and a tirade of broken promises, it must have been refreshing for Australians to see a budget that delivered no new taxes. There was no increase in income tax, no increase in sales tax, no increase in company tax, no increase in excise on petrol and diesel. I take issue with my colleague the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford): of course in every budget you have to look at inequities that grow up in the system. Part of the reason there are reductions in child care is that his government allowed child care to run on completely unfettered. In fact, I think I opened four child‐care centres in the last 18 months to two years.

SPEECH.PARA: I applaud child care, I applaud women having a choice in going to work, but what I did find unacceptable was that one of the child‐care centres that came to complain to me had to admit that 68 per cent of the children in that centre were the children of parents neither of whom worked. You, I and all of us in here, and all the taxpayers of Australia, pay for that. If that had to be pulled back a bit, that is not being mean or mean‐spirited; that is correcting an inequity.

Why should people who are not working not take responsibility for their kids—and I am not talking about people with crippled kids, or about dysfunctional families; I am talking about the broad cross‐section. I will just add another little point there. We cut back the number of hours for those people to 20. You have criticised that. Interestingly, however, in your own package two years ago, you were prepared to cut back the number of hours to 12. So at least we are being more generous in spirit than the previous government.

But returning to my text: for years the Labor Party was on a path of debt and deficit. In 1983 the foreign debt was $23 billion. Thirteen years on, it was $180 billion. Labor thought that there was no problem. Higher foreign debt means higher interest rates and higher mortgages for families and small businesses. Australians, becoming increasingly nervous about the state of our national and international debt, must have been relieved on the morning after the budget to see that the $10.3 billion black hole would be filled and that Australia returned to a budget surplus of $1.6 billion in the first term of the coalition government. By cutting debt, we have cut interest rates, and that is good for families, for small business, and for creating jobs. For the first time in more than 10 years, the Commonwealth government will not have run up a debt. Repaying a debt means that our children and future generations live more securely.

The other side of this equation is that the coalition government has brought stability to Australia over the last 15 months. Remember that under Labor in 1989, home loan interest rates reached a massive 17 per cent. The current rates are around seven per cent. That is the lowest since 1969 and a great confidence booster, I would think, to Australian families. Eight years on from Labor's mid‐term extravagances, a $100,000 home loan is $834 a month less expensive.

Put in terms of my electorate, the coalition home loan regime, in combination with the tax cuts that came into effect on 1 January, will mean that the average young Australian family, with three children, one under five years, paying off a typical home loan, will be somewhere in the vicinity of $60 to $90 a week better off than they were nine months ago. That is an extraordinary figure. When I was bringing up five kids, I would have loved to have had another $60 or $90 a week—and I brought up five kids so I know exactly what that sort of thing means. If they want to pay their loans off a bit early, it is still a good thing. Add to this an inflation rate of less than two per cent and you have all the ingredients for a full recovery, one that really respects the battlers of Australia and the families of those battlers.

Those who know my views on regional development know that I am a trenchant critic of the denuding of the bush and the centralising of services away from provincial cities. I will punish my own party, or my own government, as much as any previous government, if I see this happening. A typical example of this denuding happened during the time of the Goss Labor government in Queensland. Once you start to close court houses, remove DPI offices, reduce police strength and pull up railway lines, you create a downward spiral with irreversible impact on the infrastructure and the motivation of a community. It is not long, as people know, before it flows on to other government agencies. A school loses a teacher and then the local business puts off one or two employees and the thing goes down.

A couple of months ago I drove from Goondiwindi to Warwick in the Southern Downs. Warwick was my home town when I was growing up, so I know that area reasonably well. We passed through a little town of Yelarbon and it sent a chill through me. There it was, this once bustling little town, and hardly a shop was open. They were all empty. I am not talking about little cheap wooden shops; I am talking about solid buildings with quite good plate glass windows. I looked at these empty shops and hoped that they were not a portent of things to come.

For that reason, I applaud a range of measures which will play an important role in the regeneration of rural Australia. Ninety per cent of the $1.6 billion to be spent on roads will be spent outside the capital cities. This includes $700 million on the national highway and $36.7 million on the black spots project. Two roads in my electorate—one near Monto and another one in the Boyne Valley—will receive $510,000.

This will be very important to the Monto‐Gladstone road, which has become a significant corridor for agriculture and logging and might also lead to more mining activity. To see a dangerous road in an area like that removed is a godsend, and I applaud the government for that—as, indeed, I applaud them for the previously announced $24 million for the Wallaville Bridge in my electorate, a winding timber bridge that crosses the Burnett River, one of the last dangerous bridges on the Pacific and Bruce highways and one much in need of replacement.

The coalition has made a promise in the lead‐up to the election to spend a great deal on the regeneration of the environment, and the $1.2 billion Natural Heritage Fund which will come from the partial sale of Telstra is also most welcome. The clean seas and coastal initiatives have already started to take effect in my electorate. We are on the southern gateway to the Great Barrier Reef, and so these things are very important to us. Already $30,000 has been spent on coastal preservation projects in Bundaberg and Gladstone. These are community projects which encourage people to become involved in saving the coastline and marine life.

The budget will also deliver $16 million to local apprenticeships in regional Australia. One of the few groups I have stayed on since I got into politics is the local group apprenticeship scheme, because I think it is very important. I know that my fellow directors will applaud that move as well. Work for the dole pilot schemes are going into regional areas. As you know, 10,000 positions will become available in the coming months.

I would add that I hope the area of Hinkler, which is part of the Wide Bay statistical region, will be treated kindly. It is a sad fact that, when Labor left government, my area was the worst off in Australia. We had 20 per cent unemployment—worse than western Sydney. That rate has now dropped to 16.6 per cent, but it is still totally unacceptable. As it is twice the national rate, I appeal to the government to look to my area when it is handing out these pilot programs.

I have spoken on child care and I might not return to that, but I would very much like to talk about health. Prevention is always better than cure. Spending $34 million over the next four years on public health programs, such as the national women's health program, hepatitis C surveillance, education, the national cancer program and the anti‐tobacco campaign, will help what I think are very important aspects which will impact widely across Australia and particularly in my area.

Only half of Australia's children are fully immunised, and that is a lamentable position. I am saddened that the previous government did not recognise that. But $29 million over the next four years for an Immunise Australia program, including $15.6 million for hepatitis B vaccine for schoolchildren, will get Australia's immunisation rates up to Western standards. By increasing funding to local councils for immunisation clinics, Bundaberg has already seen an increase in immunisation rates. Rural areas in my electorate are typical of many in Australia, and I like to think that all areas—whether they are small or large—can have access to health.

This brings me to the need for the extra $15 million which has been promised for obstetric services in rural areas. It is quite often the case that people in rural hospitals have to come into provincial cities, because they cannot be sure that the appropriate medical attention will always be available. Also, where there are great difficulties, it is pleasing to know that not only will that money encourage obstetric services in some of the larger provisional areas but it will also give the opportunity to transfer difficult cases to the capital cities.

The Hinkler region, like many others, is suffering from a critical shortage of Australian doctors, and I applaud the $17.4 million provision for rural health services. This will be vital in growing communities like mine, where care is needed. The upgrading of hospitals, accommodation for doctors and nurses, clinics and incentives for specialists to come to the bush are also important aspects of this program.

I would like at this point to take issue with my colleague the member for Port Adelaide on the matter of pharmacy. Pharmacy is a very difficult area, as the previous government found, and as the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) highlighted in question time last week, when he pointed out all the drugs that the previous government was forced to take off the free list.

What has been proposed in the current budget are two things. One is that certain drugs that can be bought over the counter reasonably inexpensively, in the range of about $2.30 up to about $9—things like antispasmodics, anti‐diarrhoea mixtures, anti‐inflammatories and antifungals, which people can reasonably buy—should be taken off the free list. Rather than criticise this, I think it would be better to put a proposal—and I plan to do this some time in the near future—to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) that, where those pharmacy type lines are bought by people, they should be able to be added with prescriptions and hospital charges to your tax regime. At least that would ameliorate some of the cost for people who have to use, say, an antifungal or an antispasmodic on a regular basis, albeit that they may now buy it over the counter.

The other thing that is important about this is that the national pharmacy charge is increasing by a rate of 15 per cent a year in a climate where inflation is running at one or two per cent. I do not care what side of politics we are on: we cannot allow that to happen. We would exacerbate the health crisis if we were so irresponsible as to allow that to happen.

The other measure, and I suppose in some cases it will not be terribly palatable, is that where there are a series of drugs with the same chemical composition, the least expensive one will be covered by the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. If the patient or the doctor insists on another brand, you will pay the difference. The difference on average will be about $2. I do not think they are big things to ask to keep Australia's health program alive and well.

BREAK.PARA: Returning to my theme of provincial cities and country towns, I would like to commend the government for credit here. I have seen a lot of banks close and a lot of innovative councils buy those banks and invite credit unions to come and take them up. That is a very good move and I applaud having another $2.8 million to assist programs like that. It is very important in my area. I have at least two communities that have lost all their banking over the last three or four years. This will go some way to encouraging better services for communities like that.

Austudy is still a very difficult issue in my electorate. It is difficult for people on the land. The new program does not sit comfortably with certain families. I find that distressing. It is also so for people in small business. The spending test does not always catch the people that we want to get and sometimes I find it imposes a heavy strain on those families that really have no income, especially people from farms. I do not know how it happens, but when you take in the spending test with all its complexities, sometimes they seem to go over the limit and lose their Austudy. This will not correct the whole scene, but doubling the allowance for the second child and adding another $3,700 to the means test for other children will mean that a lot more people will have access to Austudy. I find that a very good move.

I would like to speak now about small business because this is one area that has needed a lot of attention. I commend the government for a number of measures, including previously dropping the uplift factor from eight per cent down to six per cent for small business. In the new budget, the withholding obligations for those with a PAYE tax bill of $25,000 or less being able to be paid on a three‐monthly basis rather than a monthly basis will greatly simplify matters for small business. There are also the exemptions from fringe benefits tax, where they click across at about the same numbers each year, on car parking. I commend all those measures for those little nitpicking things that have made life intolerable for small business.

The savings rebate scheme, which the member for Port Adelaide had a bit of a dig at, will also be very important to small business in savings that occur outside such matters as wages and so on. That will be a great tax saving for small businesses. It will also mean that family trusts, where the members of the family are beneficiaries, will not be caught up in any new regulations. There is a $130 million small business innovation program, and that will be good for my electorate as well.

Yesterday, the extension of drought aid was announced. I played a part in that and I am delighted that I did. It will be very important for the Isis, Kolan, Perry shires and the city of Bundaberg in my electorate. It will mean that the benefits that close down on 10 June this year will have a three‐month extension. In that three months, the new integrated rural policy package will cut in. There was a bit of a hiatus between the end of the old program and the new one, in respect of those areas that were already in drought. The continuation of the drought exceptional circumstances classification will be extended for the Banana, Calliope, Eidsvold, Isisford, Miriam Vale, Monto, Mundubbera and Nebo shires, some of which are in my electorate. That is recognition by the government that the drought is not over.

In the few minutes remaining to me, I would like to talk about a number of initiatives. The integrated rural policy package that I talked about before will deliver $190 million for such matters as rural adjustment and better planning in farm debt. With the fire blight and the fly in North Queensland—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is the white fly.

—It is not that, but it will come back to me in a minute. Fire blight is a very important issue. Having another $76 million for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to boost our quarantine arrangements, especially at our borders, will be welcomed by both sides of politics. I note that there is a decrease in the number of employees of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, but remember that some of those were in towns where the meatworks have now closed down. There is $44.3 million to totally restructure AQIS's meat inspection facilities.

BREAK.PARA: All in all, having ranged fairly widely in this speech, I think this has been a good budget. It has been good for rural Australia, good for regional development and good for the battlers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98, I think that some reflection is appropriate to fully understand the impact of this budget on my electorate of Namadgi and on the ACT. It is a matter of record that this government promised to govern for all Australians. It is a matter of record that early warnings were given throughout all of last year—and, I would be so bold as to say, throughout the election campaign as well, and again this year—that this government's policies were having a dramatic, unacceptable and intolerable effect on this community.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in the debate on the appropriation bills last year, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made a great noise about what he would do for `Mr and Mrs Namadgi', as he termed them. But what last year's budget and now this year's budget, compounding, have really produced is an attack on the greatest proportion of my community. As a result of the actions of this government, confidence in this city is so low as to be alarming.

The government puts itself up as a supporter of small business. Let's talk about small business in my constituency. The recent Yellow Pages Index says it all. Dr John Marsden, the economic adviser to that index, said, `Frankly, we have never seen confidence levels as low as they now are in the ACT.' That is a pretty damning quote. I consistently have many business people come and tell me of the difficulties they are facing in continuing to hold their business together. In fact, in all cases that I am referring to, we are talking about family businesses—small enterprises. Unfortunately, this uncertainty and low confidence is being exacerbated by the actions of the local Liberal government. They continue to jump from decision to decision, with certainty the last thing in their minds—and that is the last thing we need.

Let us hope we see the adoption of the government majority report Finding a balance as soon as possible. Each day that passes is a day of difficulty and anxiety for these people. The Trade Practices Amendment (Better Business Conduct) Bill of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) should also be debated and adopted immediately. These are the sorts of things that we need in order to give some relief to small business in this electorate. This budget has seen disastrous decisions for the ACT—for example, selling off government‐owned buildings. In the budget, it was announced that 11 major buildings in this town would be sold—and this at a time, I might add, when commercial tenancy levels are sitting at around 10 per cent, and when some of the 11 to be sold are described in the sale prospectus as largely vacant or with a vacant area of 20 per cent, for example.

Who on earth is going to be able to buy these buildings with a lease future in such doubt? One suggestion has been that the government could undertake to lease them back partly empty to ensure a lease future for the purchaser. But what a waste! Some people may make a bit of a profit in the manoeuvre of selling these buildings, but I can tell you one thing: in my electorate, my families see it as nothing other than another blow to government confidence in this town.

BREAK.PARA: Let us talk about employment. It was notable on the night of the delivery of the budget how much the Treasurer (Mr Costello) did not in fact want to speak about employment; but I do. Our youth unemployment levels have been too high for too long; in fact, they have reached as high as 50 per cent. They are down from that now, but they are still above 30 per cent. Our general unemployment levels in Canberra are also too high. Like other communities around this country, we are desperately looking for ways to replace our shrinking industry. The industry which has primarily been shrinking here is the public sector. Historically, the public sector is why Canberra is here. But all of the other sectors in our community are now suffering from that retraction.

The Newcastles and the Geelongs all have legitimate concerns about their futures, and I support them totally; but so does this town. Some people have been heard to say, `It's about time you in Canberra knew what it was like to feel tough times!' I constantly hear stupid, insulting remarks from individuals on the other side of this place who enjoy having a shot at Canberra—and they are pretty cheap shots, at that—and it is really remarkable, because they are from people who have worked so hard to get to Canberra! Those people need to keep in mind, when they feel gratified in making such silly remarks and go back to their own constituencies and boast about it, that it is Australian families that they are attacking.

When you promise to govern for all Australians, you cannot get away with that attitude, and we will constantly remind you of that. Canberra has suffered under past attacks and I recall—unfortunately, very well—the Lynch razor gang. That was pretty infamous. But we got over that and, despite the efforts of those opposite and many others, we will get over this time as well. But we need opportunities. We will happily become more diverse in our employment base. In fact, that has already started; it started some years ago. But we must have the circumstances and the conditions to allow that to happen.

The National Museum project is one way towards that—a decision out of the budget which I welcome. But it can only be of benefit to our community if our community has a role in it. Our ACT construction industry workers want to build that project. They do not want to sit and watch others come in from other parts of the country and build it in front of them. We must have a method. It is absolutely paramount for the future economic viability of Canberra that the National Museum project right now is packaged in such a way that our local construction industry and our local economy generally have an ability to tender and compete in a fair manner. They are not asking for handouts; they do not want this project given to them on a silver platter. What they want is a fair way of competing.

We have already seen the first major contract for that project, the project management first phase contract, go to a company from interstate. We have already seen trucks, much to the derision of many in this town on the Liberal side of politics, sitting protesting on that Acton Peninsula, as they watched trucks from interstate come in and move rubble from the site ready for construction. They have my absolute support for holding that demonstration. We have got to somehow show those in power that this town really does need the work that will flow on from the National Museum project. It is absolutely essential; I cannot put enough emphasis on it. It is incumbent upon the government, both local and federal, to ensure that that project is managed in such a way that the ACT construction industry has a fair and equal way of competing for it.

Let us look at a few other decisions that have been contained in this budget. The much mooted savings plan is fine for those who are in a position to benefit from it, but hardly a thing goes into the pockets of my constituency, the struggling families out there now losing their jobs or having already lost their jobs. The taxpayers who have no interest income to declare, the taxpayers on below average weekly earnings who do not receive any interest, the full rate age and service pensioners and the unemployed—none of those people benefit from that at all, so let us not tout it around as the saviour to the whole of the community. It is not.

The new drugs tax basically removes $600 million out of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Might I add that the PBS is the envy of most countries in this world for the way that it has been developed and run over the years, giving access and equity to so many people for pharmaceutical products. The government is now only going to provide a full subsidy for the cheapest drug in each of the six groups that they have listed, treating high blood pressure, high cholesterol, ulcers and depression. If you want to get a better drug you will have to pay for it. The point is most people will not be in a position to do that. The president of the AMA, Dr Keith Woollard, has said that although separate medications within the six nominated classes had a similar therapeutic effect, they could have different side effects which made them less appropriate for some patients. He said:
They have—
the government—
lumped them together as drugs having basically identical actions, but in fact they don't.
We really need to think a little bit more carefully about what we are in fact starting to do to the PBS.

Another area of concern to me and to many of my colleagues is the question of child care. Last year's budget cut $500 million—half a billion dollars—out of child care. This year's budget cuts an additional $321 million. What on earth is happening? In my electorate the childcare sector is desperate. They are having to increase fees, compromise their standards or consider closure. I would like to make a note here for the benefit of members. All of the players in the child‐care sector are sharing the concern in this. The private centres, the community based centres, the out‐of‐school care, the holiday care, the family day care, who have in fact survived budget cuts to date, and the occasional care are united as one in their total opposition to the way this government is approaching the provision of child care. Families are increasingly under pressure; they are being forced into making decisions they have never wanted to make. In my electorate they lose their job so they do not need child‐care, therefore the child‐care centre is immediately under pressure for numbers. Or they have a job but they cannot afford the increased fees. Again the child‐care centre is under pressure.

A range of reasons why parents and families may access non‐work‐related care exist, but now there is a weekly limit placed on that and therefore there is this assumption that for some reason you can control the reasons why people may need to access non‐work‐related care. I can think of many very legitimate reasons why families need to access non‐work‐related care without any cap being put on it whatsoever. Child care is all about options, so that whatever your circumstances, should you have a need to access child care you can do so in a flexible, diverse and affordable system, with high standards, qualified staff and the care of children the paramount purpose. Our families are losing out but most importantly, our children will be the losers should these sorts of decisions be allowed to continue.

I represent a constituency which happens to form part of the ACT—Canberra, the national capital. As I said in my inaugural speech, the people who have chosen to make this their home—and in most instances that is the case; they have chosen to come here—should not ever have to apologise for the fact that they live here. When Australian tourists from other cities and states come to Canberra, many come with a view, perpetuated through the media or through politicians opposite, that `Canberra did this to you' or `Canberra did that to you'. They come here bringing that sort of view with them, that this is a cold place—not just in winter, but in other ways—full of well‐off, well‐paid public servants and with a few national buildings that might be worth a bit of a look on the way from A and B to get to Grandma's.

Our tourist surveys show that, without any doubt, the overwhelming majority of people who visit here, whether they come with that opinion or not, leave with a quite different one. When they come here they visit this building and they leave with a pride in this building. They visit this city and they leave with a pride in this city as their national capital. They understand and recognise the role of this city and the role of this territory. When this Prime Minister makes budget decisions that attack this community, when members opposite go off making derisive comments about this community, when this Prime Minister decides not to live in the Lodge, these are all attacks not only on this community but on the role of the national capital.

It really is very puzzling to me. Prime Minister Menzies, who is held up as a bit of an icon to many of those opposite—particularly our current Prime Minister—was in fact the Prime Minister who recognised the relevance of the national capital and who did so much to ensure its future. What he did not know that he had to factor in was the treachery of the current Prime Minister towards the future of this city. The continuing attacks on the public sector, the continuing attacks on the public service, the continuing uncertainty and the increasing lack of confidence are all eating away at this community. Our families, our young people, our businesses, the people who have invested their money in businesses in this community, our community organisations—all the people who make up the fabric of our community—deserve better. They deserve job security, a vision for our future, and a confidence that there is a reason for people to continue to have a future in our national capital.

We are not just talking about Canberra here; we are talking about the region. I had an interesting experience yesterday morning when I was listening to ABC radio and heard interviewed, successively, three gentlemen who are local shire presidents or, in one case I think, a mayor, of areas that surround the ACT. They were uniform in one thing, that the effect of the government decisions on Canberra was rippling strongly through this region and that the government would continue to do that in those regions at its peril. We do not hold any of those seats, I might add. But I will tell you what: continue these sorts of decisions and we jolly well will. People are not going to take that sort of attitude being shown to this city and this region; they are not going to sit down and not do anything about it.

When I talk about the fabric of our community, the condition of that fabric really reflects the health of our community. Let me say very clearly: that fabric is starting to look pretty frayed at the edges in this town. The community organisations and the very community structure that exist in a city like this—and in other places as well—comes from the community.
