You start to attack that, you start to de‐fund it, you start to attend to it in a cursory fashion and what you are doing is attacking the very health of that community. Here in Canberra we have reached that point. It is absolutely essential that this government immediately gets rid of this attitude of derision and contempt towards the ACT and the people who live in it. As I said at the outset, none of them need apologise for living here—that should not have to be their burden. The role of the national capital is essential to this nation and has to be recognised.

My message about this budget, from my electorate and my territory where I live, work and represent my community, is: enough is enough. The time has come to turn that attitude around and start to understand the reality of the effect on the families in my electorate, on my community, on the economy, and on all of the things that affect the health of that community. My message to the Prime Minister is very clear: you have done so much to bad effect to this town, none of it deserved at all, and it is about time you woke up to yourself and treated this place the way you promised to treat everywhere else—to govern for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a privilege and an honour to speak on an appropriation bill. Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98 is before the House, and I welcome the opportunity to speak on what was a very good budget. It must be remembered that, when the coalition came to office over 14 months ago, we had the excesses of the former government portrayed very clearly in the $10,000 million black hole in the budget. The coalition was unaware of this figure. The previous government was aware of it, but they did not disclose those figures during the 1996 election campaign. They certainly did not disclose the full details of this country's indebtedness.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to be able to speak on this because the coalition has taken the necessary measures to reduce the deficit. They have done that in this year's budget with no increase in debt, no increase in tax, and we are now heading towards a small surplus.

I was intrigued by the contribution from the member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis). She spent 15 minutes making a contribution towards families, and I applaud her for her concern. She then spent five minutes attacking the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for giving consideration to his own family. I felt that the honourable member for Namadgi let herself down in her contribution on the budget speech in that regard.

I particularly wanted to address the regional Australian implications which were contained in this budget. It was an excellent budget for regional Australia. The Commonwealth is going to make major contributions into regional areas in Australia, including spending more than $800 million on construction and maintenance of national highways and roads of national importance. I will come back to the roads of national importance later in my contribution.

Certainly, more than 90 per cent of the available funds will be spent on rural roads throughout Australia. This will be of great benefit to regional Australia not only for improving the road network but also in contributing to the number of jobs that will be a result of that major construction on roads and highways.

The government also introduced the biggest natural resources program ever in the history of Australia, the Natural Heritage Trust, which will see $1.25 billion being spent on an integrated and long‐term strategy for the sustainable management of Australia's land, water, native vegetation and biodiversity. This is a major contribution to the area of central Victoria and the electorate of Bendigo which I have the privilege to represent. We have got some major issues which need to be addressed in that area, particularly in the management of land and water. The quality of water and the management of catchments within what is part of the Murray‐Darling river system is always a critical issue for the Bendigo electorate. We have two northern flowing rivers, the Loddon and Campaspe, which both flow into the Murray system.

The regional telecommunications infrastructure fund was also a significant boost for country and rural Australia, with an allocation of a substantial amount of money which will give people living in the regions across Australia high quality telecommunications facilities and services that people in metropolitan areas currently take for granted and have had for many years.

BREAK.PARA: In many parts of my electorate there have been small country and rural exchanges which monitor and process the calls, but the constituents never knew how much those calls were costing because they did not receive itemised phone accounts. I am pleased to say that, through negotiations by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) and Telstra, that program has been advanced. By the end of 1998, many of those small exchanges throughout my electorate will have itemised billing and have all the state‐of‐the‐art technology facilities available to the constituents in my electorate.

The introduction of a dedicated assistance to depressed regions program in the budget was important. As people in this chamber would recognise, some parts of Victoria and some other parts of Australia are still experiencing drought conditions. I know the weather factor does have an enormous impact on my electorate. We went through a period of drought and it certainly does have a terrible impact on the residents of the area. I am pleased to see that the assistance package to depressed regions will take those factors into consideration.

The changes to Austudy in the budget will provide more education assistance to regional and rural families. Families with students who need to study away from home will be major beneficiaries. That is important for country people. An increase in the income disregard for families with more than two tertiary students living away from home will mean that students from the regions currently receiving Austudy may receive up to $925 a year more. That is a very welcome initiative, particularly in the electorate of Bendigo.

A new business plan for Australian agriculture is going to be developed to place the industry on a sustainable footing. My congratulations to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), who is doing an excellent job in that portfolio. A national planning system for the Commonwealth child‐care program ensures that services are established in the areas of need. An additional 2,500 family day care places will be provided in the period 1997‐98 to 2000‐01.

The Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency is a new initiative by the government to implement a one‐stop shop in the delivery of services, and that is currently being implemented. It commenced on Monday of this week in the city of Bendigo and I understand that it is providing a more convenient way for people to access the services of both the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security.

I want to touch briefly on local government, because we made a substantial contribution to local government over the last two budgets. In this year's budget the estimated financial assistance grants for local government will be $1.205 billion. Funding to local government through those grants has increased by $40 million over the two budgets handed down by the Howard government. That is a total increase of 3½ per cent from the last Labor budget, in 1995‐96. So local government are in a better position following the increases in financial assistance grants, which they certainly welcomed.

The regional Australia aspects that I have touched on are very important, and none is more important than transport, which is a major issue for everyone in a rural area. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), has indicated a total allocation of $1.606 billion for roads in 1997‐98. As I said earlier, 90 per cent of that Commonwealth spending on roads will be allocated outside of capital cities.

I particularly want to mention one program. At the initiation of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, a roads of national importance category was introduced. Some $112 million has been allocated to this program. One of the roads in that category—and one which affects residents of my electorate—is the Calder Highway in Victoria. The minister recognised the need to upgrade the Calder Highway to a road of national importance. It is now attracting more money. A substantial amount of money was put into the Calder Highway to take it up to a dual‐carriageway, four‐lane highway. That is going along very well at the moment.

Obviously, we could always do with a few more dollars. I put in my bid regularly to the minister to ensure that that road of national importance attracts additional funding, because it is particularly important for trade and commerce. It is also the outlet for the whole of the northern Victorian area—the Sunraysia area—for carriage of goods to the markets, shipping ports and airports, and it is very important for the carriage of primary produce.

The road safety accident black spots program was abolished by the previous government. Members of that government should hang their heads in shame for abolishing that program. It took a coalition government initiative to reintroduce it. It is very important to road safety. It is a $149 million program over four years.

My electorate has already been the beneficiary of much needed funds for some of the black spots areas, where there has been a high level of accidents. We received over $1 million for improvements to those areas, some of which have already been carried out. The bulk of those programs will be completed by the end of June. They are certainly important in terms of employment because of the construction period, the changes that have been made and the implementation of those programs in the Bendigo electorate.

I now turn to primary industry, which is important to Australia, both domestically and for export markets. The process of sustainable resource management in primary industries introduced by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is receiving a great deal of commendation from industry leaders in the primary industry sector. He certainly is making a very strong impression, both here and overseas, on our markets. The need for sustainable resource management is being addressed comprehensively by the Commonwealth and a record total funding of $166.5 million has been made available for 1997‐98.

I also compliment the minister on his very quick action when there was a suspicion that fire blight was in the central Victorian area. Members would be aware that a substantial fruit industry exists in my electorate, and close to my electorate in the seat of Murray. I commend the speedy action taken by Minister Anderson to address this question. He got experts from both state and federal resources to swing into action, and to clear, in particular, the Harcourt area, which is world renowned for its apple quality, of any presence of fire blight.

In the communications area, the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, announced a regional telecommunications infrastructure fund. The $50 million allocated in this budget, and the progress of that rural and regional telecommunications infrastructure fund to improve regional and rural telecommunications infrastructure, is very important.

These days, it does not matter where you are in the world, you can run your activities, your business and your home, provided you have access to the latest services and good communications. It is very important for rural and regional Australia. A total of $250 million over five years has been allocated to this program. Already we are seeing the benefits of it in my area with the upgrading of rural exchanges and local exchanges so that modern facilities can be hooked up to the phone system and a whole range of services can be delivered at that point.

The minister has done extremely well with this initiative. It has been welcomed by many people throughout the electorate that I represent. It also helps in the furtherance of mobile phone coverage. Recently, we have seen an expansion of that through Heathcote and Castlemaine—two areas which had poor reception. That is now being upgraded and the mobile phone network will be improved to both of those districts.

Another matter I would like to mention is overseas aid. Australia has always played a very strong role in overseas aid. The budget has been very supportive, particularly of food aid. Many of the volunteers from my area who go on overseas aid programs welcomed Australia's contribution to the increase in food aid. Australia's international aid obligations under the Montreal protocol and global environment facility, as well as our obligations to provide 300,000 tonnes of wheat or wheat equivalent as food aid per annum under the food aid convention, will be met.

That is good news for the rural community in terms of their input into that, but also the assistance provided through the AusAID non‐government cooperation program will be increased by $3 million, or 17 per cent in real terms, and the volunteer programs will continue to be funded at 1996‐97 levels. As Australia plays an important part in providing aid to a number of countries, this certainly is welcome news in the budget.

I also want to touch briefly on the education side of the budget. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) is doing an amazing job pulling back some of the problems that the previous government left. Australia's 10,000 schools will receive an extra $152 million from the federal government in the 1997‐98 budget. The schools budget has increased by 4 per cent, from $3.6 billion in 1996‐97 to $3.75 billion in 1997‐98.

The 1997‐98 funding package features $560 million for special programs, including $160 million for literacy, $156 million for students with special learning needs, and $54 million for languages. An extra $7 million has been earmarked for Australia's new national literacy and numeracy plan. This was agreed to by federal, state and territory education ministers in March of this year. That is all welcome news in the education field.

The minister has introduced a number of initiatives, including funding for new apprenticeships. That was an area that was terribly neglected by the previous government. We will be providing $265 million for more than 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships in 1997‐98. Already, many young people have been taken on as apprentices in my area. I commend the employers for taking those young people on.

I would have liked to speak for a lot longer on this topic. Overall, the budget has been welcomed by the Australian community. We are still repairing the damage that was left to us by the previews government, and no doubt there is still a little way to go, but we are approaching a situation where the budget processes are improving Australia's economic climate and interest rates are coming down—I think there have been four interest rate drops in the past 12 months. Obviously, the economy is responding to the positive initiatives of the government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Any Australian waking up and reading the newspapers this morning would realise that we have a few problems on our hands. The headline of the Sydney Morning Herald is `Recession hits factories.' The headline of the business section of that paper says, `R word'—that is, the recession word—`is back and Govt blames the dollar.' This government is into blaming; it is always blaming something, someone or some phenomena. It is not looking at itself. The manufacturing sector, the second biggest employer in the country, is officially in recession after yesterday's national account figures showed the sector contracted for the second successive quarter in March, as the commentary in the Sydney Morning Herald said. As the Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, Mr Allan Handberg, said:

SPEECH.PARA: This is now a genuine concern to us and it should be for the Government. The Government must spell out clearly its vision for Australian manufacturing.
He also said:
There is a lack of confidence and a degree of uncertainty coming from a lack of consumer confidence.
In another analysis, the Sydney Morning Herald economic commentator said:
. . . important employment generating sectors of retailing and manufacturing, and service industries like health and education, were either in recession or experiencing negligible growth.
In the same article, Mr Richard Gibbs of the Macquarie Bank commented:
It does not augur well for employment and that's the rub.
As the first sentence under the lead headline of the Sydney Morning Herald said:
The manufacturing sector is now officially in recession . . .
The article concluded that the question was asked:
. . . why annual growth had halved from 4.9 per cent when Labor was last in office to 2.4 per cent.
One recalls the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), after he came into office, that this government had inherited an economy which was better than good in parts—or words to that effect.

The thrust of my comments this morning are very much directed to the issue of a lack of vision for industry and its interrelationship with the chronic unemployment that we are suffering. My comments will focus on why this government is simply incapable of addressing those problems while it maintains its current philosophical underpinning. That philosophical underpinning is one of classical liberalism. It is perhaps the most economically fundamentalist government in recent Australian history.

The philosophy of the classical liberal economists is that anything emanating from government is bad; government has to make a flawed, irrational or illogical decision and, therefore, the appropriate role for government is to contract government to get government out of the way and let the free market forces take over the show. Apparently, these free market forces have the ability to generate some miraculous cures and miraculous phenomena. All that is needed, according to the classic liberals, is to let the free market have its rein. But it leads to what I have called the doctrine of calculated neglect. While the government maintains its allegiance to that doctrine, it is incapable of backing Australian industry.

Certainly, if everyone is honest with themselves, they will realise the manufacturing sector is the only sector that is going to generate sufficient jobs to eat into Australia's unemployment. Indeed, the government, when in opposition, realised that with their promise of 200,000 jobs by the year 2000 in the manufacturing sector.

What has happened? There is evidence that the government is prepared to trade off tariffs on Australian manufactured goods for reductions in foreign tariffs on primary goods. While it is appropriate for government to enter into negotiations about tariff reductions and mutuality, as a result of the influence of the National Party, their thrust is all one way and they are turning their backs on and ignoring the manufacturing sector. We are risking very much a return to the 1950s when we exported our primary products, let the foreign countries value add and we bought back finished products at much higher prices after labourers in other countries had obtained the benefit of using their skills to value add to our primary products.

In their obsession to remove the impurities from the free market, the government has cut back industry assistance from $561 million to $146 million over the next four years. Assistance to exporters is down $26 million in the same period. Last year's budget took $400 million away from exporters and exports fell from 11 per cent to seven per cent, and it actually made a negative contribution to growth. Now, we are facing a situation where foreign debt, under the Liberals in just one year, has exceeded that for two years under Labor. One recalls the great play they made of the issue of foreign debt during the election campaign.

In addition to removing assistance, they have come around and they have hit Australian exporters with higher charges. There will be an additional $14.4 million imposed for Australian businesses wanting to use the services of Austrade and they have brought forward the recovery of the export facilitation loans by $9 million over the next four years. In terms of export promotion, the government has literally vacated the field. They have abandoned the National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference and they have virtually withdrawn from all major expositions.

I asked a series of questions on notice to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore). In question No. 618 I asked, `Where and when will the next world exposition take place?' The answer was Lisbon, Portugal, in 1998. I asked, `Will Australia be represented at the next expo and, if so, what form will that representation take?' The simple answer was, no. I asked, `What theme will be presented by Australia at the expo and how far have plans developed for Australia's representation?' The reply came back: a simple, `not applicable'. That highlights the attitude of this government's industry policy. It is one which is not applicable.

I followed up that question with question No. 1367 to the minister. I asked whether he was able to say how many countries would be represented at the world exposition in Portugal in 1998. If Australia was not to have a presence, why not, and was he able to say whether countries in Australia's region would have a presence at Lisbon and, if so, which countries? The reply came back that he understood that 100 countries had agreed to participate and that Australia's decision not to participate was one taken on economic grounds in light of fiscal targets. In terms of which countries from our region would be attending, his astonishing reply was: `I have no knowledge of which countries may have agreed to participate.'

The decision not to participate in the Lisbon expo was taken in circumstances where the minister had no information as to which countries were going to participate and, specifically, which countries from our region. That just shows you how lacking this minister is in terms of promoting Australian products, as compared with competitors in our region.

I asked the minister a further question. In question No. 1366, I asked,`Is a world exposition to be held at Hamburg, Germany, in the year 2000?' He corrected me and said, `No. Expo 2000 will be in Hanover, Germany.' I also asked him whether Australia would participate in that exposition and he said, no.

We are looking at a situation where we are coming up to perhaps the most significant event in Australia's modern history, the year 2000 Olympics. Two years before that at Lisbon, we had the opportunity to expose ourselves to the rest of the world to promote tourism and the government ignored that opportunity. The answer came back in terms of what we would be demonstrating and portraying Australia as—`not applicable'.

BREAK.PARA: We are looking at the year 2000 exposition in Hanover, perhaps one of the greatest events for the turn of the century, aside from the Olympics, when there inevitably is going to be great interest and Australia is not on the field—not even got its boots on. How is Australia going to kick any goals? It will not. There is a lesson that any politician can tell this minister: out of sight and out of mind. If you are not seen, you are not considered and people ignore you. That is what is going to happen to Australia as a result of the complete absence of any vision or any promotion of the interests of Australia.

That the proof of the pie is in the eating is very much an old cliche, but Australians have had the opportunity to taste the pie of this government and they have found they are only eating pastry. It is one without any substance. Most thinking, successful and dynamic Australians are bored, if not disillusioned, with this government.

Aside from export promotion, the government has abolished industry assistance programs. There has been no reversal of last year's policy to take $2.9 million from programs. It slashed research and development. It has abolished the DIFF scheme and it has removed bounties in a number of new and growing industries: ship building, computers, books, tool making and robotics—all industries in their embryonic stages.

In terms of protecting our Australian industry, this government has indicated it is prepared to unilaterally disarm Australia's car industry and the textile, clothing and footwear industry. Rather than putting a pause on tariff reductions until our competitors match the goodwill that we have demonstrated, the government looks like it is going to go even further ahead of the pack. As a result of their efforts, it looks like our very important car industry and indeed the textile, clothing and footwear industry may be in real trouble.

While the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism is suggesting there may be some compromise, there would be no member on the other side of the House who would not believe that the Treasury line is going to prevail in cabinet and these supposed impediments to the free market operating, the Treasury will say, have to be removed. Australians already know what the outcome will be and our industry is going to suffer.

Yesterday the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith), referred to the quote where Gough Whitlam said, `The impotent are pure'. While this government is pure in adhering to its economic fundamentalism, it is also very much an impotent government. Its obsession with academic theories is precluding it from properly addressing the reality of what Australia faces in this very competitive world.

I, not only for subjective reasons but objectively, predict if this government continues down the line it is going, it is going to be a very short-lived government indeed. For instance, an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 3 June 1997 showed that Australians are willing to sacrifice cheaper cars and clothes in order to secure Australian industry and the accompanying jobs. The reference was to the AGB McNair survey of 1,000 voters and that showed that 92 per cent of voters voiced their support for maintaining an Australian car industry. Australians certainly are not economic fundamentalists; on the whole they are realists. They are usually balanced and thoughtful people.

Another good indication of the mood of the electorate is in a speech given by Rod Cameron, the managing director of ANOP Research Services to the Minerals Council of Australia at a seminar on 29 May 1997. Mr Cameron predicted as a result of his research that aspects of industry policy will dominate political debate in this country in the foreseeable future. The government has already lost that debate, it has no industry policy.
In terms of the concerns that are being reflected in the electorate, he said in respect to the BHP announced closure of its Newcastle steelworks:
Perhaps no single announcement by a company in recent years has had a greater unsettling impact on ordinary Australians than this one has.

In terms of the decline of manufacturing industry, Mr Cameron said that there is real concern about the absence of jobs for apprentices, and the recent termination of apprentices by Qantas had demonstrated that. Further on he said there is a:
worry about an over reliance on imported products
and he said:
Toss in headlines about the balance of payments and you have quite considerable concern about the growing absence of Australian made goods and produce.
these individual triggers are combining to create a state of mind in Australians that is far from relaxed and comfortable.
That was the catchcry used by the Prime Minister before the last election. Mr Cameron continued by saying there is:
an emerging frustration that government cannot see the sense of supporting and encouraging Australian industry.
He said that there is a gloom about an Australia on the verge of returning to being an export quarry rather than value adding to our own resources. He concluded with these prophetic words:
Australians are demanding that their leaders produce a plan—a plan for industry—that shows them how jobs will be created. . .

Sooner rather than later this government will realise that it must turn its mind to industry policy . . . The only alternative to doing so is substantially to decrease the time before this government is voted out to be replaced by one which does see a role for governments in interfering with the free market in an effort to recreate industrial growth.
The reality is the government has no industry policy. It cannot address the concerns that are being voiced by Australians. These are real concerns.

In terms of the insecurity that is currently being felt, unemployment programs have been slashed. Between March and April this year, 16,200 people joined the ranks of the long-term unemployed. That is 40,000 people since this government came to power. An amount of $14.3 million has been cut from vocational and industry training, $70 million cut from education training grants to the states, and that is on top of of $183 million cut in last year's budget. Traineeships have reduced in growth from 117 per cent to 68 per cent under this government, almost halving, despite the rhetoric of the government.

In my region, unemployment has increased by 2.2 per cent in the last 12 months. It is the greatest increase in the Sydney region. In one area where I have a significant migrant population, the rate is currently 8.1 per cent. Clearly, the Australian public expects governments to play a positive role in addressing these problems. This government's obsession with reducing the size of government in the hope that market forces will miraculously stimulate industry and give jobs to Australians is nothing more than ideological bloody mindedness.

We need a government which is prepared to reintroduce direct, targeted unemployment programs, one that has a vision for industry and one which assists our traders to export Australian products. This government is none of those things. The current Liberal‐National Party government is incapable of achieving those essential requirements. Australians will find that the only useful purpose the leadership of this current government has is to retreat to the environs of academia and lecture about the bygone days of classical, liberal, economic theory, but it is their very obsession with that philosophy that is preventing them from solving Australia's problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this debate and pleased to have this opportunity to follow the member for Barton (Mr McClelland), who is noted as an intelligent and articulate member of the parliament, but who has just espoused a great deal of nonsense, as he knows. He cannot possibly expect me to rise following his speech without responding to some of that nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Barton suggests, quoting the guru of the ALP, Gough Whitlam, that there is something impotent about this government—which at this stage is largely following, in tariff terms, the very policies his party put in place. Does he really expect me to swallow that sort of argument and not respond? Here we are, pursuing the elusive level playing field—the very policies that his government pursued as well, policies that we believed were defensible, policies that we could have capitalised on in opposition by saying just the same sorts of things as the member for Barton has chosen to say this afternoon. Because we at least had the electoral stamina not to run down the popular course but the responsible one, we backed his government on tariff reductions. Now he expects us to pursue the same tariff reduction policy in government while he has the luxury of being critical.

He quoted from a news release which, by the way, I have as well. I presume it is one from the Australian Business Chamber, but it matters not whether it is the same one or not because it is true that a survey undertaken by the chamber discovered that 92 per cent of Australians said they would prefer to forgo cheaper imports—the very point the member for Barton made—in favour of protecting Australian industry and jobs. If that is true, if that is what this chamber is to believe, if that is what the member for Barton believes, tell me why it is that every time I step out of this door, or the door of my own home, or my office in my electorate, I am inundated by imported cars? Clearly, Australians are prepared to put one thing on paper and do something else when it comes to delivering the goods.

If Australians were really prepared to defend Australian industry and to buy Australian made goods, at least in the automotive area, they would be buying the more expensive Australian production which, thanks to the former government, is now at least of equal quality, and in some cases better quality, than the imported product. I concede that; we do have a much better car industry—that is why we supported you. If Australians were prepared to buy those cars they would protect Australian jobs. The reality is that they do not really care that much, I am sorry to say. I wish you were right, I wish that survey was right, because if it were I need not worry about protecting Australian jobs. Australian consumers would do it for me.

I did not want to spend my entire speech referring to the member for Barton's contribution. I wanted to tell the chamber that in the Andrew house there was a happy event early in the year when my son got married in Brisbane. This may seem somewhat unrelated to the appropriation bill, except that when we returned from this happy event my wife announced to the entire family, me included, something that left us quivering. She said that, having been through a family wedding where everything had been very happy, she was now going to introduce a family ER policy. The kids knew what she meant and I knew what she meant. She meant we were going to have a little economic rationalism in the Andrew house, because we were going to pay off the Bankcard and pay off a few incurred debts before we got back to the normal luxurious lifestyle.

Fortunately, on a parliamentary salary, it did not take long to balance the books, but for a while the 15‐year‐old was very twitchy about no longer being able to go to the movies when he wanted to. My wife knew what Australians fundamentally know—that is, if you have spent more than you have earnt, you have to do something about it. The budget we have handed down and that we are dealing with in this appropriation bill is simply a budget of a government that is saying, `We are going to stop spending more than we are earning. We are going to prune our expenditure.'

Just like the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe), the member for Barton and the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), I have had to front nursing homes and child‐care centres which are not ecstatic about the government pruning their expenditure. But what I can say to them is that we have taken a $10 billion deficit that we did not run up and we have got it to the point where we can confidently predict a surplus in one term. That is responsible economic management. That does something for the national economic outlook. That does something in the long term for jobs.

It also does something, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) indicated in question time yesterday, for the overseas debt. In spite of what the member for Barton has said—and he may well be right that the debt is rising—the government's portion of that debt will be pruned back by this government because we now have the capacity to do so. I have not checked the foreign debt figures and, if you are right, sir, I will gladly concede.

As someone coming into government, I always thought the foreign debt would rise anyway. How do you have an economic recovery unless people are importing goods in order to be more efficient producers and to generate more exports? It is to be expected that there may be a hiccup upwards in the foreign debt, as part of making a more efficient and export oriented Australia.

The member for Barton was relatively kind to us on the job front, but most of the other speakers from the opposition have been critical of the budget on the grounds that it has done nothing for unemployment. As if we could run around, as they did for at least a decade, creating mickey mouse jobs so people had nothing more than a revolving door, job training program! We are committed to doing something about jobs. The member for Barton, in his speech, would have said, `Hang on. If you are committed to doing something about jobs'—I do not want to put words into his mouth; he will nod or shake his head if I am misinterpreting him—`why are you taking this action with the manufacturing industry and with the car industry, action that may in fact put people out of work?'

Let me tell the chamber what I suspect everyone already knows: tariffs have almost nothing to do with jobs in Australia. Jobs in Australia are disappearing only because of technological advances, not because of tariffs. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know that, and the member for Lyne knows it. I can turn around the job market in Australia tomorrow by being a dictator who says to every farmer in the electorate of Wakefield, `Listen, Sam: you are no longer going to hop on your fancy self‐propelled combine. Instead of that, you are going back to the horse and the plough and the bag,' and of course jobs will be created. I can say to every wine grape grower, `The harvest you have just taken off with a machine is the last one you will take off with a machine. From now on, you are back to the bucket and the picker and the bin,' and of course I will create jobs. I have no doubt that I can say to the car manufacturing industry the same thing: `Throw away those robots you have modified from Japan and put on more people.'

Whether it is a farmer or a wine grape grower or a car manufacturer, we all know that they would employ more people and go out of business. What is costing jobs in Australia is technological advance. I regret it, but I cannot stop it happening if I am to be at the cutting edge in a competitive world. Here we are asking how we can keep competitive industry in Australia but keep people employed and, at the same time, keep ourselves as efficient as our competitors are. It is a very difficult balancing act, not solved by running simple arguments about tariffs.

The member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) ran a very good illustration of what tariffs do. He said that tariffs are like taking a small town called Morgan and saying to everybody who lives in Morgan, `The local builder is about to leave the town. What I am going to do, as dictator of Morgan, is to say the local builder, "We will make sure no‐one else comes into this town to build unless they put a 25 per cent impost on their costs. So you cannot come in as a bricklayer to Morgan unless you charge 25 per cent more."' The Morgan builder will say, `Great idea. I'll stay. My children will stay at the school. My wife will still be at the hospital. All will be well.'

But we all know that, over one year, perhaps nothing will happen. Over five years, suddenly we will discover the local builder does not have to work as hard as he used to because he has got a 25 per cent insulation against competition. Worse than that, over 10 years, suddenly every house in the town—the parsonage, the school house, and all the rest—is 25 per cent dearer than it used to be because you have kept the competition at arm's length.

Why are we, as parliamentarians, saddled with this tariff argument that the member for Barton has put in more simplistic language than he knows is defensible? Because we know that, while we can protect a local industry, in very short time we effectively put that industry out of business because our competitors are not doing the same thing. That is why the parliament is where it is. That is why the ALP in government advocated lower tariffs. That is why we backed them when they were doing it. That is why in government we have taken up this difficult mantle. If we are to keep Australia efficient, if we are to keep Australia in the export market—the very thing the member for Barton called for—we have to be prepared to do what the rest of the world is doing.

I can almost hear the arguments from the other side. `That is fine, Neil, but, in fact, the rest of the world is not doing it. There is no level playing field, and we are being very gullible.' And the member for Barton nods his head. But, sir, I am on this course because you put me on it. There is no such thing as a level playing field and there never will be such a thing. What we have achieved and the former government achieved, and we are endeavouring to keep it going, is that for the first time in your life and mine, we have a more level playing field than we have ever had before, because no signatory to the World Trade Agreement is able to be a signatory unless that country has agreed to lowering their tariff barriers.

It is easy to say, and my electorate is crying out for me to say, `Let's have a pause until they catch us up.' Delightfully simplistic, very saleable! But here I am, an Australian federal parliamentarian, and my country, with the best will in the world, cannot generate two per cent of world trade. I am not the tail on the end of the world trade dog; I am the flea on the end of the tail of the world trade dog.

BREAK.PARA: This government has no leverage at all in world trade terms. You know it and I know it. We are obliged to do what the World Trade Organisation allows us to do. Passionately, we may put our case in the World Trade Organisation, as your trade minister did and as ours does. But to pretend that we can say to 98 per cent of the world `Hang about; we're going to set the terms' is nonsense. It is nonsense to pretend that we can say to them `Hang about; we'll have a pause and wait for you to catch up.' They will say, `Get lost; we will promptly put our barriers up against whatever you're offering us.'

Why do I feel some passion about this? Because, unlike most other members of this parliament—maybe not all, but certainly most—I am someone whose annual return is directly affected by tariffs. Most of you know that I am in the citrus industry. I am insulated from it, thankfully, by a parliamentary salary. The input of Brazilian concentrated orange juice directly affects the productivity of my property. The people in the area that I represent want me to stand up and say, `Let's have a bigger tariff barrier against Brazilian imports.' But they fail to recognise that, as a result of being signatories to the World Trade Organisation, my Riverland citrus growers now enjoy access to markets that were closed to them.

What am I going to do? Put at risk that market access; put at risk that opportunity to earn export dollars for Australia by locking out cheaper Brazilian imports! It sounds simplistic but, of course, it would be ultimately to the nation's detriment. That is why it is so much nonsense to run the present car tariff argument. That is why the Adelaide Advertiser ought to be hung, drawn and quartered for the nonsense they have been running in my state about car tariffs. They have been running simplistic drivel that you would expect from people who are ill‐informed about tariffs, but not from the sole newspaper in a state.

What is the reality? The reality is that we are on the car tariff carriage that the ALP set up, and it was always due to run to 15 per cent. The question is not what happens to the 15 per cent—because, frankly, it is neither here nor there. The question is what do we do about encouraging that market, that industry, to be competitive to continue to make a real contribution to manufacturing exports by keeping it at the cutting edge of world efficiency.

I do not have a simplistic answer to that. I do not even have a complicated one because I am not in the car industry. But I do know this. I know that the export facilitation program gave the car industry the opportunity to be an exporter for the first time and that it now exports something like 60,000 units. If I can get that to something like 100,000 units, I have kept that industry in Australia and all of that has got very little to do with the last 15 per cent of tariff protection.

I think it is time that, as a parliament, we stood up and spoke with one voice about tariffs, because what you were advocating and what we are advocating is precisely the same thing. If the ALP had still been in government, they would have faced just the same difficult decision over the degree to which we manipulate the remaining segment of car tariffs—little as it is—and retain our opportunity to be seen as serious players in the World Trade Organisation.

What the government is currently going through is this difficult balancing act between keeping the car industry efficient and keeping our obligations to the WTO. Under world trade and under market access, we have enjoyed an opportunity to put a whole lot of Australian goods, not just primary, manufactured as well, in markets that were closed to us. People have the view that we are the only ones with an open market system. It is nonsense. What is the tariff on Australian automobiles going into Japan? Zero.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quotaed isn't it?

—I freely concede that it is quotaed—but it is zero. There is a real step forward because, under you, we achieved a zero tariff with a quotaed arrangement and the opportunity to negotiate those quotas. Japan, previously the most protected market in world terms, is now in a situation where it takes Australian rice, citrus and wheat. Would you have us put all of those advantages at risk simply by running the populist line currently being peddled by the Adelaide Advertiser and to a lesser extent by some of my colleagues opposite?

BREAK.PARA: If we are serious about employment in Australia, the obligation we have is to foster those industries in which we are at cutting edge of the rest of the world. It probably will not be manufacturing thongs or T‐shirts but it might be manufacturing cars. It will certainly be manufacturing wine. There is a classic illustration of an industry which has now export domination without any protection at all and it is effectively a manufacturing industry, if you look at the degree of value added that occurs.

So the obligation that we have as a parliament is to identify those industries where we can outperform the rest of the world and get on with encouraging them. This budget, by reducing our deficit, allows us to do just that and, by adhering to the World Trade Organisation, we can ensure that we will not be locked out of markets that were previously closed to us.

I am proud to be a part of a government that has had the intestinal fortitude to continue unpopular policies, knowing that they are right, and the tariff industry is a classic one of those. It is time that, as a parliament, we endeavoured to speak with one voice on the question of the access that we need to have to export markets.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sercombe) adjourned.
